Dimorphic Hemorrhoids.description: Hemorrhoids, also known as piles, are swollen and inflamed veins in the lower rectum or anus. They can develop internally inside the rectum (internal hemorrhoids) or externally under the skin around the anus (external hemorrhoids).
Dimorphic Hemorrhoids.symptoms: Itching or irritation around the anus,Pain or discomfort, especially during bowel movements
Dimorphic Hemorrhoids.treatment: Increasing fiber intake to soften stools and reduce straining, drinking plenty of fluids, and using over-the-counter creams or suppositories to relieve symptoms.

Pneumonia.description: Pneumonia Pneumonia is an inflammatory condition of the lung affecting primarily the microscopic air sacs known as alveoli. It is usually caused by infection with viruses or bacteria and less commonly other microorganisms, certain drugs and other conditions such as autoimmune diseases. Source: Wikipedia
Pneumonia.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Fever, Chills, Wheezing, Nasal congestion, Cough, Vomiting, Difficulty breathing, Sore throat, Weakness, Coryza, Sharp chest pain, Often producing phlegm or mucus, which may be green, yellow, or even bloody,Often high, accompanied by chills and sweating.
Pneumonia.treatment: Usually resolves on its own, but antiviral medications may be prescribed in certain cases, such as influenza. Symptomatic treatment includes rest, fluids, and over-the-counter medications to relieve fever and pain.
Pneumonia.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for pneumonia include age 75+ years, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years.

Varicose Veins.description: Varicose veins are enlarged, twisted veins that commonly occur in the legs and feet due to increased pressure in the veins. They often appear as blue or dark purple and can be raised above the surface of the skin.
Varicose Veins.symptoms: Aching, heavy, or uncomfortable legs, swollen feet and ankles, burning or throbbing in the legs, muscle cramps, particularly at night, dry, itchy, and thin skin over the affected vein, and in severe cases, skin discoloration or ulcers around the ankles.
Varicose Veins.treatment: Lifestyle changes such as exercising regularly, losing weight, avoiding long periods of standing or sitting, elevating the legs, and wearing compression stockings can help manage the condition.

Psoriasis.description: Psoriasis Psoriasis /suraj.Yshs/ is an immune-mediated disease that affects the skin. It is typically a lifelong condition. There is currently no cure, but various treatments can help to control the symptoms. Source: Wikipedia
Psoriasis.symptoms: Joint pain, Skin moles, Skin growth, Itchy scalp, Skin lesion, Skin swelling, Acne or pimples, Abnormal appearing skin, Skin rash, Irregular appearing scalp, Itching of skin, Skin dryness, peeling, scaliness, or roughness, Red patches of skin covered with thick, silvery scales, dry and cracked skin that may bleed, itching, burning, or soreness, thickened or ridged nails, and swollen and stiff joints.
Psoriasis.treatment: Topical treatments like corticosteroids, vitamin D analogs, salicylic acid, and coal tar
tests: Other diagnostic procedures on skin and subcutaneous tissue
Referral to home health care service
Psoriasis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for psoriasis include age 60-74 years age 45-59 years.

Acne.description: Acne Acne vulgaris (cystic acne or simply acne) is a common human skin disease, characterized by areas of skin with seborrhea (scaly red skin), comedones (blackheads and whiteheads), papules (pinheads), pustules (pimples), nodules (large papules) and possibly scarring. Acne affects mostly skin with the densest population of sebaceous follicles; these areas include the face, the upper part of the chest, and the back. Severe acne is inflammatory, but acne can also manifest in noninflammatory forms. The lesions are caused by changes in pilosebaceous units, skin structures consisting of a hair follicle and its associated sebaceous gland, changes that require androgen stimulation. Source: Wikipedia
Acne.symptoms: Skin moles, Long menstrual periods, Skin growth, Acne or pimples, Skin swelling, Too little hair, Nose deformity, Abnormal appearing skin, Skin rash, Irregular appearing scalp, Warts, Skin dryness, peeling, scaliness, or roughness, Acne manifests as various types of skin lesions including pimples (papules) and pus-filled lesions (pustules), as well as blackheads (open comedones), whiteheads (closed comedones), cysts (painful, pus-filled lumps beneath the skin), and nodules (large, solid, painful lumps beneath the surface of the skin).
Acne.treatment: Effective treatments for acne include over-the-counter topical treatments such as benzoyl peroxide or salicylic acid, which help to reduce oil production and unclog pores. Prescription medications like antibiotics (topical or oral) are often used to kill acne-causing bacteria and reduce inflammation.
tests: Other non-OR therapeutic procedures on skin and breast
medications: Alight Plus Gel 15gm for Acne Treatment
Acne.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for acne include age 5-14 years age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years almost never get acne.

Fungal infection.description: Fungal infections, also known as mycoses, are caused by various types of fungi that can affect different parts of the body. These infections can range from superficial, affecting the skin, nails, and hair, to systemic, impacting internal organs.
Fungal infection.symptoms: Red, itchy, and peeling skin between the toes, often accompanied by a burning sensation,Ring-shaped, red, and scaly patches on the skin that are often itchy.
Fungal infection.treatment: Creams, ointments, or powders applied directly to the affected area, such as clotrimazole, miconazole, or terbinafine, are commonly used for skin infections.

urinary tract infection.description: A urinary tract infection (UTI) is a common bacterial infection that affects any part of the urinary system, including the kidneys, ureters, bladder, and urethra.
urinary tract infection.symptoms: Burning sensation or pain during urination,Cloudy or bloody urine,Pelvic pain in women.Rectal pain in men
urinary tract infection.treatment: In addition to antibiotics, drinking plenty of water and urinating frequently helps flush out bacteria from the urinary tract. Pain relievers such as ibuprofen may also be recommended to alleviate discomfort.

Impetigo.description: Impetigo Impetigo /jmphtajao/ is a highly contagious bacterial skin infection most common among pre-school children. People who play close contact sports such as rugby, American football and wrestling are also susceptible, regardless of age. Impetigo is not as common in adults. The name derives from the Latin impetere ("assail"). It is also known as school sores. Source: Wikipedia
Impetigo.symptoms: Fever, Nasal congestion, Skin lesion, Cough, Skin swelling, Mouth ulcer, Abnormal appearing skin, Skin rash, Itching of skin, Skin on head or neck looks infected, Peripheral edema, Sore in nose, The symptoms of impetigo include red sores that quickly rupture, ooze for a few days, and then form a honey-colored crust. The sores are often itchy and can spread to other parts of the body through scratching
Impetigo.treatment: Mild cases can often be treated with topical antibiotics like mupirocin or retapamulin, which are applied directly to the affected areas. For more severe or widespread infections, oral antibiotics such as dicloxacillin, cephalexin, or clindamycin may be prescribed
tests: Referral to home health care service
Impetigo.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for impetigo include age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years.

Chicken pox.description: Chickenpox, also known as varicella, is a highly contagious viral infection caused by the varicella-zoster virus (VZV). It predominantly affects children but can occur at any age. The infection is characterized by an itchy rash that turns into fluid-filled blisters and eventually scabs over.
Chicken pox.symptoms: The initial symptoms of chickenpox include fever, tiredness, loss of appetite, and headache. These symptoms are soon followed by the development of a red, itchy rash that starts on the face, chest, and back before spreading to the rest of the body
Chicken pox.treatment: Common approaches include the use of antihistamines or calamine lotion to reduce itching, acetaminophen (paracetamol) for fever and pain relief, and maintaining good hygiene to prevent secondary bacterial infections.

Malaria.description: Malaria Also known as Malarial Fever and Paludism Malaria is a mosquito-borne infectious disease of humans and other animals caused by protists (a type of microorganism) of the genus Plasmodium. It begins with a bite from an infected female Anopheles mosquito, which introduces the protists through saliva into the circulatory system. In the blood, the protists travel to the liver to mature and reproduce. Malaria causes symptoms that typically include fever and headache, which in severe cases can progress to coma or death. The disease is widespread in tropical and subtropical regions in a broad band around the equator, including much of Sub-Saharan Africa, Asia, and the Americas. Source: Wikipedia
Malaria.symptoms: Ache all over, Vulvar sore, Fever, Fainting, Headache, Back pain, Knee lump or mass, Vomiting, Excessive growth, Itchy eyelid, Wrist weakness, Weakness, The most common symptoms include recurring episodes of fever, often accompanied by chills and sweating.
Malaria.treatment: Antimalarial medications are the cornerstone of treatment and include drugs like chloroquine, artemisinin-based combination therapies (ACTs), and other specific antimalarial agents.
Malaria.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for malaria include age 45-59 years.

gastroesophageal reflux disease.description: Gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD) is a chronic condition characterized by the backward flow of stomach acid and occasionally bile into the esophagus, leading to irritation and inflammation.
gastroesophageal reflux disease.symptoms: Heartburn, a burning sensation in the chest that often occurs after eating or when lying down.
gastroesophageal reflux disease.treatment: Initial treatment involves lifestyle modifications such as avoiding trigger foods,eating smaller meals, maintaining a healthy weight, not lying down immediately after eating, and elevating the head of the bed., over-the-counter antacids

peptic ulcer disease.description: Peptic ulcer disease (PUD) refers to painful sores or ulcers that develop in the lining of the stomach, the first part of the small intestine (duodenum), or sometimes in the lower esophagus.
peptic ulcer disease.symptoms: Burning stomach pain,Nausea and vomiting,Feeling of fullness or bloating
peptic ulcer disease.treatment: Proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) and H2-receptor antagonists (H2 blockers) are commonly used to reduce stomach acid production and allow the ulcer to heal. Antibiotics are prescribed if H. pylori infection is present,use antacids

Dengue.description: Dengue fever is a mosquito-borne viral infection that causes flu-like illness and can sometimes develop into severe dengue, also known as dengue hemorrhagic fever or dengue shock syndrome, which can be life-threatening.
Dengue.symptoms: The initial symptoms include a sudden high fever, severe headaches, pain behind the eyes, severe joint and muscle pain, fatigue, nausea, vomiting, and a skin rash that appears two to five days after the onset of fever.
Dengue.treatment: Management focuses on relieving symptoms and includes rest, adequate fluid intake to prevent dehydration, and medications like acetaminophen (paracetamol) to reduce fever and pain.

Common Cold.description: The common cold is a viral infection of the upper respiratory tract, primarily affecting the nose and throat.
Common Cold.symptoms: Symptoms of the common cold include a runny or stuffy nose, sneezing, sore throat, coughing, mild headache, body aches, and a general feeling of being unwell.
Common Cold.treatment: Ensuring adequate rest helps the bodyâ€™s immune system fight off the infection,Decongestants (like pseudoephedrine) can help reduce nasal congestion, while antihistamines (like diphenhydramine) can relieve sneezing and runny nose.

Cervical spondylosis.description: Cervical spondylosis is a condition characterized by degenerative changes in the cervical spine (neck region) due to wear and tear over time.
Cervical spondylosis.symptoms: Common symptoms of cervical spondylosis include neck pain that may radiate to the shoulders and arms, stiffness in the neck, headaches (often originating from the neck), tingling or numbness in the arms or hands, and weakness in the muscles of the arms or hands.
Cervical spondylosis.treatment: Rest, physical therapy to strengthen neck muscles and improve range of motion, and pain management with nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs) or muscle relaxants.

diabetes.description: Diabetes is a chronic metabolic disorder characterized by elevated blood sugar levels (hyperglycemia) due to either insufficient insulin production by the pancreas or the body's inability to effectively use insulin
diabetes.symptoms: Increased thirst and frequent urination,Unexplained weight loss,Blurred vision
diabetes.treatment: Monitoring blood sugar,Healthy eating,Regular exercise improves insulin sensitivity and helps manage weight.

allergy.description: Allergy refers to an overreaction of the immune system to substances that are typically harmless to most people.
allergy.symptoms: Sneezing and runny or stuffy nose,Itchy, watery eyes,Swelling of the lips, tongue, or throat
allergy.treatment: Antihistamines,Decongestants,Nasal corticosteroids sprays reduce inflammation in the nasal passages and are effective for treating allergic rhinitis.

Bronchial Asthma.description: Bronchial asthma is a chronic respiratory condition characterized by inflammation and narrowing of the airways, making breathing difficult. It is typically triggered by various factors, including allergens, irritants, respiratory infections, exercise, and emotional stress.
Bronchial Asthma.symptoms: Asthma symptoms include recurrent episodes of wheezing (a whistling sound when breathing), shortness of breath, chest tightness, and coughing, especially at night or early in the morning
Bronchial Asthma.treatment: This includes daily use of anti-inflammatory medications such as inhaled corticosteroids to reduce airway inflammation and prevent asthma symptoms

Hypertension.description: Hypertension, commonly known as high blood pressure, is a chronic medical condition where the blood pressure in the arteries is consistently elevated.
Hypertension.symptoms: Headaches, shortness of breath, chest pain, dizziness, and nosebleeds may occur.
Hypertension.treatment: These include adopting a healthy diet rich in fruits, vegetables, and whole grains while limiting salt intake, maintaining a healthy weight, regular physical activity, limiting alcohol consumption, and avoiding smoking.

Migraine.description: Migraine Also known as Migraine Headaches and Migraine Syndrome Migraine is a chronic neurological disorder characterized by recurrent moderate to severe headaches often in association with a number of autonomic nervous system symptoms. The word derives from the Greek ! (hemikrania), "pain on one side of the head", from !- (hemi-), "half", and (kranion), "skull". Source: Wikipedia
Migraine.symptoms: Long menstrual periods, Nausea, Headache, Symptoms of the face, Spots or clouds in vision, Blindness, Vomiting, Disturbance of memory, Dizziness, Diminished vision, Migraine headaches typically involve throbbing pain on one side of the head, although they can affect both sides.
Migraine.treatment: Over-the-counter pain relievers like ibuprofen or aspirin may be effective for mild migraines.
tests: Other OR Rx procedures on respiratory system and mediastinum
Migraine.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for migraine include age 30-44 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get migraine.

Arthritis.description: Arthritis refers to a group of conditions involving inflammation of the joints. It can affect people of all ages and is characterized by symptoms such as joint pain, stiffness, swelling, and decreased range of motion.
Arthritis.symptoms: Joint pain, stiffness, swelling, and decreased range of motion.
Arthritis.treatment: Treatment options vary but may include medications to reduce inflammation and pain, physical therapy to improve joint function and mobility, lifestyle changes like exercise and weight management, and in severe cases, surgery to repair or replace damaged joints.

Typhoid.description: Typhoid fever is a serious infectious disease caused by the bacterium Salmonella Typhi. It spreads through contaminated food and water and is most prevalent in areas with poor sanitation and hygiene.
Typhoid.symptoms: Initial symptoms include sustained high fever, weakness, fatigue, headache, and loss of appetite. As the disease progresses, other symptoms may appear, such as abdominal pain, diarrhea or constipation, a rash with rose-colored spots, an enlarged spleen or liver, and in severe cases, confusion, delirium, and intestinal bleeding or perforation.
Typhoid.treatment: Treatment for typhoid fever primarily involves antibiotics to kill the bacteria. Commonly used antibiotics include ciprofloxacin, azithromycin, and ceftriaxone.

Jaundice.description: Jaundice is a medical condition characterized by yellowing of the skin, sclera (white part of the eyes), and mucous membranes due to elevated levels of bilirubin in the blood.
Jaundice.symptoms: Yellowing skin,whites of the eyes, and mucous membranes. Other symptoms may include dark urine (due to bilirubin excretion), pale stools (due to lack of bilirubin in the intestines), itching (pruritus), fatigue, abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting.
Jaundice.treatment: Various medications may be used to treat the conditions leading to jaundice, such as steroids in the treatment of some autoimmune disorders. Certain patients with cirrhosis, for example, may require treatment with diuretics and lactulose.

drug reaction.description: A drug reaction, also known as a drug allergy or adverse drug reaction (ADR), refers to an unexpected and harmful response to a medication or drug.
drug reaction.symptoms: Skin reactions such as rash, hives, itching, or blistering,nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or abdominal pain.
drug reaction.treatment: Stopping the offending drug is usually the first step to prevent further harm,Medications such as antihistamines or corticosteroids may be used to manage symptoms like itching, rash, or swelling.

Anemia of chronic disease.description: Anemia of chronic disease Anemia of chronic disease, also referred to as anemia of inflammatory response, or ACD, is a form of anemia seen in chronic illness, e.g. from chronic infection, chronic immune activation, or malignancy. New discoveries suggest that the syndrome is likely largely the result of the body's production of hepcidin, a master regulator of human iron metabolism. Source: Wikipedia
Anemia of chronic disease.symptoms: Emotional symptoms, Chills, Low back weakness, Vomiting, Coryza, Itching of skin, Weight gain, Fatigue, Dizziness, Feeling ill, Weakness, Diarrhea
Anemia of chronic disease.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for anemia of chronic disease include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, age 15-29 years, and age < 1 years almost never get anemia of chronic disease.

Dysthymic disorder.description: Dysthymic disorder Also known as Dysthymia Dysthymia (/djs.aj.mi.Y/ dis-THEYE-mee-Y), from Ancient Greek , "melancholy"}}), also known as neurotic depression, dysthymic disorder, and chronic depression, is a mood disorder consisting of the same cognitive and physical problems as in depression, with less severe but longer-lasting symptoms, which may persist for at least 2 years. The concept was coined by Dr. Robert Spitzer (an editor of the American Psychiatric Association's Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-III)) as a replacement for the term "depressive personality" in the late 1970s. Source: Wikipedia
Dysthymic disorder.symptoms: Disturbance of memory, Temper problems, Low self-esteem, Fears and phobias, Slurring words, Excessive anger, Antisocial behavior, Insomnia, Depression, Anxiety and nervousness, Loss of sex drive, Depressive or psychotic symptoms
tests: Psychological and psychiatric evaluation and therapy
Other OR therapeutic procedures on nose; mouth and pharynx
Dysthymic disorder.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for dysthymic disorder include age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get dysthymic disorder.

Scarlet fever.description: Scarlet fever Also known as Scarlatina Scarlet fever (also called scarlatina in older literature) is an infectious disease which most commonly affects 4-8 year old children. Symptoms include sore throat, fever and a characteristic red rash. Scarlet fever is usually spread by inhalation. There is no vaccine, but the disease is effectively treated with antibiotics. Most of the clinical features are caused by erythrogenic toxin, a substance produced by the bacterium Streptococcus pyogenes (group A strep.) when infected by a certain bacteriophage. Source: Wikipedia
Scarlet fever.symptoms: Throat swelling, Fever, Penis pain, Skin swelling, Cough, Difficulty in swallowing, Skin rash, Mouth pain, Sinus congestion, Groin pain, Sore throat, Coryza
Scarlet fever.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for scarlet fever include age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years and race/ethnicity = black. On the other hand, age 75+ years and age 45-59 years almost never get scarlet fever.

Hypertensive heart disease.description: Hypertensive heart disease Hypertensive heart disease includes a number of complications of systemic arterial hypertension or high blood pressure that affect the heart. While there are several definitions of hypertensive heart disease in the medical literature, the term is most widely used in the context of the International Classification of Diseases (ICD) coding categories. The definition in the Tenth Revision of the International Classification of Diseases (ICD-10) includes heart failure and other cardiac complications of hypertension when a causal relationship between the heart disease and hypertension is stated or implied on the death certificate. According to ICD-10, hypertensive heart disease (I11), and its subcategories: hypertensive heart disease with heart failure (I11.0) and hypertensive heart disease without heart failure (I11.9) are distinguished from chronic rheumatic heart diseases (I05-I09), other forms of heart disease (I30-I52) and ischemic heart diseases (I20-I25). However, since high blood pressure is a risk factor for atherosclerosis and ischemic heart disease, death rates from hypertensive heart disease provide an incomplete measure of the burden of disease due to high blood pressure. Source: Wikipedia
Hypertensive heart disease.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Recent pregnancy, Palpitations, Chest tightness, Fluid retention, Fatigue, Insomnia, Heartburn, Difficulty breathing, Leg swelling, Weakness, Sharp chest pain
Hypertensive heart disease.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for hypertensive heart disease include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, age 15-29 years, and age < 1 years almost never get hypertensive heart disease.

Drug abuse (barbiturates).description: Drug abuse (barbiturates) Drug abuse (barbiturates) is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Drug abuse (barbiturates).symptoms: Abnormal involuntary movements, Drug abuse, Abusing alcohol, Hostile behavior, Slurring words, Delusions or hallucinations, Excessive anger, Depression, Anxiety and nervousness, Depressive or psychotic symptoms
tests: Psychological and psychiatric evaluation and therapy
Drug abuse (barbiturates).riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for drug abuse (barbiturates) include age 30-44 years age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years and age < 1 years almost never get drug abuse (barbiturates).

Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).description: Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS) Also known as Stein Leventhal Syndrome and Ovarian Hyperthecosis A complex disorder characterized by infertility, HIRSUTISM; OBESITY; and various menstrual disturbances such as OLIGOMENORRHEA; AMENORRHEA; ANOVULATION. Polycystic ovary syndrome is usually associated with bilateral enlarged ovaries studded with atretic follicles, not with cysts. The term, polycystic ovary, is misleading. Source: MeSH
Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).symptoms: Long menstrual periods, Painful menstruation, Cramps and spasms, Acne or pimples, Heavy menstrual flow, Pelvic pain, Absence of menstruation, Infertility, Weight gain, Intermenstrual bleeding, Unpredictable menstruation, Hot flashes
Polycystic ovarian syndrome (PCOS).riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for polycystic ovarian syndrome (pcos) include age 30-44 years, sex == female and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, sex == male, age 60-74 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get polycystic ovarian syndrome (pcos).

Encephalitis.description: Encephalitis Also known as Brain Inflammation Encephalitis (from Ancient Greek enkphalos brain , composed of in and head , and the medical suffix -itis inflammation ) is an acute inflammation of the brain. Encephalitis with meningitis is known as meningoencephalitis. Symptoms include headache, fever, confusion, drowsiness, and fatigue. More advanced and serious symptoms include seizures or convulsions, tremors, hallucinations, and memory problems. Source: Wikipedia
Encephalitis.symptoms: Joint pain, Headache, Paresthesia, Loss of sensation, Disturbance of memory, Leg pain, Seizures, Fatigue, Problems with movement, Insomnia, Dizziness, Leg weakness
tests: Physical therapy exercises; manipulation; and other procedures
Encephalitis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for encephalitis include age 5-14 years age 45-59 years.

Cyst of the eyelid.description: Cyst of the eyelid Also known as Eyelid Cyst Cyst of the eyelid is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Cyst of the eyelid.symptoms: Symptoms of eye, Eyelid lesion or rash, Skin growth, Itchiness of eye, Skin rash, Mass on eyelid, Elbow cramps or spasms, Abnormal movement of eyelid, Muscle swelling, Wrinkles on skin, Diminished vision, Pain in eye
tests: Ophthalmologic and otologic diagnosis and treatment
Other therapeutic procedures on eyelids; conjunctiva; cornea
Cyst of the eyelid.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for cyst of the eyelid include race/ethnicity = other, age 60-74 years and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years almost never get cyst of the eyelid.

Balanitis.description: Balanitis Balanitis (/blYnajtjs/; from Greek: balanos "acorn") is inflammation of the glans penis. When the foreskin is also affected, it is termed balanoposthitis. Source: Wikipedia
Balanitis.symptoms: Diaper rash, Fever, Penis pain, Painful urination, Skin lesion, Penis redness, Cough, Suprapubic pain, Abnormal appearing skin, Skin rash, Itching of skin, Penile discharge
tests: Prostate specific antigen measurement (Prostate specific antigen test)
Balanitis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for balanitis include race/ethnicity = other, race/ethnicity = hispanic, sex == male, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years.

Foreign body in the throat.description: Foreign body in the throat Also known as Pharyngeal Foreign Body Foreign body in the throat is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Foreign body in the throat.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Throat swelling, Infant spitting up, Lymphedema, Paresthesia, Difficulty in swallowing, Cough, Vomiting, Infant feeding problem, Difficulty breathing, Sore throat, Coughing up sputum
Foreign body in the throat.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for foreign body in the throat include age 75+ years, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years.

Drug abuse (cocaine).description: Drug abuse (cocaine) Also known as Cocaine Abuse Cocaine (INN) (benzoylmethylecgonine, an ecgonine derivative) is a crystalline tropane alkaloid that is obtained from the leaves of the coca plant. The name comes from "coca" and the alkaloid suffix -ine, forming cocaine. It is a stimulant, an appetite suppressant, and a topical anesthetic. Biologically, cocaine acts as a serotonin norepinephrine dopamine reuptake inhibitor, also known as a triple reuptake inhibitor (TRI). It is addictive because of its effect on the mesolimbic reward pathway. Source: Wikipedia
Drug abuse (cocaine).symptoms: Drug abuse, Abusing alcohol, Hysterical behavior, Hostile behavior, Fears and phobias, Delusions or hallucinations, Excessive anger, Nightmares, Depression, Depressive or psychotic symptoms, Sharp chest pain
Drug abuse (cocaine).riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for drug abuse (cocaine) include age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = black and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get drug abuse (cocaine).

Optic neuritis.description: Optic neuritis Optic neuritis is a condition consisting in the inflammation of the optic nerve that may cause a complete or partial loss of vision. Source: Wikipedia
Optic neuritis.symptoms: Symptoms of eye, Eyelid swelling, Headache, Retention of urine, Spots or clouds in vision, Blindness, Fatigue, Diminished vision, Pain in eye
tests: Other therapeutic procedures on eyelids; conjunctiva; cornea
Optic neuritis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for optic neuritis include age 30-44 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get optic neuritis.

Alcohol withdrawal.description: Alcohol withdrawal Alcohol withdrawal syndrome is the set of symptoms seen when an individual reduces or stops alcohol consumption after prolonged periods of excessive alcohol intake. Excessive use of alcohol leads to tolerance, physical dependence, and an alcohol withdrawal syndrome. The withdrawal syndrome is largely due to the central nervous system being in a hyper-excitable state. The withdrawal syndrome can include seizures and delirium tremens and may lead to excito-neurotoxicity. Source: Wikipedia
Alcohol withdrawal.symptoms: Fainting, Abnormal involuntary movements, Nausea, Abusing alcohol, Vomiting, Dizziness, Delusions or hallucinations, Seizures, Antisocial behavior, Depressive or psychotic symptoms, Weakness, Sharp chest pain
Alcohol withdrawal.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for alcohol withdrawal include age 30-44 years, sex == male and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get alcohol withdrawal.

Premature atrial contractions (PACs).description: Premature atrial contractions (PACs) Also known as Premature Atrial Beats, Premature Atrial Complexes, Ectopic Atrial Beats, and Atrial Premature Beat Cardiac dysrhythmia (also known as arrhythmia or irregular heartbeat) is any of a large and heterogeneous group of conditions in which there is abnormal electrical activity in the heart. The heartbeat may be too fast or too slow, and may be regular or irregular. A heart beat that is too fast is called tachycardia and a heart beat that is too slow is called bradycardia. Although many arrhythmias are not life-threatening, some can cause cardiac arrest. Source: Wikipedia
Premature atrial contractions (PACs).symptoms: Shortness of breath, Fainting, Frequent urination, Irregular heartbeat, Pus in urine, Palpitations, Chest tightness, Increased heart rate, Fatigue, Muscle swelling, Dizziness, Sharp chest pain
Premature atrial contractions (PACs).riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for premature atrial contractions (pacs) include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get premature atrial contractions (pacs).

Hemiplegia.description: Hemiplegia Hemiplegia /he.mY.pli.diY/ is total paralysis of the arm, leg, and trunk on the same side of the body. Hemiplegia is more severe than hemiparesis, wherein one half of the body has less marked weakness. Hemiplegia and Hemiparesis may be congenital, or they might be acquired conditions resulting from an illness, an injury, or a stroke. Source: Wikipedia
Hemiplegia.symptoms: Abnormal involuntary movements, Difficulty speaking, Headache, Arm weakness, Cramps and spasms, Loss of sensation, Slurring words, Seizures, Focal weakness, Problems with movement, Weakness, Arm stiffness or tightness
Hemiplegia.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for hemiplegia include race/ethnicity = other age 5-14 years.

Hammer toe.description: Hammer toe A hammer toe or contracted toe is a deformity of the proximal interphalangeal joint of the second, third, or fourth toe causing it to be permanently bent, resembling a hammer. Mallet toe is a similar condition affecting the distal interphalangeal joint. Source: Wikipedia
Hammer toe.symptoms: Skin growth, Foot or toe swelling, Skin lesion, Foot or toe pain, Loss of sensation, Problems with movement, Irregular appearing nails
tests: Bunionectomy or repair of toe deformities
Hammer toe.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for hammer toe include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get hammer toe.

Open wound of the cheek.description: Open wound of the cheek Open wound of the cheek is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.

Meningioma.description: Meningioma Meningiomas are a diverse set of tumors arising from the meninges, the membranous layers surrounding the central nervous system. They arise from the arachnoid "cap" cells of the arachnoid villi in the meninges. These tumors are usually benign in nature; however, a small percentage are malignant. Many meningiomas are asymptomatic, producing no symptoms throughout a person's life, and require no treatment other than periodic observation. Symptomatic meningiomas are typically treated with either radiosurgery or conventional surgery. Historical evidence of meningiomas has been found going back hundreds of years, with some successful surgeries for their removal beginning in the 1800s. Source: Wikipedia
Meningioma.symptoms: Difficulty speaking, Headache, Nausea, Facial pain, Disturbance of memory, Dizziness, Seizures, Diminished hearing, Focal weakness, Weakness, Depressive or psychotic symptoms, Diminished vision
Meningioma.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for meningioma include age 75+ years, age 60-74 years and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, age 15-29 years, and age < 1 years almost never get meningioma.

Brain cancer.description: Brain cancer Also known as Cancer Of The Brain and Malignant Neoplasm Of Brain A brain tumor, or tumour, is an intracranial solid neoplasm, a tumor (defined as an abnormal growth of cells) within the brain or the central spinal canal. Source: Wikipedia

Brain cancer.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for brain cancer include age 5-14 years.

Placental abruption.description: Placental abruption Also known as Abruptio Placenta and Accidental Hemorrhage Placental abruption (also known as abruptio placentae) is a complication of pregnancy, wherein the placental lining has separated from the uterus of the mother. It is the most common pathological cause of late pregnancy bleeding. In humans, it refers to the abnormal separation after 20 weeks of gestation and prior to birth. It occurs in 1% of pregnancies worldwide. Placental abruption is a significant contributor to maternal mortality worldwide; early and skilled medical intervention is needed to ensure a good outcome, and this is not available in many parts of the world. Treatment depends on how serious the abruption is and how far along the woman is in her pregnancy. Source: Wikipedia
Placental abruption.symptoms: Uterine contractions, Emotional symptoms, Cross-eyed, Nausea, Cramps and spasms, Spotting or bleeding during pregnancy, Excessive growth, Problems during pregnancy, Itchy eyelid, Elbow cramps or spasms, Wrist weakness, Lower abdominal pain
Placental abruption.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for placental abruption include race/ethnicity = other, sex == female and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, sex == male, age 60-74 years, and age 45-59 years almost never get placental abruption.

Seasonal allergies (hay fever).description: Seasonal allergies (hay fever) Also known as Hay Fever, Seasonal Allergic Rhinitis, and Pollenosis Hay Fever is a comic play written by Nol Coward in 1924 and first produced in 1925 with Marie Tempest as the first Judith Bliss. Laura Hope Crews played the role in New York. Best described as a cross between high farce and a comedy of manners, the play is set in an English country house in the 1920s, and deals with the four eccentric members of the Bliss family and their outlandish behaviour when they each invite a guest to spend the weekend. The self-centred behaviour of the hosts finally drives their guests to flee while the Blisses are so engaged in a family row that they do not notice their guests' furtive departure. Source: Wikipedia
Seasonal allergies (hay fever).symptoms: Painful sinuses, Itchiness of eye, Headache, Frontal headache, Nasal congestion, Cough, Lacrimation, Coryza, Sore throat, Sneezing, Allergic reaction, Ear pain

Seasonal allergies (hay fever).riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for seasonal allergies (hay fever) include age 5-14 years age 1-4 years.

Lung cancer.description: Lung cancer Also known as Carcinoma Of Lung and Pulmonary Carcinoma Lung cancer is a disease characterized by uncontrolled cell growth in tissues of the lung. If left untreated, this growth can spread beyond the lung in a process called metastasis into nearby tissue or other parts of the body. Most cancers that start in lung, known as primary lung cancers, are carcinomas that derive from epithelial cells. The main types of lung cancer are small-cell lung carcinoma (SCLC), also called oat cell cancer, and non-small-cell lung carcinoma (NSCLC). The most common symptoms are coughing (including coughing up blood), weight loss and shortness of breath. Source: Wikipedia
Lung cancer.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Drainage in throat, Cough, Hemoptysis, Smoking problems, Decreased appetite, Fatigue, Leg weakness
Lung cancer.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for lung cancer include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, age 15-29 years, and age < 1 years almost never get lung cancer.

Eye alignment disorder.description: Eye alignment disorder When you look at an object, you re using several muscles to move both eyes to focus on it. If you have a problem with the muscles, the eyes don t work properly. There are many kinds of eye movement disorders. Two common ones are: Strabismus a disorder in which the two eyes don t line up in the same direction. This results in crossed eyes or walleye. Nystagmus fast, uncontrollable movements of the eyes, sometimes called dancing eyes Some eye movement disorders are present at birth. Others develop over time and may be associated with other problems, such as injuries. Treatments include glasses, eye muscle exercises, and surgery. There is no treatment for some kinds of eye movement disorders, such as most kinds of nystagmus. Source: MedlinePlus
Eye alignment disorder.symptoms: Symptoms of eye, Cross-eyed, Double vision, Foreign body sensation in eye, Eye deviation, Eye moves abnormally, Lack of growth, Irregular appearing scalp, Swollen lymph nodes, Abnormal movement of eyelid, Diminished vision, Pain in eye
tests: Other extraocular muscle and orbit therapeutic procedures

Pyloric stenosis.description: Pyloric stenosis Also known as Gastric Outlet Obstruction, Pyloric Obstruction, and Gastric Outflow Obstruction Pyloric stenosis (or infantile hypertrophic pyloric stenosis or pylorostenosis) is a condition that causes severe projectile non-bilious vomiting in the first few months of life. There is narrowing (stenosis) of the opening from the stomach to the first part of the small intestine known as the duodenum, due to enlargement (hypertrophy) of the muscle surrounding this opening (the pylorus, meaning "gate"), which spasms when the stomach empties. This hypertrophy is felt classically as an olive-shaped mass in the middle upper part or right upper quadrant of the infant's abdomen. In pyloric stenosis, it is uncertain whether there is a real congenital narrowing or whether there is a functional hypertrophy of the pyloric sphincter muscle. This condition typically develops in male babies in the first 2 6 weeks of life. Source: Wikipedia
Pyloric stenosis.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Pain during pregnancy, Burning abdominal pain, Infant spitting up, Regurgitation, Restlessness, Cough, Vomiting, Vomiting blood, Wheezing, Arm stiffness or tightness, Symptoms of infants
Pyloric stenosis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for pyloric stenosis include race/ethnicity = hispanic, sex == male, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years. On the other hand, age 15-29 years almost never get pyloric stenosis.

Salivary gland disorder.description: Salivary gland disorder Also known as Salivary Gland Disease The salivary glands in mammals are exocrine glands, glands with ducts, that produce saliva. They also secrete amylase, an enzyme that breaks down starch into maltose. In other organisms such as insects, salivary glands are often used to produce biologically important proteins like silk or glues, and fly salivary glands contain polytene chromosomes that have been useful in genetic research. Source: Wikipedia
Salivary gland disorder.symptoms: Jaw swelling, Neck mass, Facial pain, Skin swelling, Cough, Swollen lymph nodes, Mouth dryness, Peripheral edema, Neck swelling, Sore throat, Throat feels tight, Ear pain

Osteochondrosis.description: Osteochondrosis Osteochondrosis is a family of orthopedic diseases of the joint that occur in children and adolescents and in rapidly growing animals, particularly pigs, horses, and dogs. They are characterized by interruption of the blood supply of a bone, in particular to the epiphysis, followed by localized bony necrosis, and later, regrowth of the bone. This disorder is defined as a focal disturbance of endochondral ossification and is regarded as having a multifactorial etiology, so no one thing accounts for all aspects of this disease. Source: Wikipedia

Metabolic disorder.description: Metabolic disorder Inborn errors of metabolism comprise a large class of genetic diseases involving disorders of metabolism. The majority are due to defects of single genes that code for enzymes that facilitate conversion of various substances (substrates) into others (products). In most of the disorders, problems arise due to accumulation of substances which are toxic or interfere with normal function, or to the effects of reduced ability to synthesize essential compounds. Inborn errors of metabolism are now often referred to as congenital metabolic diseases or inherited metabolic diseases. Source: Wikipedia
Metabolic disorder.symptoms: Difficulty eating, Scanty menstrual flow, Problems with shape or size of breast, Recent weight loss, Muscle pain, Smoking problems, Weight gain, Infant feeding problem, Mouth dryness, Jaundice, Underweight, Arm stiffness or tightness
Metabolic disorder.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for metabolic disorder include age 60-74 years.

Vaginitis.description: Vaginitis Also known as Vagina Inflammation Vaginitis is an inflammation of the vagina. It can result in discharge, itching and pain, and is often associated with an irritation or infection of the vulva. It is usually due to infection. The three main kinds of vaginitis are bacterial vaginosis (BV), vaginal candidiasis, and trichomoniasis. A woman may have any combination of vaginal infections at one time. The symptoms that arise vary with the infection, although there are general symptoms that all vaginitis infections have and infected women may also be asymptomatic. Testing for vaginal infections is not a part of routine pelvic exams; therefore, women should neither assume their health care providers will know of the infection, nor that they will provide appropriate treatment without their input. Source: Wikipedia
Vaginitis.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Vaginal discharge, Vaginal pain, Pain during pregnancy, Painful urination, Vaginal redness, Pelvic pain, Suprapubic pain, Vulvar irritation, Vaginal itching, Pain during intercourse, Lower abdominal pain

Sick sinus syndrome.description: Sick sinus syndrome Sick sinus syndrome (SSS), also called sinus node dysfunction (SND), is an umbrella term for a group of abnormal heart rhythms (arrhythmias) presumably caused by a malfunction of the sinus node, the heart's primary pacemaker. Bradycardia-tachycardia syndrome is a variant of sick sinus syndrome in which slow arrhythmias and fast arrhythmias alternate. In recent years, the syndrome has become increasingly prevalent in dogs. The reason is unknown. Source: Wikipedia
Sick sinus syndrome.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Fainting, Irregular heartbeat, Decreased heart rate, Palpitations, Increased heart rate, Bleeding or discharge from nipple, Dizziness, Weakness, Sharp chest pain
Sick sinus syndrome.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for sick sinus syndrome include age 75+ years.

Tinnitus of unknown cause.description: Tinnitus of unknown cause Do you hear a ringing, roaring, clicking or hissing sound in your ears? Do you hear this sound often or all the time? Does the sound bother you? If you answer is yes, you might have tinnitus. Millions of people in the U.S. have tinnitus. People with severe tinnitus may have trouble hearing, working or even sleeping. Causes of tinnitus include hearing loss, exposure to loud noises or medicines you may be taking for a different problem. Tinnitus may also be a symptom of other health problems, such as allergies, high or low blood pressure, tumors and problems in the heart, blood vessels, jaw and neck. Treatment depends on the cause. Treatments may include hearing aids, sound-masking devices, medicines and ways to learn how to cope with the noise. NIH: National Institute on Deafness and Other Communication Disorders Source: MedlinePlus,Patients with tinnitus of unknown cause often receive ophthalmologic and otologic diagnosis and treatment, magnetic resonance imaging, other therapeutic ear procedures, other physical therapy and rehabilitation, diagnostic procedures on ear, diagnostic procedures on nose; mouth and pharynx, other or therapeutic nervous system procedures and upper gastrointestinal endoscopy; biopsy .

tests: Ophthalmologic and otologic diagnosis and treatment

Glaucoma.description: Glaucoma Glaucoma is a term describing a group of ocular disorders with multi-factorial etiology united by a clinically characteristic intraocular pressure-associated optic neuropathy. This can permanently damage vision in the affected eye(s) and lead to blindness if left untreated. It is normally associated with increased fluid pressure in the eye (aqueous humour). The term "ocular hypertension" is used for people with consistently raised intraocular pressure (IOP) without any associated optic nerve damage. Conversely, the term 'normal tension' or 'low tension' glaucoma is used for those with optic nerve damage and associated visual field loss, but normal or low IOP. Source: Wikipedia
Glaucoma.symptoms: Symptoms of eye, Itchiness of eye, Foreign body sensation in eye, Spots or clouds in vision, Blindness, Lacrimation, Eye burns or stings, Itchy eyelid, Feeling cold, Eye redness, Diminished vision, Pain in eye

Eating disorder.description: Eating disorder Eating disorders are conditions defined by abnormal eating habits that may involve either insufficient or excessive food intake to the detriment of an individual's physical and mental health. Bulimia nervosa and anorexia nervosa are the most common specific forms in the United Kingdom. Other types of eating disorders include binge eating disorder and eating disorder not otherwise specified. Bulimia nervosa is a disorder characterized by binge eating and purging. Purging can include self-induce vomiting, over-exercising, and the usage of diuretics, enemas, and laxatives. Anorexia nervosa is characterized by extreme food restriction to the point of self-starvation and excessive weight loss. Though primarily thought of as affecting females (an estimated 5 10 million being affected in the U.K.), eating disorders affect males as well. An estimated 10 15% of people with eating disorders are males (Gorgan, 1999). (an estimated 1 million U.K. males being affected). Although eating disorders are increasing all over the world among both men and women, there is evidence to suggest that it is women in the Western world who are at the highest risk of developing them and the degree of westernization increases the risk. Nearly half of all Americans personally know someone with an eating disorder. The skill to comprehend the central processes of appetite has increased tremendously since leptin was discovered, and the skill to observe the functions of the brain as well. Interactions between motivational, homeostatic and self-regulatory control processes are involved in eating behaviour, which is a key component in eating disorders. Source: Wikipedia
Eating disorder.symptoms: Difficulty eating, Excessive appetite, Abusing alcohol, Acne or pimples, Weight gain, Excessive anger, Vomiting blood, Decreased appetite, Depression, Insomnia, Anxiety and nervousness, Depressive or psychotic symptoms
tests: Other diagnostic radiology and related techniques

Eating disorder.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for eating disorder include age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years and age < 1 years almost never get eating disorder.

Transient ischemic attack.description: Transient ischemic attack Also known as TIA A transient ischemic attack (TIA) is a transient episode of neurologic dysfunction caused by ischemia (loss of blood flow) either focal brain, spinal cord or retinal without acute infarction (tissue death). Source: Wikipedia

Pyelonephritis.description: Pyelonephritis Also known as Bacterial Infection Of The Kidney Pyelonephritis (from Greek pyelum, meaning "renal pelvis", nephros, meaning "kidney", and -itis, meaning "inflammation") is an ascending urinary tract infection that has reached the pyelum or pelvis of the kidney. It is a form of nephritis that is also referred to as pyelitis. Severe cases of pyelonephritis can lead to pyonephrosis (pus accumulation around the kidney), urosepsis (a systemic inflammatory response of the body to infection), kidney failure and even death. Source: Wikipedia

Rotator cuff injury.description: Rotator cuff injury Also known as Rotator Cuff Tear and Rotator Cuff Rupture A rotator cuff tear is a tear of one or more of the tendons of the four rotator cuff muscles. A rotator cuff injury can include any type of irritation or damage to the rotator cuff muscles or tendons. Source: Wikipedia

Chronic pain disorder.description: Chronic pain disorder Also known as Pain Syndrome and Pain Disorder Pain disorder is chronic pain experienced by a patient in one or more areas, and is thought to be caused by psychological stress. The pain is often so severe that it disables the patient from proper functioning. Duration may be as short as a few days or as long as many years. The disorder may begin at any age, and occurs more frequently in girls than boys. This disorder often occurs after an accident or during an illness that has caused pain, which then takes on a 'life' of its own. Source: Wikipedia

Liver cancer.description: Liver cancer Also known as Cancer Of The Liver, Hepatic Cancer, and Malignant Neoplasm Of Liver Liver cancer or hepatic cancer (from the Greek hpar, meaning liver) is a cancer that originates in the liver. Liver cancers are malignant tumors that grow on the surface or inside the liver. Liver tumors are discovered on medical imaging equipment (often by accident) or present themselves symptomatically as an abdominal mass, abdominal pain, jaundice, nausea or liver dysfunction. Liver cancers should not be confused with liver metastases, which are cancers that originate from organs elsewhere in the body and migrate to the liver. Source: Wikipedia

Atelectasis.description: Atelectasis Atelectasis (from Greek: , "incomplete" + , "extension") is defined as the collapse or closure of the lung resulting in reduced or absent gas exchange . It may affect part or all of one lung. It is a condition where the alveoli are deflated, as distinct from pulmonary consolidation. Source: Wikipedia

Injury to the hand.description: Injury to the hand Also known as Hand injury The hand is a very complex organ with multiple joints, different types of ligament, tendons and nerves. With constant use, it is no wonder that hand disease injuries are common in society. Hand injuries can result from excessive use, degenerative disorders or trauma. Source: Wikipedia

Choledocholithiasis.description: Choledocholithiasis A gallstone is a crystalline concretion formed within the gallbladder by accretion of bile components. These calculi are formed in the gallbladder but may distally pass into other parts of the biliary tract such as the cystic duct, common bile duct, pancreatic duct, or the ampulla of Vater. Rarely, in cases of severe inflammation, gallstones may erode through the gallbladder into adherent bowel potentially causing an obstruction termed gallstone ileus. Source: Wikipedia

Cirrhosis.description: Cirrhosis Also known as Liver Cirrhosis, Cirrhosis Of Liver, and Hepatic Cirrhosis Cirrhosis /sjrosjs/ is a consequence of chronic liver disease characterized by replacement of liver tissue by fibrosis, scar tissue and regenerative nodules (lumps that occur as a result of a process in which damaged tissue is regenerated), leading to loss of liver function. Cirrhosis is most commonly caused by alcoholism, hepatitis B and hepatitis C, and fatty liver disease, but has many other possible causes. Some cases are idiopathic (i.e., of unknown cause). Source: Wikipedia
Cirrhosis.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Shortness of breath, Peripheral edema, Regurgitation, Symptoms of the kidneys, Blood in stool, Abdominal distention, Vomiting blood, Upper abdominal pain, Fatigue, Stomach bloating, Melena

Thoracic aortic aneurysm.description: Thoracic aortic aneurysm A thoracic aortic aneurysm is an aortic aneurysm that presents primarily in the thorax. Source: Wikipedia

Subdural hemorrhage.description: Subdural hemorrhage Also known as Subdural Hematoma A subdural hematoma (American spelling) or subdural haematoma (British spelling), also known as a subdural haemorrhage (SDH), is a type of hematoma, usually associated with traumatic brain injury. Blood gathers within the outermost meningeal layer, between the dura mater, which adheres to the skull, and the arachnoid mater, which envelops the brain. Usually resulting from tears in bridging veins which cross the subdural space, subdural hemorrhages may cause an increase in intracranial pressure (ICP), which can cause compression of and damage to delicate brain tissue. Subdural hematomas are often life-threatening when acute. Chronic subdural hematomas, however, have better prognosis if properly managed. Source: Wikipedia
Subdural hemorrhage.symptoms: Headache, Facial pain, Irritable infant, Vomiting, Disturbance of memory, Hostile behavior, Delusions or hallucinations, Seizures, Abnormal movement of eyelid, Problems with movement, Dizziness, Depressive or psychotic symptoms
Subdural hemorrhage.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for subdural hemorrhage include age 75+ years.

Congenital rubella.description: Congenital rubella Congenital rubella syndrome (CRS) can occur in a developing fetus of a pregnant woman who has contracted rubella during her first trimester. If infection occurs 0 28 days before conception, there is a 43% chance the infant will be affected. If the infection occurs 0 12 weeks after conception, there is a 51% chance the infant will be affected. Source: Wikipedia
Congenital rubella.symptoms: Pain or soreness of breast, Pain during pregnancy, Joint stiffness or tightness, Facial pain, Shoulder cramps or spasms, Knee lump or mass, Wrist pain, Excessive anger, Ankle pain, Fatigue, Excessive urination at night, Pain in eye
Congenital rubella.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for congenital rubella include race/ethnicity = other, age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = hispanic, age 75+ years, age 60-74 years, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, race/ethnicity = black, age 15-29 years, age 45-59 years and age < 1 years.

Diabetic retinopathy.description: Diabetic retinopathy Diabetic retinopathy, () is retinopathy (damage to the retina) caused by complications of diabetes, which can eventually lead to blindness. It is an ocular manifestation of diabetes, a systemic disease, which affects up to 80 percent of all patients who have had diabetes for 10 years or more. Despite these intimidating statistics, research indicates that at least 90% of these new cases could be reduced if there was proper and vigilant treatment and monitoring of the eyes. The longer a person has diabetes, the higher his or her chances of developing diabetic retinopathy. Source: Wikipedia
Diabetic retinopathy.symptoms: Symptoms of eye, Bleeding from eye, Itchiness of eye, Double vision, Foreign body sensation in eye, Spots or clouds in vision, Blindness, Lacrimation, Abnormal movement of eyelid, Eye redness, Diminished vision, Pain in eye
tests: Other extraocular muscle and orbit therapeutic procedures
Ophthalmologic and otologic diagnosis and treatment
Other therapeutic procedures on eyelids; conjunctiva; cornea
Destruction of lesion of retina and choroid
Diabetic retinopathy.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for diabetic retinopathy include age 75+ years, age 60-74 years and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get diabetic retinopathy.

Fibromyalgia.description: Fibromyalgia Also known as Fibromyalgia Syndrome, Fibromyositis, and Muscular Rheumatism Fibromyalgia (FM or FMS) is characterised by chronic widespread pain and allodynia (a heightened and painful response to pressure). Its exact cause is unknown but is believed to involve psychological, genetic, neurobiological and environmental factors. Fibromyalgia symptoms are not restricted to pain, leading to the use of the alternative term fibromyalgia syndrome for the condition. Other symptoms include debilitating fatigue, sleep disturbance, and joint stiffness. Some patients also report difficulty with swallowing, bowel and bladder abnormalities, numbness and tingling, and cognitive dysfunction. Fibromyalgia is frequently comorbid with psychiatric conditions such as depression and anxiety and stress-related disorders such as posttraumatic stress disorder. Not all fibromyalgia patients experience all associated symptoms. Fibromyalgia is estimated to affect 2 4% of the population, with a female to male incidence ratio of approximately 9:1. The term "fibromyalgia" derives from new Latin, fibro-, meaning "fibrous tissues", Greek myo-, "muscle", and Greek algos-, "pain"; thus the term literally means "muscle and connective tissue pain". Source: Wikipedia
Fibromyalgia.symptoms: Ache all over, Shoulder pain, Headache, Back pain, Muscle pain, Neck pain, Low back pain, Leg pain, Hip pain, Arm pain, Fatigue, Sharp chest pain
Fibromyalgia.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for fibromyalgia include age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get fibromyalgia.

Ischemia of the bowel.description: Ischemia of the bowel Ischemia of the bowel is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Ischemia of the bowel.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Nausea, Burning abdominal pain, Chills, Retention of urine, Rectal bleeding, Vomiting, Blood in stool, Constipation, Melena, Lower abdominal pain, Diarrhea
Ischemia of the bowel.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for ischemia of the bowel include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get ischemia of the bowel.

Fetal alcohol syndrome.description: Fetal alcohol syndrome Fetal alcohol syndrome (FAS) is a pattern of mental and physical defects that can develop in a fetus in association with high levels of alcohol consumption during pregnancy. Alcohol crosses the placental barrier and can stunt fetal growth or weight, create distinctive facial stigmata, damage neurons and brain structures, which can result in psychological or behavioral problems, and cause other physical damage. The main effect of FAS is permanent central nervous system damage, especially to the brain. Developing brain cells and structures can be malformed or have development interrupted by prenatal alcohol exposure; this can create an array of primary cognitive and functional disabilities (including poor memory, attention deficits, impulsive behavior, and poor cause-effect reasoning) as well as secondary disabilities (for example, predispositions to mental health problems and drug addiction). Alcohol exposure presents a risk of fetal brain damage at any point during a pregnancy, since brain development is ongoing throughout pregnancy. Source: Wikipedia
Fetal alcohol syndrome.symptoms: Emotional symptoms, Lack of growth, Hostile behavior, Temper problems, Smoking problems, Eye strain, Wrist weakness, Excessive anger, Seizures, Eye redness, Depressive or psychotic symptoms, Coryza
tests: Ophthalmologic and otologic diagnosis and treatment
Fetal alcohol syndrome.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for fetal alcohol syndrome include race/ethnicity = other, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years. On the other hand, age 30-44 years, age 75+ years, age 60-74 years, and age 45-59 years almost never get fetal alcohol syndrome.

Peritonitis.description: Peritonitis Peritonitis is an inflammation of the peritoneum, the thin tissue that lines the inner wall of the abdomen and covers most of the abdominal organs. Peritonitis may be localized or generalised, and may result from infection (often due to rupture of a hollow organ as may occur in abdominal trauma or appendicitis) or from a non-infectious process. Source: Wikipedia
Peritonitis.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Shortness of breath, Fever, Groin mass, Nausea, Back pain, Side pain, Vomiting, Upper abdominal pain, Groin pain, Intermenstrual bleeding, Lower abdominal pain
Peritonitis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for peritonitis include age 60-74 years.

Injury to the abdomen.description: Injury to the abdomen Injury to the abdomen is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Injury to the abdomen.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Pain during pregnancy, Blood in urine, Burning abdominal pain, Back pain, Side pain, Neck pain, Problems during pregnancy, Leg pain, Upper abdominal pain, Lower abdominal pain, Sharp chest pain
Injury to the abdomen.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for injury to the abdomen include age 5-14 years age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, age 60-74 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get injury to the abdomen.

Acute pancreatitis.description: Acute pancreatitis Acute pancreatitis or acute pancreatic necrosis is a sudden inflammation of the pancreas. It can have severe complications and high mortality despite treatment. While mild cases are often successfully treated with conservative measures, such as NPO (nil per os, fasting) and aggressive intravenous fluid rehydration, severe cases may require admission to the intensive care unit or even surgery to deal with complications of the disease process. Source: Wikipedia
Acute pancreatitis.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Nausea, Burning abdominal pain, Sharp chest pain, Back pain, Abusing alcohol, Side pain, Vomiting, Lower body pain, Hemoptysis, Upper abdominal pain, Diarrhea
Acute pancreatitis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for acute pancreatitis include age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get acute pancreatitis.

Thrombophlebitis.description: Thrombophlebitis Thrombophlebitis is phlebitis (vein inflammation) related to a thrombus (blood clot). When it occurs repeatedly in different locations, it is known as "Thrombophlebitis migrans" or "migrating thrombophlebitis". Source: Wikipedia
Thrombophlebitis.symptoms: Ache all over, Hand or finger swelling, Lymphedema, Leg cramps or spasms, Skin swelling, Foot or toe pain, Skin on leg or foot looks infected, Abnormal appearing skin, Arm swelling, Leg pain, Arm pain, Leg swelling
tests: Physical therapy exercises; manipulation; and other procedures
Other OR procedures on vessels other than head and neck
Thrombophlebitis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for thrombophlebitis include age 75+ years age 60-74 years.

Asthma.description: Asthma Also known as Bronchial Asthma Asthma (from the Greek , sthma, "panting") is a common chronic inflammatory disease of the airways characterized by variable and recurring symptoms, reversible airflow obstruction, and bronchospasm. Common symptoms include wheezing, coughing, chest tightness, and shortness of breath. Source: Wikipedia
Asthma.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Fever, Congestion in chest, Nasal congestion, Cough, Chest tightness, Allergic reaction, Coughing up sputum, Difficulty breathing, Wheezing, Coryza, Sharp chest pain
tests: Other diagnostic procedures on skin and subcutaneous tissue
Ophthalmologic and otologic diagnosis and treatment
Asthma.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for asthma include age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years and race/ethnicity = black.

Foreign body in the vagina.description: Foreign body in the vagina Also known as Vaginal Foreign Body Foreign body in the vagina is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Foreign body in the vagina.symptoms: Emotional symptoms, Vaginal discharge, Painful urination, Pus in urine, Skin lesion, Low back weakness, Pelvic pain, Back weakness, Pus in sputum, Abnormal size or shape of ear, Muscle swelling, Lower abdominal pain
Foreign body in the vagina.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for foreign body in the vagina include race/ethnicity = other, sex == female, race/ethnicity = black and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, sex == male, age 60-74 years, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get foreign body in the vagina.

Restless leg syndrome.description: Restless leg syndrome Also known as Ekbom Syndrome Restless Legs Syndrome (RLS), also known as Willis-Ekbom disease (WED), is a neurological disorder characterized by an irresistible urge to move one's body to stop uncomfortable or odd sensations. It most commonly affects the legs, but can affect the arms, torso, head, and even phantom limbs. Moving the affected body part modulates the sensations, providing temporary relief. Source: Wikipedia
Restless leg syndrome.symptoms: Sleepiness, Abnormal involuntary movements, Abnormal breathing sounds, Headache, Back pain, Loss of sensation, Apnea, Leg pain, Fatigue, Depression, Insomnia, Difficulty breathing
tests: Other therapeutic procedures on eyelids; conjunctiva; cornea
Restless leg syndrome.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for restless leg syndrome include age 60-74 years age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years almost never get restless leg syndrome.

Emphysema.description: Emphysema Also known as Lung Emphysema and Pulmonary Emphysema Emphysema is a long-term lung disease. In people with emphysema, the tissues necessary to support the shape and function of the lungs are destroyed. It is included in a group of diseases called chronic obstructive pulmonary disease or COPD. Emphysema is called an obstructive lung disease because the destruction of lung tissue around smaller sacs, called alveoli, makes these air sacs unable to hold their functional shape upon exhalation. Emphysema is most often caused by tobacco smoking and long-term exposure to air pollution. Source: Wikipedia
Emphysema.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Ache all over, Emotional symptoms, Cross-eyed, Nausea, Back pain, Cough, Excessive growth, Chest tightness, Itchy eyelid, Elbow cramps or spasms, Sharp chest pain
Emphysema.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for emphysema include race/ethnicity = other, sex == male, age 5-14 years, age 15-29 years and age < 1 years. On the other hand, age 60-74 years, race/ethnicity = black, and age 45-59 years almost never get emphysema.

Cysticercosis.description: Cysticercosis Cysticercosis refers to tissue infection after exposure to eggs of Taenia solium, the pork tapeworm. The disease is spread via the fecal-oral route through contaminated food and water, and is primarily a food borne disease. After ingestion the eggs pass through the lumen of the intestine into the tissues and migrate preferentially to the brain and muscles. There they form cysts that can persist for years. In some cases the cysts will eventually cause an inflammatory reaction presenting as painful nodules in the muscles and seizures when the cysts are located in the brain. Symptomatic disease from Taenia solium cysts in the brain is referred to as neurocysticercosis and is the most common tapeworm infection of the brain worldwide. Cysticercosis should be differentiated from taeniasis: carriage of the adult tapeworm in the intestine (which is through ingestion of cysts in an intermediate host, not the ingestion of the eggs as in cysticercosis). These represent two different stages of the parasite s life cycle. Though both forms of infection can potentially occur in the same individual at the same time, they are distinct disease entities and have different treatments and potential outcomes. Source: Wikipedia
Cysticercosis.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Abnormal involuntary movements, Feeling hot and cold, Headache, Low back weakness, Vomiting, Excessive growth, Wrist weakness, Seizures, Elbow cramps or spasms, Underweight, Elbow weakness
Cysticercosis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for cysticercosis include age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = hispanic and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, age 5-14 years, race/ethnicity = black, and race/ethnicity = white almost never get cysticercosis.

Induced abortion.description: Induced abortion Abortion is the termination of pregnancy by the removal or expulsion from the uterus of a fetus or embryo prior to viability. An abortion can occur spontaneously, in which case it is usually called a miscarriage, or it can be purposely induced. The term abortion most commonly refers to the induced abortion of a human pregnancy. Source: Wikipedia
Induced abortion.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Vaginal discharge, Pain during pregnancy, Cramps and spasms, Spotting or bleeding during pregnancy, Pelvic pain, Absence of menstruation, Problems during pregnancy, Groin pain, Intermenstrual bleeding, Blood clots during menstrual periods, Lower abdominal pain
Induced abortion.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for induced abortion include race/ethnicity = other, age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = hispanic, sex == female and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, sex == male, age 60-74 years, age 1-4 years, age 45-59 years, and age < 1 years almost never get induced abortion.

Infectious gastroenteritis.description: Infectious gastroenteritis Also known as Stomach Flu and Gastric Flu Gastroenteritis is a medical condition characterized by inflammation ("-itis") of the gastrointestinal tract that involves both the stomach ("gastro"-) and the small intestine ("entero"-), resulting in some combination of diarrhea, vomiting, and abdominal pain and cramping. Gastroenteritis has also been referred to as gastro, stomach bug, and stomach virus. Although unrelated to influenza, it has also been called stomach flu and gastric flu. Source: Wikipedia
Infectious gastroenteritis.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Fever, Nausea, Burning abdominal pain, Headache, Chills, Vomiting, Blood in stool, Fluid retention, Decreased appetite, Flu-like syndrome, Diarrhea
Infectious gastroenteritis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for infectious gastroenteritis include age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years.

Acute sinusitis.description: Acute sinusitis Sinusitis or rhinosinusitis is inflammation of the paranasal sinuses. It can be due to infection, allergy, or autoimmune issues. Most cases are due to a viral infection and resolve over the course of 10 days. It is a common condition, with over 24 million cases annually in the U.S. Source: Wikipedia
Acute sinusitis.symptoms: Painful sinuses, Fever, Headache, Frontal headache, Facial pain, Nasal congestion, Cough, Sinus congestion, Sore throat, Coughing up sputum, Coryza, Ear pain
tests: Physical therapy exercises; manipulation; and other procedures
Acute sinusitis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for acute sinusitis include .

Von Hippel-Lindau disease.description: Von Hippel-Lindau disease Von Hippel Lindau (VHL) disease is a rare, autosomal dominant genetic condition that predisposes individuals to benign and malignant tumours. The most common tumours found in VHL are central nervous system and retinal hemangioblastomas, clear cell renal carcinomas, pheochromocytomas, pancreatic neuroendocrine tumours, pancreatic cysts, endolymphatic sac tumors and epididymal papillary cystadenomas. VHL results from a mutation in the von Hippel Lindau tumor suppressor gene on chromosome 3p25.3. Source: Wikipedia
Von Hippel-Lindau disease.symptoms: Blood in urine, Headache, Nausea, Paresthesia, Excessive growth, Abnormal appearing skin, Kidney mass, Seizures, Upper abdominal pain, Fatigue, Knee pain, Diminished vision
Von Hippel-Lindau disease.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for von hippel-lindau disease include race/ethnicity = other, race/ethnicity = hispanic and age 5-14 years. On the other hand, age 60-74 years almost never get von hippel-lindau disease.
