Blepharospasm.description: Blepharospasm Also known as Eyelid Twitching and Eyelid Spasms A blepharospasm (from Greek: blepharo, eyelid, and spasm, an uncontrolled muscle contraction), is any abnormal contraction or twitch of the eyelid. Source: Wikipedia
Blepharospasm.symptoms: Eyelid lesion or rash, Muscle cramps, contractures, or spasms, Headache, Arm weakness, Cramps and spasms, Low back weakness, Blindness, Eye moves abnormally, Abnormal movement of eyelid, Leg weakness, Pain during intercourse, Diminished vision
tests: Injections and aspirations of muscles; tendons; bursa; joints and soft tissue
Blepharospasm.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for blepharospasm include race/ethnicity = other, age 75+ years, age 60-74 years and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years and age 1-4 years almost never get blepharospasm.

Sarcoidosis.description: Sarcoidosis Also known as Sarcoid, Schaumann Disease, and Boeck's Sarcoid Sarcoidosis (from sarc meaning "flesh", -oid, "like", and -osis, "diseased or abnormal condition"), also called sarcoid, Besnier-Boeck disease or Besnier-Boeck-Schaumann disease, is a syndrome involving abnormal collections of chronic inflammatory cells (granulomas) that can form as nodules in multiple organs. The granulomas that appear are usually not of the caseating variety and are most often located in the lungs or the lymph nodes, but virtually any organ can be affected. Onset is usually gradual. Sarcoidosis may be asymptomatic or chronic. It commonly improves or clears up spontaneously. More than two-thirds of people with lung sarcoidosis have no symptoms after 9 years. About 50% have relapses. About 10% develop serious disability. Lung scarring or infection may lead to respiratory failure and death. In chronic cases, symptoms may fluctuate over many years. The causes of sarcoidosis are not completely understood. Source: Wikipedia
Sarcoidosis.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Headache, Facial pain, Paresthesia, Cough, Muscle pain, Pain in eye, Chest tightness, Fatigue, Peripheral edema, Wheezing, Sharp chest pain
Sarcoidosis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for sarcoidosis include race/ethnicity = other, age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = black and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get sarcoidosis.

Metastatic cancer.description: Metastatic cancer Also known as Secondary Neoplasm Metastasis, or metastatic disease, is the spread of a cancer from one organ or part to another non-adjacent organ or part. The new occurrences of disease thus generated are referred to as metastases (sometimes abbreviated mets) It was previously thought that only malignant tumor cells and infections have the capacity to metastasize; however, this is being reconsidered due to new research. In origin metastasis is a Greek word meaning "displacement", from , meta, "next", and , stasis, "placement". The plural is metastases. Source: Wikipedia
Metastatic cancer.symptoms: Neck mass, Leg cramps or spasms, Unusual color or odor to urine, Vaginal dryness, Focal weakness, Decreased appetite, Fatigue, Stomach bloating
Metastatic cancer.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for metastatic cancer include age 75+ years, age 60-74 years and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get metastatic cancer.

Trigger finger (finger disorder).description: Trigger finger (finger disorder) Also known as Snap Finger A painful disability in the hand affecting the finger or thumb. It is caused by mechanical impingement of the digital flexor tendons as they pass through a narrowed retinacular pulley at the level of the metacarpal head. Thickening of the sheath and fibrocartilaginous metaplasia can occur, and nodules can form. (From Green's Operative Hand Surgery, 5th ed, p2137-58). Source: MeSH
Trigger finger (finger disorder).symptoms: Hand or finger pain, Back stiffness or tightness, Hand or finger swelling, Paresthesia, Hand or finger cramps or spasms, Bleeding from ear, Muscle stiffness or tightness, Wrist pain, Hand or finger stiffness or tightness, Skin on arm or hand looks infected, Bones are painful, Shoulder stiffness or tightness
tests: Injections and aspirations of muscles; tendons; bursa; joints and soft tissue
Other non-OR therapeutic procedures on musculoskeletal system
Trigger finger (finger disorder).riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for trigger finger (finger disorder) include age 60-74 years age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 15-29 years almost never get trigger finger (finger disorder).

Stye.description: Stye Also known as Hordeolum and Hordeolum Externum An external stye or sty /staj/, also hordeolum /hTrdiYlYm/, is an infection of the sebaceous glands of Zeis at the base of the eyelashes, or an infection of the apocrine sweat glands of Moll. External styes form on the outside of the lids and can be seen as small red bumps. Internal styes are infections of the meibomian sebaceous glands lining the inside of the eyelids. They also cause a red bump underneath the lid with only generalized redness and swelling visible on the outside. Styes are similar to chalazia, but tend to be of smaller size and are more painful and usually produce no lasting damage. They contain water and pus and the bacteria will spread if the stye is forcefully ruptured. Styes are characterized by an acute onset and usually short in duration (7 10 days without treatment) compared to chalazia that are chronic and usually do not resolve without intervention. Styes are usually caused by staphylococcus aureus bacterium. Source: Wikipedia
Stye.symptoms: Symptoms of eye, Eyelid lesion or rash, Eyelid swelling, Itchiness of eye, Swollen eye, Skin swelling, Lacrimation, Abnormal appearing skin, Eye burns or stings, Mass on eyelid, Eye redness, Pain in eye
tests: Physical therapy exercises; manipulation; and other procedures
Other OR therapeutic nervous system procedures
Stye.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for stye include age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years and age 15-29 years.

Hemochromatosis.description: Hemochromatosis Also known as Bronze Diabetes and Iron Storage Disease In medicine, iron overload indicates accumulation of iron in the body from any cause. The most important causes are hereditary haemochromatosis (HHC), a genetic disorder, and transfusional iron overload, which can result from repeated blood transfusion. Source: Wikipedia
Hemochromatosis.symptoms: Ache all over, Pain in testicles, Joint pain, Drainage in throat, Difficulty speaking, Too little hair, Disturbance of memory, Recent weight loss, Abnormal appearing skin, Pelvic pain, Bones are painful
tests: Prostate specific antigen measurement (Prostate specific antigen test)
Hemochromatosis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for hemochromatosis include age 60-74 years age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get hemochromatosis.

Osteochondroma.description: Osteochondroma Also known as Exostosis, Cartilaginous Exostosis, and Ecchondroma Osteochondroma is a type of benign tumor that consists of cartilage and bone. It is a benign cartilage-capped outgrowth, connected to bone by a stalk. Source: Wikipedia
Osteochondroma.symptoms: Shoulder pain, Skin growth, Skin lesion, Foot or toe pain, Pelvic pain, Abnormal appearing skin, Itching of skin, Ankle pain, Hand or finger lump or mass, Knee pain, Lip swelling, Lower abdominal pain
Osteochondroma.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for osteochondroma include race/ethnicity = other age 60-74 years.

Cushing syndrome.description: Cushing syndrome Cushing's syndrome describes the signs and symptoms associated with prolonged exposure to inappropriately high levels of the hormone cortisol. This can be caused by taking glucocorticoid drugs, or diseases that result in excess cortisol, adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH), or CRH levels. Source: Wikipedia
Cushing syndrome.symptoms: Emotional symptoms, Shoulder pain, Bladder mass, Itching of scrotum, Infrequent menstruation, Low back weakness, Decreased heart rate, Elbow weakness, Weight gain, Elbow cramps or spasms, Muscle swelling, Nailbiting
tests: Psychological and psychiatric evaluation and therapy
Cushing syndrome.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for cushing syndrome include race/ethnicity = other age 30-44 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years almost never get cushing syndrome.

Typhoid fever.description: Typhoid fever Also known as Typhoid and Enteric Fever Typhoid fever, also known simply as typhoid, is a common worldwide bacterial disease transmitted by the ingestion of food or water contaminated with the feces of an infected person, which contain the bacterium Salmonella enterica enterica, serovar Typhi. Source: Wikipedia
Typhoid fever.symptoms: Pain or soreness of breast, Fever, Pain during pregnancy, Joint stiffness or tightness, Facial pain, Shoulder cramps or spasms, Knee lump or mass, Wrist pain, Excessive anger, Ankle pain, Fatigue, Pain in eye
Typhoid fever.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for typhoid fever include race/ethnicity = other, sex == male and age 5-14 years.

Vitreous degeneration.description: Vitreous degeneration Also known as Vitreous Syneresis Vitreous degeneration is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Vitreous degeneration.symptoms: Symptoms of eye, Bleeding from eye, Itchiness of eye, Double vision, Foreign body sensation in eye, Spots or clouds in vision, Blindness, Lacrimation, Eye burns or stings, Eye redness, Diminished vision, Pain in eye
tests: Other extraocular muscle and orbit therapeutic procedures
Ophthalmologic and otologic diagnosis and treatment
Other therapeutic procedures on eyelids; conjunctiva; cornea
Vitreous degeneration.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for vitreous degeneration include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get vitreous degeneration.

Atrophic skin condition.description: Atrophic skin condition Atrophic skin condition is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Atrophic skin condition.symptoms: Skin moles, Skin growth, Skin lesion, Skin swelling, Acne or pimples, Too little hair, Abnormal appearing skin, Itching of skin, Warts, Lip swelling, Wrinkles on skin, Skin irritation
tests: Injections and aspirations of muscles; tendons; bursa; joints and soft tissue
Other diagnostic procedures on skin and subcutaneous tissue
Atrophic skin condition.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for atrophic skin condition include age 60-74 years age 45-59 years.

Aspergillosis.description: Aspergillosis Aspergillosis is the name given to a wide variety of diseases caused by infection by fungi of the genus Aspergillus. The most common forms are allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis, pulmonary aspergilloma, and invasive aspergillosis. Most humans inhale Aspergillus spores every day. Aspergillosis develops mainly in individuals who are immunocompromised, either from disease or from immunosuppressive drugs, and is a leading cause of death in acute leukemia and hematopoietic stem cell transplantation. The most common cause is Aspergillus fumigatus. Source: Wikipedia
Aspergillosis.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Vulvar sore, Shortness of breath, Shoulder swelling, Knee lump or mass, Excessive growth, Wrist weakness, Vomiting blood, Diminished hearing, Loss of sex drive, Neck cramps or spasms, Nailbiting
Aspergillosis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for aspergillosis include race/ethnicity = hispanic, age 75+ years, age 60-74 years and age 5-14 years.

Uterine atony.description: Uterine atony Also known as Inertia Uteri Uterine atony is a loss of tone in the uterine musculature. Normally, contraction of the uterine muscle compresses the vessels and reduces flow. This increases the likelihood of coagulation and prevents bleeds. Thus, lack of uterine muscle contraction can cause an acute hemorrhage. Clinically, 75-80% of postpartum hemorrhages are due to uterine atony. Source: Wikipedia
Uterine atony.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Uterine contractions, Pain during pregnancy, Blood in urine, Back cramps or spasms, Spotting or bleeding during pregnancy, Infertility, Problems during pregnancy, Intermenstrual bleeding, Lower abdominal pain
Uterine atony.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for uterine atony include age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = hispanic, sex == female and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, sex == male, age 60-74 years, age 1-4 years, age 45-59 years, and age < 1 years almost never get uterine atony.

Trichinosis.description: Trichinosis Also known as Trichiniasis and Trichinelliasis Trichinosis, also called trichinellosis, or trichiniasis, is a parasitic disease caused by eating raw or undercooked pork or wild game infected with the larvae of a species of roundworm Trichinella spiralis, commonly called the trichina worm. There are eight Trichinella species; five are encapsulated and three are not. Only three Trichinella species are known to cause trichinosis: T. spiralis, T. nativa, and T. britovi. Source: Wikipedia
Trichinosis.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Vulvar sore, Bedwetting, Pelvic pressure, Shoulder swelling, Painful urination, Nasal congestion, Knee lump or mass, Excessive growth, Skin rash, Loss of sex drive, Neck cramps or spasms
Trichinosis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for trichinosis include race/ethnicity = hispanic, race/ethnicity = black and age 15-29 years.

Whooping cough.description: Whooping cough Also known as Pertussis Pertussis commonly called whooping cough (/hupjK kRf/ or /hwupjK kRf/) is a highly contagious bacterial disease caused by Bordetella pertussis. In some countries, this disease is called the 100 days' cough or cough of 100 days. Source: Wikipedia
Whooping cough.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Sharp abdominal pain, Fever, Headache, Irritable infant, Nasal congestion, Difficulty in swallowing, Cough, Vomiting, Sinus congestion, Sore throat, Coryza
tests: Referral to home health care service
Whooping cough.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for whooping cough include age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years. On the other hand, race/ethnicity = other, age 75+ years, and age 60-74 years almost never get whooping cough.

Pick disease.description: Pick disease Also known as Frontotemporal Dementia Pick's disease is a rare neurodegenerative disease that causes progressive destruction of nerve cells in the brain. Symptoms include loss of speech (aphasia) and dementia. While some of the symptoms can initially be alleviated, the disease progresses and patients often die within two to ten years. A defining characteristic of the disease is build-up of tau proteins in neurons, accumulating into silver-staining, spherical aggregations known as "Pick bodies". Source: Wikipedia
Pick disease.symptoms: Pain or soreness of breast, Pain during pregnancy, Joint stiffness or tightness, Facial pain, Shoulder cramps or spasms, Knee lump or mass, Wrist pain, Excessive anger, Ankle pain, Fatigue, Excessive urination at night, Pain in eye
Pick disease.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for pick disease include race/ethnicity = other, age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = hispanic, age 75+ years, age 60-74 years, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, race/ethnicity = black, age 15-29 years, age 45-59 years and age < 1 years.

Open wound of the lip.description: Open wound of the lip Open wound of the lip is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Open wound of the lip.symptoms: Dry lips, Bleeding in mouth, Facial pain, Mouth ulcer, Bleeding gums, Tongue pain, Mouth pain, Slurring words, Lip swelling
tests: Other non-OR therapeutic procedures on nose; mouth and pharynx
Open wound of the lip.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for open wound of the lip include sex == male, age 5-14 years and age 1-4 years.

Subacute thyroiditis.description: Subacute thyroiditis Also known as De Quervain Thyroiditis Subacute thyroiditis is an intriguing form of thyroiditis that can be a cause of both thyrotoxicosis and hypothyroidism. It is uncommon and can affect individuals of both sexes and all ages. The most common form, subacute granulomatous, or de Quervain's, thyroiditis manifests as a sudden and painful enlargement of the thyroid gland accompanied with fever, malaise and muscle aches. Some have suggested that its cause might be viral in origin. Source: Wikipedia
Subacute thyroiditis.symptoms: Uterine contractions, Pain during pregnancy, Sweating, Leg cramps or spasms, Spotting or bleeding during pregnancy, Palpitations, Problems during pregnancy, Blood in stool, Fluid retention, Heartburn, Pain of the anus
Subacute thyroiditis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for subacute thyroiditis include race/ethnicity = other, age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = hispanic, sex == female and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, sex == male, age 60-74 years, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, age 45-59 years, and age < 1 years almost never get subacute thyroiditis.

Oral mucosal lesion.description: Oral mucosal lesion Also known as Mouth Lesion and Oral Lesion Oral mucosal lesion is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Oral mucosal lesion.symptoms: Fever, Gum pain, Bleeding in mouth, Facial pain, Mouth ulcer, Cough, Mouth pain, Toothache, Sore throat, Lip swelling, Ear pain, Tongue lesions
tests: Other OR therapeutic procedures on nose; mouth and pharynx
Diagnostic procedures on nose; mouth and pharynx
Oral mucosal lesion.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for oral mucosal lesion include age 1-4 years.

Open wound due to trauma.description: Open wound due to trauma Open wound due to trauma is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Open wound due to trauma.symptoms: Shoulder stiffness or tightness, Wrist swelling, Skin on arm or hand looks infected
Open wound due to trauma.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for open wound due to trauma include .

Intracerebral hemorrhage.description: Intracerebral hemorrhage Also known as Cerebral Hemorrhage, Brain Bleeding, and Brain Haemorrhage A cerebral hemorrhage or haemorrhage (or intracerebral hemorrhage, ICH) is a subtype of intracranial hemorrhage that occurs within the brain tissue itself. Intracerebral hemorrhage can be caused by brain trauma, or it can occur spontaneously in hemorrhagic stroke. Non-traumatic intracerebral hemorrhage is a spontaneous bleeding into the brain tissue. Source: Wikipedia
Intracerebral hemorrhage.symptoms: Nausea, Headache, Depressive or psychotic symptoms, Blindness, Vomiting, Slurring words, Focal weakness, Seizures, Problems with movement, Dizziness, Weakness, Diminished vision
Intracerebral hemorrhage.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for intracerebral hemorrhage include age 75+ years, age 60-74 years and age < 1 years.

Alzheimer disease.description: Alzheimer disease Alzheimer's disease (AD), also known in medical literature as Alzheimer disease, is the most common form of dementia. There is no cure for the disease, which worsens as it progresses, and eventually leads to death. It was first described by German psychiatrist and neuropathologist Alois Alzheimer in 1906 and was named after him. Most often, AD is diagnosed in people over 65 years of age, although the less-prevalent early-onset Alzheimer's can occur much earlier. In 2006, there were 26.6 million sufferers worldwide. Alzheimer's is predicted to affect 1 in 85 people globally by 2050. Source: Wikipedia
Alzheimer disease.symptoms: Difficulty speaking, Restlessness, Muscle cramps, contractures, or spasms, Depression, Hostile behavior, Disturbance of memory, Irregular appearing scalp, Fears and phobias, Delusions or hallucinations, Problems with movement, Depressive or psychotic symptoms, Eye burns or stings
tests: Insertion of catheter into urinary bladder
Alzheimer disease.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for alzheimer disease include age 75+ years. On the other hand, age 30-44 years, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, age 15-29 years, and age < 1 years almost never get alzheimer disease.

Vaginismus.description: Vaginismus Vaginismus, sometimes anglicized vaginism, is the condition that affects a woman's ability to engage in any form of vaginal penetration, including sexual intercourse, insertion of tampons and/or menstrual cups, and the penetration involved in gynecological examinations. This is the result of a reflex of the pubococcygeus muscle, which is sometimes referred to as the "PC muscle". The reflex causes the muscles in the vagina to tense suddenly, which makes any kind of vaginal penetration including sexual intercourse painful or impossible. Source: Wikipedia
Vaginismus.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Vaginal pain, Frequent urination, Vaginal discharge, Painful menstruation, Vaginal dryness, Heavy menstrual flow, Pelvic pain, Suprapubic pain, Hot flashes, Pain during intercourse, Lower abdominal pain
Vaginismus.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for vaginismus include age 30-44 years, sex == female and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, sex == male, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get vaginismus.

Systemic lupus erythematosis (SLE).description: Systemic lupus erythematosis (SLE) Also known as Lupus, SLE, and Disseminated Lupus Erythematosus Systemic lupus erythematosus i/sjst[mjk lupYs [rjimYtosYs/, often abbreviated to SLE or lupus, is a systemic autoimmune disease (or autoimmune connective tissue disease) that can affect any part of the body. As occurs in other autoimmune diseases, the immune system attacks the body's cells and tissue, resulting in inflammation and tissue damage. It is a Type III hypersensitivity reaction in which antibody-immune complexes precipitate and cause a further immune response. Source: Wikipedia
Systemic lupus erythematosis (SLE).symptoms: Ache all over, Joint pain, Joint swelling, Too little hair, Absence of menstruation, Muscle pain, Focal weakness, Hand or finger stiffness or tightness, Bones are painful, Leg swelling, Knee pain, Sharp chest pain
Systemic lupus erythematosis (SLE).riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for systemic lupus erythematosis (sle) include race/ethnicity = other, age 30-44 years and race/ethnicity = black. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get systemic lupus erythematosis (sle).

Premature ovarian failure.description: Premature ovarian failure Premature Ovarian Failure (POF), also known as premature ovarian insufficiency, primary ovarian insufficiency (this is the most accurate term as some women may still conceive), premature menopause, hypergonadotropic hypogonadism, is the loss of function of the ovaries before age 40. A commonly cited triad for the diagnosis is amenorrhea, hypergonadotropinism, and hypoestrogenism. If it has a genetic cause, it may be called gonadal dysgenesis Source: Wikipedia,Patients with premature ovarian failure often receive radiographic imaging procedure, hematologic tests, ultrasonography, pelvis exam, examination of breast, standard pregnancy test, rectal examination and microscopic examination (bacterial smear; culture; toxicology) .
Premature ovarian failure.symptoms: Dry or flaky scalp, Heavy menstrual flow, Pelvic pain, Absence of menstruation, Lack of growth, Too little hair, Infertility, Pain during intercourse, Weight gain, Intermenstrual bleeding, Unpredictable menstruation, Hot flashes
Premature ovarian failure.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for premature ovarian failure include race/ethnicity = other, age 30-44 years, sex == female and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, sex == male, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get premature ovarian failure.

Thoracic outlet syndrome.description: Thoracic outlet syndrome Thoracic outlet syndrome (TOS) is a syndrome involving compression at the superior thoracic outlet wherein excess pressure placed on a neurovascular bundle passing between the anterior scalene and middle scalene muscles. It can affect one or more of the nerves that innervate the upper limb and/or blood vessels as they pass between the chest and upper extremity; specifically in the brachial plexus, the subclavian artery, and - rarely - the subclavian vein, which does not normally pass through the scalene hiatus. Source: Wikipedia
Thoracic outlet syndrome.symptoms: Hand or finger pain, Shoulder pain, Hand or finger weakness, Paresthesia, Back pain, Loss of sensation, Neck pain, Arm pain, Decreased appetite, Shoulder weakness, Weakness, Sharp chest pain
Thoracic outlet syndrome.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for thoracic outlet syndrome include sex == male age 45-59 years.

Ganglion cyst.description: Ganglion cyst Also known as Synovial Cyst and Myxoid Cyst A ganglion cyst, also known as a Bible cyst or Bible bump, is a benign soft tissue tumor that may occur in any joint, but most often occurs on or around joints and tendons in the hands or feet. Source: Wikipedia
Ganglion cyst.symptoms: Hand or finger pain, Knee swelling, Wrist lump or mass, Skin growth, Wrist swelling, Foot or toe pain, Knee lump or mass, Wrist pain, Leg pain, Hand or finger lump or mass, Leg swelling, Knee pain
Ganglion cyst.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for ganglion cyst include . On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get ganglion cyst.

Dislocation of the knee.description: Dislocation of the knee Also known as Knee Dislocation and Dislocated Knee Slippage of the FEMUR off the TIBIA. Source: MeSH
Dislocation of the knee.symptoms: Joint pain, Knee swelling, Shoulder pain, Knee stiffness or tightness, Knee pain
tests: Other non-OR therapeutic procedures on musculoskeletal system
Dislocation of the knee.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for dislocation of the knee include age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get dislocation of the knee.

Crohn disease.description: Crohn disease Also known as Granulomatous Enteritis Crohn's disease, also known as Crohn syndrome and regional enteritis, is a type of inflammatory bowel disease that may affect any part of the gastrointestinal tract from mouth to anus, causing a wide variety of symptoms. It primarily causes abdominal pain, diarrhea (which may be bloody if inflammation is at its worst), vomiting (can be continuous), or weight loss, but may also cause complications outside the gastrointestinal tract such as skin rashes, arthritis, inflammation of the eye, tiredness, and lack of concentration. Crohn's disease is caused by interactions between environmental, immunological and bacterial factors in genetically susceptible individuals. This results in a chronic inflammatory disorder, in which the body's immune system attacks the gastrointestinal tract possibly directed at microbial antigens. Crohn's disease has wrongly been described as an autoimmune disease in the past; recent investigators have described it as an immune deficiency state. Source: Wikipedia
Crohn disease.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Joint pain, Burning abdominal pain, Nausea, Regurgitation, Rectal bleeding, Vomiting, Blood in stool, Heartburn, Stomach bloating, Pain of the anus, Diarrhea
Crohn disease.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for crohn disease include age 30-44 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get crohn disease.

Postoperative infection.description: Postoperative infection Postoperative infection is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Postoperative infection.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Fever, Jaw swelling, Recent pregnancy, Skin swelling, Irregular belly button, Skin on leg or foot looks infected, Abnormal appearing skin, Fluid retention, Skin on arm or hand looks infected, Leg swelling, Fluid in ear
Postoperative infection.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for postoperative infection include age 45-59 years.

Folate deficiency.description: Folate deficiency Also known as Folic Acid Deficiency Folate deficiency is a lack of folic acid in the diet and the signs are often subtle. Folate deficiency anemia is the medical name given for the condition. Source: Wikipedia
Folate deficiency.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Sharp abdominal pain, Joint pain, Problems during pregnancy, Delusions or hallucinations, Vomiting blood, Increased heart rate, Fatigue, Difficulty breathing, Weakness, Melena, Sharp chest pain
Folate deficiency.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for folate deficiency include age 75+ years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years almost never get folate deficiency.

Fluid overload.description: Fluid overload Also known as Hypervolemia and Excess Fluid Volume Hypervolemia, or fluid overload, is the medical condition where there is too much fluid in the blood. The opposite condition is hypovolemia, which is too little fluid volume in the blood. Fluid volume excess in the intravascular compartment occurs due to an increase in total body sodium content and a consequent increase in extracellular body water. The mechanism usually stems from compromised regulatory mechanisms for sodium handling as seen in congestive heart failure (CHF), kidney failure, and liver failure. It may also be caused by excessive intake of sodium from foods, intravenous (IV) solutions and blood transfusions, medications, or diagnostic contrast dyes. Source: Wikipedia
Fluid overload.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Sharp abdominal pain, Hand or finger swelling, Nausea, Cough, Vomiting, Fluid retention, Peripheral edema, Difficulty breathing, Leg swelling, Weakness, Sharp chest pain
Fluid overload.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for fluid overload include race/ethnicity = hispanic, age 60-74 years and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years and age < 1 years almost never get fluid overload.

Atrial flutter.description: Atrial flutter Also known as Flutter Auricular Atrial flutter (AFL) is an abnormal heart rhythm that occurs in the atria of the heart. When it first occurs, it is usually associated with a fast heart rate or tachycardia (beats over 100 per minute), and falls into the category of supra-ventricular tachycardias. While this rhythm occurs most often in individuals with cardiovascular disease (e.g. hypertension, coronary artery disease, and cardiomyopathy) and diabetes, it may occur spontaneously in people with otherwise normal hearts. It is typically not a stable rhythm, and frequently degenerates into atrial fibrillation (AF). However, it does rarely persist for months to years. Source: Wikipedia
Atrial flutter.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Frequent urination, Irregular heartbeat, Feeling hot, Palpitations, Chest tightness, Increased heart rate, Swollen lymph nodes, Fatigue, Difficulty breathing, Dizziness, Sharp chest pain
Atrial flutter.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for atrial flutter include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get atrial flutter.

Skin disorder.description: Skin disorder Also known as Skin Disease, Dermatosis, Integumentary Disease, Dermatological Disease, and Dermatological Disorders A cutaneous condition is any medical condition that affects the integumentary system the organ system that encloses the body and includes skin, hair, nails, and related muscle and glands. The major function of this system is as a barrier against the external environment. Source: Wikipedia
Skin disorder.symptoms: Skin moles, Skin growth, Skin lesion, Skin swelling, Acne or pimples, Skin rash, Abnormal appearing skin, Irregular appearing scalp, Itching of skin, Warts, Skin irritation, Skin dryness, peeling, scaliness, or roughness
tests: Other diagnostic procedures on skin and subcutaneous tissue
Skin disorder.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for skin disorder include age 75+ years age 60-74 years.

Floaters.description: Floaters Also known as Eye Floater, Vitreous Floaters, Myodesopsia, and Muscae Volitantes Floaters are deposits of various size, shape, consistency, refractive index, and motility within the eye s vitreous humour, which is normally transparent. At a young age, the vitreous is transparent, but as one ages, imperfections gradually develop. The common type of floater, which is present in most people s eyes, is due to degenerative changes of the vitreous humour. The perception of floaters is known as myodesopsia, or less commonly as myodaeopsia, myiodeopsia, myiodesopsia. They are also called Muscae volitantes (Latin: "flying flies"), or mouches volantes (from the French). Floaters are visible because of the shadows they cast on the retina or refraction of the light that passes through them, and can appear alone or together with several others in one s visual field. They may appear as spots, threads, or fragments of cobwebs, which float slowly before the observer s eyes. Since these objects exist within the eye itself, they are not optical illusions but are entoptic phenomena. Source: Wikipedia
Floaters.symptoms: Symptoms of eye, Itchiness of eye, Foreign body sensation in eye, Spots or clouds in vision, Lacrimation, Eye burns or stings, Diminished vision, Pain in eye
tests: Ophthalmologic and otologic diagnosis and treatment
Other therapeutic procedures on eyelids; conjunctiva; cornea
Floaters.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for floaters include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get floaters.

Tooth disorder.description: Tooth disorder Also known as Tooth Disease, Dental Disease, and Disease Of Teeth Your teeth are made of a hard, bonelike material. Inside the tooth are nerves and blood vessels. You need your teeth for many activities you may take for granted. These include eating, speaking and even smiling. But tooth disorders are nothing to smile about. They include problems such as cavities (also known as tooth decay), infections, and injuries. The most familiar symptom of a tooth problem is a toothache. Others include worn-down or loose teeth. It's important that you see a dentist if you have any problems with your teeth. Fortunately, you can prevent many tooth disorders by taking care of your teeth and keeping them clean. Source: MedlinePlus
Tooth disorder.symptoms: Jaw swelling, Headache, Facial pain, Mouth ulcer, Bleeding gums, Mouth pain, Pain in gums, Swollen lymph nodes, Peripheral edema, Toothache, Gum pain, Ear pain
tests: Other diagnostic radiology and related techniques
Tooth disorder.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for tooth disorder include age 30-44 years age 15-29 years.

Heart attack.description: Heart attack Also known as MI, Myocardial Infarction, Coronary Attack, and Cardiac Infarction Myocardial infarction (MI) or acute myocardial infarction (AMI), commonly known as a heart attack, results from the partial interruption of blood supply to a part of the heart muscle, causing the heart cells to be damaged or die. This is most commonly due to occlusion (blockage) of a coronary artery following the rupture of a vulnerable atherosclerotic plaque, which is an unstable collection of cholesterol and fatty acids and white blood cells in the wall of an artery. The resulting ischemia (restriction in blood supply) and ensuing oxygen shortage, if left untreated for a sufficient period of time, can cause damage or death (infarction) of heart muscle tissue (myocardium). Source: Wikipedia
Heart attack.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Fainting, Irregular heartbeat, Nausea, Sweating, Lower body pain, Chest tightness, Increased heart rate, Arm pain, Heartburn, Burning chest pain, Sharp chest pain
Heart attack.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for heart attack include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, age 15-29 years, and age < 1 years almost never get heart attack.

Open wound of the abdomen.description: Open wound of the abdomen Open wound of the abdomen is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Open wound of the abdomen.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Swollen abdomen, Sweating, Blindness, Irregular belly button
Open wound of the abdomen.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for open wound of the abdomen include . On the other hand, age 1-4 years almost never get open wound of the abdomen.

Fracture of the leg.description: Fracture of the leg Also known as Broken Leg, Leg Fracture, Lower Extremity Fracture, and Lower Limb Fractures Fracture of the leg is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Fracture of the leg.symptoms: Knee swelling, Hip stiffness or tightness, Leg stiffness or tightness, Leg pain, Ankle pain, Hip pain, Problems with movement, Leg swelling, Knee pain, Ankle swelling, Knee weakness, Leg weakness
Fracture of the leg.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for fracture of the leg include age 75+ years.

Oral thrush (yeast infection).description: Oral thrush (yeast infection) Candida is the scientific name for yeast. It is a fungus that lives almost everywhere, including in your body. Usually, your immune system keeps yeast under control. If you are sick or taking antibiotics, it can multiply and cause an infection. Yeast infections affect different parts of the body in different ways: Thrush is a yeast infection that causes white patches in your mouth Esophagitis is thrush that spreads to your esophagus, the tube that takes food from your mouth to your stomach. Esophagitis can make it hard or painful to swallow Women can get vaginal yeast infections, causing itchiness, pain and discharge Yeast infections of the skin cause itching and rashes Yeast infections in your bloodstream can be life-threatening Antifungal medicines eliminate yeast infections in most people. If you have a weak immune system, treatment might be more difficult. Source: MedlinePlus
Oral thrush (yeast infection).symptoms: Diaper rash, Fever, Abnormal appearing tongue, Nasal congestion, Irritable infant, Cough, Mouth ulcer, Skin rash, Mouth pain, Constipation, Sore throat, Tongue lesions
tests: Other non-OR therapeutic procedures on skin and breast
Diagnostic bronchoscopy and biopsy of bronchus
Other OR therapeutic nervous system procedures
Oral thrush (yeast infection).riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for oral thrush (yeast infection) include race/ethnicity = black age < 1 years.

Pityriasis rosea.description: Pityriasis rosea Pityriasis rosea (also known as pityriasis rosea Gibert) is a skin rash. It is benign but may inflict substantial discomfort in certain cases. Classically, it begins with a single "herald patch" lesion, followed in 1 or 2 weeks by a generalized body rash lasting up to 12 weeks, however usually around 6 - 8. Source: Wikipedia
Pityriasis rosea.symptoms: Dry or flaky scalp, Skin growth, Excessive appetite, Skin swelling, Acne or pimples, Abnormal appearing skin, Skin rash, Fears and phobias, Itching of skin, Warts, Weight gain, Vaginal itching
Pityriasis rosea.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for pityriasis rosea include age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, race/ethnicity = black and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years almost never get pityriasis rosea.

Allergy to animals.description: Allergy to animals Also known as Animal Dander Allergy Allergy to animals is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Allergy to animals.symptoms: Fever, Cross-eyed, Itchiness of eye, Nasal congestion, Acne or pimples, Cough, Abnormal appearing skin, Smoking problems, Wrist weakness, Peripheral edema, Sore throat, Allergic reaction
tests: Other diagnostic procedures on skin and subcutaneous tissue
Allergy to animals.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for allergy to animals include race/ethnicity = other, age 30-44 years and age 5-14 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years and age 45-59 years almost never get allergy to animals.

Orthostatic hypotension.description: Orthostatic hypotension Also known as Postural Hypotension Orthostatic hypotension, also known as postural hypotension, orthostasis, and colloquially as head rush or dizzy spell, is a form of hypotension in which a person's blood pressure suddenly falls when standing up or stretching. Medically it is defined as a fall in systolic blood pressure of at least 20mm Hg and diastolic blood pressure of at least 10 mm Hg when a person assumes a standing position. Source: Wikipedia
Orthostatic hypotension.symptoms: Fainting, Abnormal involuntary movements, Irregular heartbeat, Headache, Palpitations, Increased heart rate, Fatigue, Hurts to breath, Dizziness, Feeling ill, Weakness, Sharp chest pain
Orthostatic hypotension.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for orthostatic hypotension include age 75+ years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get orthostatic hypotension.

Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).description: Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA) Also known as OSA Osa may refer to: Source: Wikipedia,Patients with obstructive sleep apnea (osa) often receive other diagnostic procedures (interview; evaluation; consultation), other therapeutic procedures on eyelids; conjunctiva; cornea, ultrasonography, echocardiography, electroencephalogram (eeg), ophthalmologic and otologic diagnosis and treatment, referral to home health care service and other or upper gi therapeutic procedures .
Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).symptoms: Shortness of breath, Abnormal breathing sounds, Sleepiness, Abnormal involuntary movements, Sweating, Difficulty in swallowing, Apnea, Weight gain, Fatigue, Insomnia, Difficulty breathing, Mouth dryness
tests: Ophthalmologic and otologic diagnosis and treatment
Other therapeutic procedures on eyelids; conjunctiva; cornea
Referral to home health care service
Other OR upper GI therapeutic procedures
Obstructive sleep apnea (OSA).riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for obstructive sleep apnea (osa) include age 60-74 years age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get obstructive sleep apnea (osa).

Hypokalemia.description: Hypokalemia Also known as Potassium Deficiency, K Deficiency, Hypopotassemia, and Potassium Depletion Hypokalemia (American English) or hypokalaemia (British English), also hypopotassemia or hypopotassaemia (ICD-9), refers to the condition in which the concentration of potassium (K+) in the blood is low. The prefix hypo- means "under" (contrast with hyper-, meaning "over"); kal- refers to kalium, the Neo-Latin for potassium, and -emia means "condition of the blood." Source: Wikipedia,Patients with hypokalemia often receive hematologic tests, complete blood count, intravenous fluid replacement, kidney function tests, electrolytes panel, glucose measurement, radiographic imaging procedure and urinalysis .
Hypokalemia.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Shortness of breath, Fainting, Fever, Nausea, Headache, Diarrhea, Loss of sensation, Vomiting, Dizziness, Weakness, Sharp chest pain
Hypokalemia.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for hypokalemia include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get hypokalemia.

Dislocation of the shoulder.description: Dislocation of the shoulder Also known as Shoulder Dislocation A dislocated shoulder occurs when the humerus separates from the scapula at the glenohumeral joint. The shoulder joint has the greatest range of motion of any joint in the body and as a result is particularly susceptible to dislocation and subluxation. Approximately half of major joint dislocations seen in emergency departments are of the shoulder. Partial dislocation of the shoulder is referred to as subluxation. Source: Wikipedia
Dislocation of the shoulder.symptoms: Shoulder pain, Neck mass, Redness in or around nose, Shoulder lump or mass, Arm swelling, Wrist pain, Arm pain, Leg weakness, Arm stiffness or tightness, Shoulder stiffness or tightness
Dislocation of the shoulder.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for dislocation of the shoulder include sex == male age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get dislocation of the shoulder.

Intussusception.description: Intussusception Also known as Bowel Intussusception and Intestinal Intussusception Intussusception may refer to: Source: Wikipedia,Patients with intussusception often receive radiographic imaging procedure, complete blood count, hematologic tests, x-ray computed tomography, intravenous fluid replacement, electrolytes panel, plain x-ray and liver function tests .
Intussusception.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Emotional symptoms, Cross-eyed, Nausea, Regurgitation, Vomiting, Excessive growth, Blood in stool, Itchy eyelid, Constipation, Upper abdominal pain, Diarrhea
Intussusception.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for intussusception include age 1-4 years, race/ethnicity = black and age < 1 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years and age 60-74 years almost never get intussusception.

Cervicitis.description: Cervicitis Cervicitis is inflammation of the uterine cervix. Cervicitis in women has many features in common with urethritis in men and many cases are caused by sexually transmitted infections. Non-infectious causes of cervicitis can include intrauterine devices, contraceptive diaphragms, and allergic reactions to spermicides or latex condoms. Source: Wikipedia
Cervicitis.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Vaginal discharge, Vaginal pain, Pain during pregnancy, Burning abdominal pain, Nausea, Painful urination, Cramps and spasms, Pelvic pain, Suprapubic pain, Vaginal itching, Lower abdominal pain
Cervicitis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for cervicitis include age 30-44 years, sex == female, race/ethnicity = black and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, sex == male, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get cervicitis.

Abscess of the pharynx.description: Abscess of the pharynx Abscess of the pharynx is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Abscess of the pharynx.symptoms: Throat swelling, Fever, Headache, Nasal congestion, Difficulty in swallowing, Cough, Sore throat, Coughing up sputum, Feeling ill, Allergic reaction, Ear pain, Sharp chest pain
Abscess of the pharynx.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for abscess of the pharynx include race/ethnicity = other, age 5-14 years and age 1-4 years.

Primary thrombocythemia.description: Primary thrombocythemia Also known as Essential Thrombocythemia, Essential Thrombocytosis, and Idiopathic Thrombocythemia Thrombocytosis (or thrombocythemia) is the presence of high platelet counts in the blood, and can be either primary (also termed essential and caused by a myeloproliferative disease) or reactive (also termed secondary). Although often symptomless (particularly when it is a secondary reaction), it can predispose to thrombosis in some patients. Source: Wikipedia
Primary thrombocythemia.symptoms: Joint pain, Symptoms of eye, Frequent urination, Sweating, Abusing alcohol, Rectal bleeding, Muscle pain, Flatulence, Fluid retention, Fatigue, Dizziness, Pain of the anus
Primary thrombocythemia.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for primary thrombocythemia include age 75+ years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get primary thrombocythemia.

Arthritis of the hip.description: Arthritis of the hip Also known as Hip Arthritis Arthritis of the hip is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Arthritis of the hip.symptoms: Ache all over, Joint pain, Hip stiffness or tightness, Lower body pain, Back pain, Pelvic pain, Low back pain, Leg pain, Hip pain, Groin pain, Problems with movement, Knee pain
tests: Other non-OR therapeutic procedures on musculoskeletal system

Insertion of catheter or spinal stimulator and injection into spinal canal
Arthritis of the hip.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for arthritis of the hip include age 75+ years age 45-59 years.

Decubitus ulcer.description: Decubitus ulcer Also known as Pressure Ulcer, Pressure Sores, Bed Sore, and Contact Ulcers Pressure ulcers, also known as decubitus ulcers or bedsores, are localized injuries to the skin and/or underlying tissue that usually occur over a bony prominence as a result of pressure, or pressure in combination with shear and/or friction. The most common sites are the sacrum, coccyx, heels or the hips, but other sites such as the elbows, knees, ankles or the back of the cranium can be affected. Source: Wikipedia
Decubitus ulcer.symptoms: Incontinence of stool, Difficulty speaking, Skin lesion, Penis redness, Skin on leg or foot looks infected, Disturbance of smell or taste, Skin pain
tests: Traction; splints; and other wound care
Debridement of wound; infection or burn
Referral to home health care service
Decubitus ulcer.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for decubitus ulcer include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years almost never get decubitus ulcer.

Hypernatremia.description: Hypernatremia Also known as Excess Sodium in Blood Hypernatremia or hypernatraemia (see American and British English spelling differences) is an electrolyte disturbance that is defined by an elevated sodium level in the blood. Hypernatremia is generally not caused by an excess of sodium, but rather by a relative deficit of free water in the body. For this reason, hypernatremia is often synonymous with the less precise term, dehydration. Source: Wikipedia
Hypernatremia.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Ache all over, Fever, Fainting, Heavy menstrual flow, Vomiting, Apnea, Fluid retention, Problems with movement, Difficulty breathing, Depressive or psychotic symptoms, Weakness
Hypernatremia.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for hypernatremia include age 75+ years, age 60-74 years, race/ethnicity = black and age < 1 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years almost never get hypernatremia.

Sensorineural hearing loss.description: Sensorineural hearing loss Also known as Sensory Hearing Loss and Sensorineural Deafness Sensorineural hearing loss (SNHL) is a type of hearing loss in which the root cause lies in the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII), the inner ear, or central processing centers of the brain. Sensorineural hearing loss can be mild, moderate, or severe, including total deafness. Source: Wikipedia
Sensorineural hearing loss.symptoms: Itchy ear(s), Redness in ear, Neck mass, Hoarse voice, Nasal congestion, Ringing in ear, Plugged feeling in ear, Diminished hearing, Dizziness, Throat feels tight, Ear pain, Fluid in ear
tests: Ophthalmologic and otologic diagnosis and treatment
Psychological and psychiatric evaluation and therapy
Other OR therapeutic procedures on nose; mouth and pharynx
Diagnostic procedures on nose; mouth and pharynx
Sensorineural hearing loss.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for sensorineural hearing loss include age 75+ years age 60-74 years.

Chronic ulcer.description: Chronic ulcer Also known as Chronic Skin Ulcer An ulcer is a discontinuity or break in a bodily membrane that impedes the organ of which that membrane is a part from continuing its normal functions. Common forms of ulcers recognized in medicine include: Source: Wikipedia,Patients with chronic ulcer often receive wound care management, complete physical skin exam performed (ml), debridement of wound; infection or burn, examination of foot, traction; splints; and other wound care, excision, referral to home health care service and application of splint .
Chronic ulcer.symptoms: Skin lesion, Skin pain, Skin on leg or foot looks infected
tests: Traction; splints; and other wound care
Debridement of wound; infection or burn
Referral to home health care service
Chronic ulcer.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for chronic ulcer include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get chronic ulcer.

Osteoporosis.description: Osteoporosis Osteoporosis ("porous bones", from Greek: /ostoun meaning "bone" and /poros meaning "pore") is a disease of bones that leads to an increased risk of fracture. In osteoporosis, the bone mineral density (BMD) is reduced, bone microarchitecture deteriorates, and the amount and variety of proteins in bone are altered. Osteoporosis is defined by the World Health Organization (WHO) as a bone mineral density of 2.5 standard deviations or more below the mean peak bone mass (average of young, healthy adults) as measured by dual-energy X-ray absorptiometry; the term "established osteoporosis" includes the presence of a fragility fracture. The disease may be classified as primary type 1, primary type 2, or secondary. Source: Wikipedia
Osteoporosis.symptoms: Joint pain, Muscle cramps, contractures, or spasms, Leg cramps or spasms, Back pain, Disturbance of memory, Early or late onset of menopause, Low back stiffness or tightness, Hip pain, Excessive urination at night, Bones are painful, Stomach bloating, Melena
Osteoporosis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for osteoporosis include age 75+ years, age 60-74 years and sex == female. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, age 15-29 years, and age < 1 years almost never get osteoporosis.

Ileus.description: Ileus Also known as Bowel Ileus Ileus (/jliYs/ or /jljYs/) is a disruption of the normal propulsive ability of the gastrointestinal tract. Source: Wikipedia
Ileus.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Nausea, Burning abdominal pain, Headache, Side pain, Vomiting, Constipation, Upper abdominal pain, Pain of the anus, Stomach bloating, Lower abdominal pain, Diarrhea
Ileus.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for ileus include race/ethnicity = other, age 75+ years and age 60-74 years.

Sickle cell crisis.description: Sickle cell crisis Also known as Sickle Cell Pain Crisis Sickle-cell disease (SCD), or sickle-cell anaemia (SCA) or drepanocytosis, is a hereditary blood disorder, characterized by red blood cells that assume an abnormal, rigid, sickle shape. Sickling decreases the cells' flexibility and results in a risk of various complications. The sickling occurs because of a mutation in the haemoglobin gene. Individuals with one copy of the defunct gene display both normal and abnormal haemoglobin. This is an example of codominance. Source: Wikipedia
Sickle cell crisis.symptoms: Ache all over, Sharp abdominal pain, Fever, Burning abdominal pain, Back pain, Vomiting, Low back pain, Leg pain, Hip pain, Arm pain, Knee pain, Sharp chest pain
Sickle cell crisis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for sickle cell crisis include age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = black and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, age 60-74 years, and race/ethnicity = white almost never get sickle cell crisis.

Urethritis.description: Urethritis Also known as Inflammation Of Urethra Urethritis is inflammation of the urethra. The most common symptom is painful or difficult urination. Source: Wikipedia
Urethritis.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Pain in testicles, Frequent urination, Blood in urine, Penis pain, Retention of urine, Painful urination, Suprapubic pain, Pelvic pain, Itching of skin, Vaginal itching, Penile discharge
tests: Physical therapy exercises; manipulation; and other procedures
Endoscopy and endoscopic biopsy of the urinary tract
Urethritis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for urethritis include age 30-44 years, sex == male, race/ethnicity = black and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get urethritis.

Prostatitis.description: Prostatitis Also known as Prostate Inflammation Prostatitis is inflammation of the prostate gland. Prostatitis is classified into acute, chronic, asymptomatic inflammatory prostatitis, and chronic pelvic pain syndrome. Source: Wikipedia
Prostatitis.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Pain in testicles, Fever, Frequent urination, Blood in urine, Symptoms of prostate, Impotence, Retention of urine, Painful urination, Back pain, Lower abdominal pain, Chills
tests: Prostate specific antigen measurement (Prostate specific antigen test)

Prostatitis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for prostatitis include sex == male, age 60-74 years and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, sex == female, and age < 1 years almost never get prostatitis.

Otitis externa (swimmer's ear).description: Otitis externa (swimmer's ear) Also known as Swimmer's ear Otitis externa (also known as "External otitis" and "Swimmer's ear") is an inflammation of the outer ear and ear canal. Along with otitis media, external otitis is one of the two human conditions commonly called "earache". It also occurs in many other species. Inflammation of the skin of the ear canal is the essence of this disorder. The inflammation can be secondary to dermatitis (eczema) only, with no microbial infection, or it can be caused by active bacterial or fungal infection. In either case, but more often with infection, the ear canal skin swells and may become painful or tender to touch. Source: Wikipedia
Otitis externa (swimmer's ear).symptoms: Itchy ear(s), Redness in ear, Fever, Facial pain, Ringing in ear, Cough, Bleeding from ear, Plugged feeling in ear, Diminished hearing, Sore throat, Ear pain, Fluid in ear
tests: Ophthalmologic and otologic diagnosis and treatment
Otitis externa (swimmer's ear).riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for otitis externa (swimmer's ear) include age 5-14 years.

Poisoning due to anticonvulsants.description: Poisoning due to anticonvulsants Poisoning due to anticonvulsants is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Poisoning due to anticonvulsants.symptoms: Difficulty speaking, Headache, Depression, Ringing in ear, Vomiting, Slurring words, Itching of skin, Seizures, Problems with movement, Dizziness, Feeling ill, Pain in eye
Poisoning due to anticonvulsants.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for poisoning due to anticonvulsants include . On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get poisoning due to anticonvulsants.

Testicular torsion.description: Testicular torsion Also known as Torsion Of Testis and Spermatic Cord Torsion Testicular torsion occurs when the spermatic cord (from which the testicle is suspended) twists, cutting off the testicle's blood supply, a condition called ischemia. The principal symptom is rapid onset of testicular pain. The most common underlying cause is a congenital malformation known as a "bell-clapper deformity" wherein the testis is inadequately affixed to the scrotum allowing it to move freely on its axis and susceptible to induced twisting of the cord and its vessels. The diagnosis can be made clinically but an urgent ultrasound is helpful in evaluation. Irreversible ischemia begins around six hours after onset and emergency diagnosis and treatment is required within this time in order to minimize necrosis and to improve the chance of salvaging the testicle. Source: Wikipedia
Testicular torsion.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Pain in testicles, Emotional symptoms, Burning abdominal pain, Itching of scrotum, Back pain, Symptoms of the scrotum and testes, Elbow weakness, Elbow cramps or spasms, Muscle swelling, Swelling of scrotum, Nailbiting
Testicular torsion.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for testicular torsion include sex == male, age 5-14 years and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, age 60-74 years, and sex == female almost never get testicular torsion.

Tricuspid valve disease.description: Tricuspid valve disease Also known as Tricuspid Valve Disorder Tricuspid valve disease is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Tricuspid valve disease.symptoms: Drainage in throat, Emotional symptoms, Hip stiffness or tightness, Cross-eyed, Back pain, Excessive growth, Itchy eyelid, Wrist weakness, Elbow cramps or spasms, Nailbiting, Anxiety and nervousness, Elbow weakness
Tricuspid valve disease.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for tricuspid valve disease include race/ethnicity = other, age 75+ years and age 60-74 years.

Urethral stricture.description: Urethral stricture Also known as Urethral Stenosis A urethral stricture is a narrowing of the urethra caused by injury or disease such as urinary tract infections or other forms of urethritis. Source: Wikipedia
Urethral stricture.symptoms: Frequent urination, Blood in urine, Symptoms of prostate, Retention of urine, Painful urination, Penis redness, Symptoms of the scrotum and testes, Suprapubic pain, Symptoms of bladder, Excessive urination at night, Involuntary urination, Swelling of scrotum
tests: Prostate specific antigen measurement (Prostate specific antigen test)
Insertion of catheter into urinary bladder
Endoscopy and endoscopic biopsy of the urinary tract
Urethral stricture.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for urethral stricture include age 75+ years, sex == male and age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get urethral stricture.

Vitamin D deficiency.description: Vitamin D deficiency Hypovitaminosis D is a deficiency of vitamin D. It can result from inadequate nutritional intake of vitamin D coupled with inadequate sunlight exposure (in particular sunlight with adequate ultraviolet B rays), disorders that limit vitamin D absorption, and conditions that impair the conversion of vitamin D into active metabolites including certain liver, kidney, and hereditary disorders. Deficiency results in impaired bone mineralization and leads to bone softening diseases including rickets in children and osteomalacia and osteoporosis in adults. Source: Wikipedia
Vitamin D deficiency.symptoms: Joint pain, Back stiffness or tightness, Infrequent menstruation, Feeling hot, Smoking problems, Weight gain, Fatigue, Mouth dryness, Hot flashes, Melena, Arm stiffness or tightness, Skin irritation
Vitamin D deficiency.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for vitamin d deficiency include age 60-74 years.

Hydatidiform mole.description: Hydatidiform mole Also known as Molar Pregnancy and Hydatid Mole Molar pregnancy is an abnormal form of pregnancy in which a non-viable fertilized egg implants in the uterus and converts a normal pregnancy into an abnormal one (which will fail to come to term). A molar pregnancy is a gestational trophoblastic disease that grows into a mass in the uterus that has swollen chorionic villi. These villi grow in clusters that resemble grapes. A molar pregnancy can develop when an egg that is missing its nucleus is fertilized and that may or may not contain fetal tissue. It is characterized by the presence of a hydatidiform mole (or hydatid mole, mola hydatidosa). Molar pregnancies are categorized into partial and complete moles. Mole as used here simply indicates clump of growing tissue, or a 'growth'. Source: Wikipedia
Hydatidiform mole.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Pain during pregnancy, Nausea, Burning abdominal pain, Spotting or bleeding during pregnancy, Side pain, Vomiting, Pelvic pain, Low back pain, Problems during pregnancy, Dizziness, Diminished vision
Hydatidiform mole.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for hydatidiform mole include age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = hispanic, sex == female and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, sex == male, age 60-74 years, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, age 45-59 years, and age < 1 years almost never get hydatidiform mole.

Pain disorder affecting the neck.description: Pain disorder affecting the neck Pain disorder affecting the neck is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Pain disorder affecting the neck.symptoms: Shoulder pain, Headache, Paresthesia, Back pain, Loss of sensation, Neck stiffness or tightness, Disturbance of memory, Neck pain, Low back pain, Arm pain, Insomnia, Dizziness
tests: Other non-OR or closed therapeutic nervous system procedures
Insertion of catheter or spinal stimulator and injection into spinal canal
Pain disorder affecting the neck.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for pain disorder affecting the neck include . On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get pain disorder affecting the neck.

Tuberculosis.description: Tuberculosis Also known as TB and Tuberculosis Infection Tuberculosis, MTB, or TB (short for tubercle bacillus) is a common, and in many cases lethal, infectious disease caused by various strains of mycobacteria, usually Mycobacterium tuberculosis. Tuberculosis typically attacks the lungs, but can also affect other parts of the body. It is spread through the air when people who have an active TB infection cough, sneeze, or otherwise transmit respiratory fluids through the air. Most infections are asymptomatic and latent, but about one in ten latent infections eventually progresses to active disease which, if left untreated, kills more than 50% of those so infected. Source: Wikipedia
Tuberculosis.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Drainage in throat, Itchiness of eye, Back cramps or spasms, Sweating, Cough, Hemoptysis, Vaginal itching, Hurts to breath, Congestion in chest, Skin dryness, peeling, scaliness, or roughness
tests: Other diagnostic procedures on skin and subcutaneous tissue
Diagnostic bronchoscopy and biopsy of bronchus

Moxclav DS Powder for Oral Suspension
Tuberculosis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for tuberculosis include race/ethnicity = other, race/ethnicity = hispanic, age 5-14 years and race/ethnicity = black. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get tuberculosis.

Pelvic fistula.description: Pelvic fistula Pelvic fistula is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Pelvic fistula.symptoms: Vaginal discharge, Fainting, Itching of scrotum, Recent pregnancy, Back pain, Rectal bleeding, Elbow weakness, Elbow cramps or spasms, Heartburn, Muscle swelling, Dizziness, Nailbiting
