Acute bronchiolitis.description: Acute bronchiolitis Bronchiolitis is inflammation of the bronchioles, the smallest air passages of the lungs. It usually occurs in children less than two years of age with the majority being aged between three and six months. It presents with coughing, wheezing and shortness of breath which can cause some children difficulty feeding. This inflammation is usually caused by respiratory syncytial virus (70% of cases) and is much more common in the winter months. Treatment is typically supportive and may involve the use of nebulized epinephrine or hypertonic saline. Bronchiolitis is common with up to one third of children being affected in their first year of life. Source: Wikipedia
Acute bronchiolitis.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Fever, Irritable infant, Nasal congestion, Cough, Vomiting, Pulling at ears, Decreased appetite, Hurts to breath, Difficulty breathing, Wheezing, Coryza
tests: Other OR therapeutic nervous system procedures
Acute bronchiolitis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for acute bronchiolitis include race/ethnicity = other, race/ethnicity = hispanic, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, age 60-74 years, and age 15-29 years almost never get acute bronchiolitis.

Presbyopia.description: Presbyopia Presbyopia is a condition where with age, the eye exhibits a progressively diminished ability to focus on near objects. Presbyopia s exact mechanisms are not known with certainty; the research evidence most strongly supports a loss of elasticity of the crystalline lens, although changes in the lens s curvature from continual growth and loss of power of the ciliary muscles (the muscles that bend and straighten the lens) have also been postulated as its cause. Like gray hair and wrinkles, presbyopia is a symptom caused by the natural course of aging. The first signs of presbyopia eyestrain, difficulty seeing in dim light, problems focusing on small objects and/or fine print are usually first noticed between the ages of 40 and 50. The ability to focus on near objects declines throughout life, from an accommodation of about 20 dioptres (ability to focus at 50 mm away) in a child, to 10 dioptres at age 25 (100 mm), and levels off at 0.5 to 1 dioptre at age 60 (ability to focus down to 1 2 meters only). The expected, maximum, and minimum amplitudes of accommodation for a corrected patient of a given age can be determined using Hofstetter's formulas: Expected amplitude (D) = 18.5 - 0.3 x (age in years), Maximum amplitude (D) = 25 - 0.4 x (age in years), Minimum amplitude (D) = 15 - 0.25 x (age in years). Source: Wikipedia
Presbyopia.symptoms: Symptoms of eye, Itchiness of eye, Difficulty speaking, Foreign body sensation in eye, Spots or clouds in vision, Lacrimation, Eye burns or stings, Mass on eyelid, Abnormal movement of eyelid, Eye redness, Diminished vision, Pain in eye
tests: Ophthalmologic and otologic diagnosis and treatment
Other therapeutic procedures on eyelids; conjunctiva; cornea
Referral to home health care service
Presbyopia.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for presbyopia include race/ethnicity = other, age 60-74 years and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years, age 15-29 years, and age < 1 years almost never get presbyopia.

Dementia.description: Dementia Dementia (taken from Latin, originally meaning "madness", from de- "without" + ment, the root of mens "mind") is a serious loss of global cognitive ability in a previously unimpaired person, beyond what might be expected from normal ageing. It may be static, the result of a unique global brain injury, or progressive, resulting in long-term decline due to damage or disease in the body. Although dementia is far more common in the geriatric population, it can occur before the age of 65, in which case it is termed "early onset dementia". Source: Wikipedia
Dementia.symptoms: Abnormal involuntary movements, Difficulty speaking, Paresthesia, Disturbance of memory, Hostile behavior, Disturbance of smell or taste, Dizziness, Delusions or hallucinations, Focal weakness, Insomnia, Problems with movement, Depressive or psychotic symptoms
Dementia.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for dementia include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get dementia.

Insect bite.description: Insect bite Insect bites and stings occur when an insect is agitated and seeks to defend itself through its natural defense mechanisms, or when an insect seeks to feed off the bitten person. Some insects inject formic acid, which can cause an immediate skin reaction often resulting in redness and swelling in the injured area. Stings from fire ants, bees, wasps and hornets are usually painful, and may stimulate a dangerous allergic reaction called anaphylaxis for at-risk patients, and some wasps can also have a powerful bite along with a sting. Bites from mosquitoes and fleas are more likely to cause itching than pain. Source: Wikipedia
Insect bite.symptoms: Hand or finger swelling, Swollen eye, Skin swelling, Skin lesion, Abnormal appearing skin, Skin rash, Arm swelling, Itching of skin, Fluid retention, Peripheral edema, Leg swelling, Lip swelling
Insect bite.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for insect bite include age 5-14 years age 1-4 years.

Paroxysmal ventricular tachycardia.description: Paroxysmal ventricular tachycardia Also known as VT, Ventricular Tachycardia, V Tach, and Ventricular Tachyarrhythmia VT or Vt may refer to: Source: Wikipedia,Patients with paroxysmal ventricular tachycardia often receive electrocardiogram, intravenous fluid replacement, electrolytes panel, other diagnostic procedures (interview; evaluation; consultation), cardiac enzymes measurement, kidney function tests, cardiac monitoring and echocardiography .
Paroxysmal ventricular tachycardia.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Fainting, Irregular heartbeat, Decreased heart rate, Palpitations, Chest tightness, Increased heart rate, Weight gain, Slurring words, Fatigue, Dizziness, Sharp chest pain
Paroxysmal ventricular tachycardia.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for paroxysmal ventricular tachycardia include age 75+ years, sex == male and age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get paroxysmal ventricular tachycardia.

Congenital heart defect.description: Congenital heart defect Also known as Cardiac Anomaly, Heart Anomaly, and Heart Malformation A congenital heart defect (CHD) is a defect in the structure of the heart and great vessels which is present at birth. Many types of heart defects exist, most of which either obstruct blood flow in the heart or vessels near it, or cause blood to flow through the heart in an abnormal pattern. Other defects, such as long QT syndrome, affect the heart's rhythm. Heart defects are among the most common birth defects and are the leading cause of birth defect-related deaths. Approximately 9 people in 1000 are born with a congenital heart defect. Many defects don't need treatment, but some complex congenital heart defects require medication or surgery. Source: Wikipedia
Congenital heart defect.symptoms: Cross-eyed, Lymphedema, Excessive appetite, Irregular belly button, Lack of growth, Decreased heart rate, Arm swelling, Slurring words, Hand or finger stiffness or tightness, Infant feeding problem, Neck cramps or spasms, Sharp chest pain
Congenital heart defect.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for congenital heart defect include race/ethnicity = other, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years.

Connective tissue disorder.description: Connective tissue disorder Also known as Connective Tissue Disease A connective tissue disease is any disease that has the connective tissues of the body as a target of pathology. Connective tissue is any type of biological tissue with an extensive extracellular matrix that supports, binds together, and protects organs. These tissues form a framework, or matrix, for the body, and are composed of two major structural protein molecules: collagen and elastin. There are many different types of collagen protein in each of the body's tissues. Elastin has the capability of stretching and returning to its original length like a spring or rubber band. Elastin is the major component of ligaments (tissues that attach bone to bone) and skin. In patients with connective tissue disease, it is common for collagen and elastin to become injured by inflammation. Many connective tissue diseases feature abnormal immune system activity with inflammation in tissues as a result of an immune system that is directed against one's own body tissues (autoimmunity). Source: Wikipedia
Connective tissue disorder.symptoms: Joint pain, Ache all over, Fever, Headache, Lymphedema, Paresthesia, Difficulty in swallowing, Foot or toe pain, Skin rash, Fatigue, Arm pain, Feeling ill
tests: Referral to home health care service
Connective tissue disorder.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for connective tissue disorder include age 30-44 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get connective tissue disorder.

Foreign body in the eye.description: Foreign body in the eye Foreign body in the eye is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Foreign body in the eye.symptoms: Symptoms of eye, Eyelid lesion or rash, Eyelid swelling, Itchiness of eye, Swollen eye, Foreign body sensation in eye, Lacrimation, White discharge from eye, Pain in eye, Abnormal movement of eyelid, Eye redness, Eye burns or stings
tests: Other therapeutic procedures on eyelids; conjunctiva; cornea
Foreign body in the eye.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for foreign body in the eye include age 30-44 years, sex == male and age 15-29 years.

Poisoning due to gas.description: Poisoning due to gas Also known as Gas Poisoning Chemical warfare (CW) involves using the toxic properties of chemical substances as weapons. This type of warfare is distinct from nuclear warfare and biological warfare, which together make up NBC, the military acronym for nuclear, biological, and chemical (warfare or weapons), all of which are considered "weapons of mass destruction" (WMD). None of these fall under the term conventional weapons which are primarily effective due to their destructive potential. Chemical warfare does not depend upon explosive force to achieve an objective. Rather it depends upon the unique properties of the chemical agent weaponized. A lethal agent is designed to injure or incapacitate the enemy, or deny unhindered use of a particular area of terrain. Defoliants are used to quickly kill vegetation and deny its use for cover and concealment. It can also be used against agriculture and livestock to promote hunger and starvation. With proper protective equipment, training, and decontamination measures, the primary effects of chemical weapons can be overcome. Many nations possess vast stockpiles of weaponized agents in preparation for wartime use. The threat and the perceived threat have become strategic tools in planning both measures, and counter measures. Source: Wikipedia
Poisoning due to gas.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Drainage in throat, Fever, Headache, Nausea, Wheezing, Nasal congestion, Cough, Difficulty breathing, Sore throat, Dizziness, Sharp chest pain
Poisoning due to gas.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for poisoning due to gas include race/ethnicity = other age 1-4 years.

Pyogenic skin infection.description: Pyogenic skin infection Also known as Pyoderma and Pyodermia Pyoderma means any skin disease that is pyogenic. These include superficial bacterial infections such as impetigo, impetigo contagiosa, ecthyma, folliculitis, Bockhart's impetigo, furuncle, carbuncle, tropical ulcer, etc. Autoimmune conditions include pyoderma gangrenosum. Pyoderma affects more than 111 million children worldwide, making it one of the three most common skin disorders in children along with scabies and tinea. Source: Wikipedia
Pyogenic skin infection.symptoms: Hand or finger pain, Hand or finger swelling, Foot or toe swelling, Skin lesion, Foot or toe pain, Skin swelling, Skin on leg or foot looks infected, Skin rash, Abnormal appearing skin, Leg pain, Peripheral edema, Leg swelling
Pyogenic skin infection.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for pyogenic skin infection include .

Endometrial hyperplasia.description: Endometrial hyperplasia Endometrial hyperplasia is a condition of excessive proliferation of the cells of the endometrium, or inner lining of the uterus. Source: Wikipedia
Endometrial hyperplasia.symptoms: Vaginal discharge, Low back weakness, Vaginal bleeding after menopause, Heavy menstrual flow, Pelvic pain, Back weakness, Pus in sputum, Elbow cramps or spasms, Abnormal size or shape of ear, Involuntary urination, Muscle swelling, Unpredictable menstruation
Endometrial hyperplasia.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for endometrial hyperplasia include sex == female age 45-59 years. On the other hand, sex == male, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get endometrial hyperplasia.

Acanthosis nigricans.description: Acanthosis nigricans Acanthosis nigricans is a brown to black, poorly defined, velvety hyperpigmentation of the skin. It is usually found in body folds, such as the posterior and lateral folds of the neck, the axilla, groin, umbilicus, forehead, and other areas. Source: Wikipedia
Acanthosis nigricans.symptoms: Pain or soreness of breast, Skin moles, Skin growth, Acne or pimples, Skin lesion, Infertility, Apnea, Weight gain, Warts, Fluid retention, Unwanted hair, Allergic reaction
Acanthosis nigricans.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for acanthosis nigricans include race/ethnicity = hispanic, age 5-14 years, race/ethnicity = black and age 15-29 years.

Central atherosclerosis.description: Central atherosclerosis Also known as Aortoiliac Disease Central atherosclerosis is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Central atherosclerosis.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Peripheral edema, Joint pain, Blood in urine, Irregular heartbeat, Hand or finger cramps or spasms, Muscle pain, Symptoms of the kidneys, Weight gain, Increased heart rate, Excessive urination at night, Fatigue
tests: Arterio- or venogram (not heart and head)
Central atherosclerosis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for central atherosclerosis include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get central atherosclerosis.

Viral exanthem.description: Viral exanthem Also known as Viral Rash An exanthem (from Greek "exanthema", a breaking out) is a widespread rash usually occurring in children. Exanthems can be caused by toxins or drugs, microorganisms, or can result from autoimmune disease. Source: Wikipedia
Viral exanthem.symptoms: Fever, Nasal congestion, Skin swelling, Cough, Lip sore, Vomiting, Skin rash, Abnormal appearing skin, Pulling at ears, Itching of skin, Flu-like syndrome, Decreased appetite
Viral exanthem.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for viral exanthem include age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years and age 60-74 years almost never get viral exanthem.

Blastomycosis.description: Blastomycosis Blastomycosis (also known as "North American blastomycosis," "Blastomycetic dermatitis," and "Gilchrist's disease") is a fungal infection caused by the organism Blastomyces dermatitidis. Endemic to portions of North America, blastomycosis causes clinical symptoms similar to histoplasmosis. Source: Wikipedia
Blastomycosis.symptoms: Pain or soreness of breast, Pain during pregnancy, Joint stiffness or tightness, Facial pain, Shoulder cramps or spasms, Knee lump or mass, Wrist pain, Excessive anger, Ankle pain, Fatigue, Excessive urination at night, Pain in eye
Blastomycosis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for blastomycosis include race/ethnicity = other, age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = hispanic, age 75+ years, age 60-74 years, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, race/ethnicity = black, age 15-29 years, age 45-59 years and age < 1 years.

Noninfectious gastroenteritis.description: Noninfectious gastroenteritis Noninfectious gastroenteritis is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Noninfectious gastroenteritis.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Fever, Nausea, Burning abdominal pain, Headache, Chills, Rectal bleeding, Vomiting, Blood in stool, Fluid retention, Decreased appetite, Diarrhea
Noninfectious gastroenteritis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for noninfectious gastroenteritis include age 1-4 years age < 1 years.

Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).description: Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) Also known as BPH, Benign Prostatic Hypertrophy, and Benign Prostate Enlargement BPH may refer to: Source: Wikipedia,Patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia (bph) often receive urinalysis, hematologic tests, prostate specific antigen measurement, rectal examination, ultrasonography, lipid panel, other diagnostic procedures (interview; evaluation; consultation) and endoscopy and endoscopic biopsy of the urinary tract .
Benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH).symptoms: Pain in testicles, Impotence, Frequent urination, Blood in urine, Symptoms of prostate, Retention of urine, Low urine output, Symptoms of bladder, Excessive urination at night, Involuntary urination, Hesitancy, Swelling of scrotum
