Pulmonary hypertension.description: Pulmonary hypertension Also known as Pulmonary Hypertension Disorder Pulmonary hypertension (PH) is an increase of blood pressure in the pulmonary artery, pulmonary vein, or pulmonary capillaries, together known as the lung vasculature, leading to shortness of breath, dizziness, fainting, leg swelling and other symptoms. Pulmonary hypertension can be a severe disease with a markedly decreased exercise tolerance and heart failure. It was first identified by Dr. Ernst von Romberg in 1891. According to the most recent classification, it can be one of five different types: arterial, venous, hypoxic, thromboembolic or miscellaneous. Source: Wikipedia
Pulmonary hypertension.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Hurts to breath, Cough, Hemoptysis, Apnea, Palpitations, Fatigue, Peripheral edema, Difficulty breathing, Wheezing, Feeling ill, Sharp chest pain
Pulmonary hypertension.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for pulmonary hypertension include age 75+ years age 60-74 years.

Thyroid nodule.description: Thyroid nodule Thyroid nodules are lumps which commonly arise within an otherwise normal thyroid gland. They indicate a thyroid neoplasm, but only a small percentage of these are thyroid cancers. Source: Wikipedia
Thyroid nodule.symptoms: Sleepiness, Neck mass, Difficulty in swallowing, Back weakness, Weight gain, Lump in throat, Fatigue, Diminished hearing, Abnormal movement of eyelid, Neck swelling, Throat feels tight, Hoarse voice
Thyroid nodule.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for thyroid nodule include age 60-74 years age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get thyroid nodule.

Broken tooth.description: Broken tooth Dental trauma refers to trauma to the face, mouth, and especially the teeth, lips and periodontium. The study of dental trauma is called dental traumatology. Source: Wikipedia
Broken tooth.symptoms: Difficulty eating, Gum pain, Bleeding in mouth, Dry lips, Facial pain, Bleeding gums, Lump over jaw, Mouth pain, Slurring words, Peripheral edema, Toothache, Lip swelling
Broken tooth.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for broken tooth include age 1-4 years age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years almost never get broken tooth.

Dumping syndrome.description: Dumping syndrome Gastric dumping syndrome, or rapid gastric emptying is a condition where ingested foods bypass the stomach too rapidly and enter the small intestine largely undigested. It happens when the small intestine expands too quickly due to the presence of hyperosmolar (having increased osmolarity) food from the stomach. "Early" dumping begins concurrently with or immediately succeeding ingestion of a meal. Symptoms of early dumping include nausea, vomiting, bloating, cramping, diarrhea, dizziness, and fatigue. "Late" dumping happens one to three hours after eating. Symptoms of late dumping include weakness, sweating, and dizziness. Many people have both types. The syndrome is most often associated with gastric bypass (Roux-en-Y) surgery. Source: Wikipedia
Dumping syndrome.symptoms: Vulvar sore, Nausea, Headache, Knee lump or mass, Vomiting, Excessive growth, Weight gain, Itchy eyelid, Fatigue, Upper abdominal pain, Ear pain, Diarrhea
Dumping syndrome.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for dumping syndrome include age 60-74 years, age 45-59 years and race/ethnicity = white. On the other hand, race/ethnicity = black and age 15-29 years almost never get dumping syndrome.

Lymphadenitis.description: Lymphadenitis Also known as Adenitis and Lymph Gland Infection Lymphadenopathy is a term meaning "disease of the lymph nodes." It is, however, almost synonymously used with "swollen/enlarged lymph nodes". It could be due to infection, auto-immune disease, or malignancy. Source: Wikipedia
Lymphadenitis.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Fever, Neck mass, Headache, Skin swelling, Cough, Vomiting, Neck pain, Swollen lymph nodes, Neck swelling, Sore throat, Ear pain
Lymphadenitis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for lymphadenitis include age 5-14 years age 1-4 years.

Injury to the face.description: Injury to the face Also known as Face Injury and Facial Injury General or unspecified injuries to the soft tissue or bony portions of the face. Source: MeSH
Injury to the face.symptoms: Headache, Bleeding in mouth, Facial pain, Swollen eye, Neck stiffness or tightness, Redness in or around nose, Bleeding from ear, Neck pain, Mouth pain, Diminished hearing, Nosebleed, Ear pain
Injury to the face.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for injury to the face include age 5-14 years age 1-4 years.

Aortic valve disease.description: Aortic valve disease Also known as Aortic Valve Disorder Aortic valve disease is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Aortic valve disease.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Fainting, Irregular heartbeat, Groin mass, Lymphedema, Leg cramps or spasms, Palpitations, Increased heart rate, Fatigue, Peripheral edema, Difficulty breathing, Sharp chest pain
Aortic valve disease.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for aortic valve disease include age 75+ years age 60-74 years.

Rheumatoid arthritis.description: Rheumatoid arthritis Also known as Atrophic Arthritis and Proliferative Arthritis Rheumatoid arthritis (RA) is an autoimmune disease that results in a chronic, systemic inflammatory disorder that may affect many tissues and organs, but principally attacks flexible (synovial) joints. It can be a disabling and painful condition, which can lead to substantial loss of functioning and mobility if not adequately treated. Source: Wikipedia
Rheumatoid arthritis.symptoms: Joint pain, Hand or finger pain, Ache all over, Hand or finger swelling, Wrist swelling, Hand or finger weakness, Elbow swelling, Joint swelling, Wrist pain, Stiffness all over, Peripheral edema, Knee pain
Rheumatoid arthritis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for rheumatoid arthritis include age 75+ years, age 60-74 years and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get rheumatoid arthritis.

Spermatocele.description: Spermatocele Also known as Epididymal Cyst and Cyst Of Epididymis Spermatocele (/sp\rmtYsil/) is a retention cyst of a tubule of the rete testis or the head of the epididymis distended with barely watery fluid that contains spermatozoa. Spermatoceles are the most common cystic condition encountered within the scrotum. They vary in size from several millimeters to many centimeters. Spermatoceles are generally not painful. However, some men may experience discomfort from larger spermatoceles. They are harmless. Source: Wikipedia
Spermatocele.symptoms: Pain in testicles, Impotence, Frequent urination, Skin growth, Retention of urine, Low back weakness, Mass in scrotum, Leg lump or mass, Groin pain, Muscle swelling, Swelling of scrotum, Elbow weakness
tests: Prostate specific antigen measurement (Prostate specific antigen test)
Other non-OR therapeutic procedures of urinary tract
Spermatocele.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for spermatocele include sex == male age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, sex == female, and age < 1 years almost never get spermatocele.

Anal fistula.description: Anal fistula Anal fistula, or fistula-in-ano, is an abnormal connection between the epithelialised surface of the anal canal and (usually) the perianal skin. Source: Wikipedia
Anal fistula.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Incontinence of stool, Low back cramps or spasms, Lower body pain, Rectal bleeding, Mass in scrotum, Blood in stool, Constipation, Mass or swelling around the anus, Discharge in stools, Pain of the anus
tests: Other OR lower GI therapeutic procedures
Anal fistula.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for anal fistula include age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = hispanic, age 45-59 years and age < 1 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years almost never get anal fistula.

Hypothermia.description: Hypothermia Hypothermia (from Greek ) is a condition in which core temperature drops below the required temperature for normal metabolism and body functions which is defined as 35.0 C (95.0 F). Body temperature is usually maintained near a constant level of 36.5 37.5 C (98 100 F) through biologic homeostasis or thermoregulation. If exposed to cold and the internal mechanisms are unable to replenish the heat that is being lost, a drop in core temperature occurs. As body temperature decreases, characteristic symptoms occur such as shivering and mental confusion. Source: Wikipedia
Hypothermia.symptoms: Emotional symptoms, Fainting, Feeling hot and cold, Loss of sensation, Vomiting, Leg stiffness or tightness, Skin rash, Wrist weakness, Leg swelling, Depressive or psychotic symptoms, Weakness, Elbow weakness
Hypothermia.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for hypothermia include sex == male, age 45-59 years and age < 1 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years and age 5-14 years almost never get hypothermia.

Oppositional disorder.description: Oppositional disorder Also known as Oppositional Defiant Disorder Oppositional defiant disorder (ODD) is a childhood disorder described by the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM) as an ongoing pattern of anger-guided disobedience, hostility, and defiant behavior toward authority figures which goes beyond the bounds of normal childhood behavior. Children suffering from this disorder may appear very stubborn and often angry. A diagnosis of ODD cannot be given if the child presents with conduct disorder (CD). Source: Wikipedia
Oppositional disorder.symptoms: Fainting, Restlessness, Hostile behavior, Temper problems, Low self-esteem, Nightmares, Excessive anger, Low urine output, Antisocial behavior, Obsessions and compulsions, Depressive or psychotic symptoms
tests: Psychological and psychiatric evaluation and therapy
Oppositional disorder.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for oppositional disorder include sex == male age 5-14 years. On the other hand, age 30-44 years, age 75+ years, age 60-74 years, age 45-59 years, and age < 1 years almost never get oppositional disorder.

Diabetic peripheral neuropathy.description: Diabetic peripheral neuropathy Diabetic neuropathies are neuropathic disorders that are associated with diabetes mellitus. These conditions are thought to result from diabetic microvascular injury involving small blood vessels that supply nerves (vasa nervorum) in addition to macrovascular conditions that can culminate in diabetic neuropathy. Relatively common conditions which may be associated with diabetic neuropathy include third nerve palsy; mononeuropathy; mononeuropathy multiplex; diabetic amyotrophy; a painful polyneuropathy; autonomic neuropathy; and thoracoabdominal neuropathy. Source: Wikipedia
Diabetic peripheral neuropathy.symptoms: Foot or toe swelling, Lymphedema, Paresthesia, Skin lesion, Foot or toe pain, Loss of sensation, Hand or finger cramps or spasms, Skin on leg or foot looks infected, Foot or toe stiffness or tightness, Leg pain, Problems with movement, Poor circulation
Diabetic peripheral neuropathy.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for diabetic peripheral neuropathy include age 75+ years, age 60-74 years and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get diabetic peripheral neuropathy.

Testicular disorder.description: Testicular disorder Also known as Testis Disorder and Testicular Disease The testicle (from Latin testiculus, diminutive of testis, meaning "witness" of virility, plural testes) is the male gonad in animals. Like the ovaries to which they are homologous, testes are components of both the reproductive system and the endocrine system. The primary functions of the testes are to produce sperm (spermatogenesis) and to produce androgens, primarily testosterone. Source: Wikipedia
Testicular disorder.symptoms: Skin moles, Pain in testicles, Impotence, Symptoms of prostate, Regurgitation, Symptoms of the scrotum and testes, Mass in scrotum, Excessive anger, Fatigue, Excessive urination at night, Loss of sex drive, Hoarse voice
tests: Prostate specific antigen measurement (Prostate specific antigen test)
Testicular disorder.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for testicular disorder include sex == male, age 60-74 years and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years, sex == female, and age < 1 years almost never get testicular disorder.

Gestational diabetes.description: Gestational diabetes Also known as GDM, Gestational Diabetes Mellitus, and Pregnancy Induced Diabetes Gestational diabetes (or gestational diabetes mellitus, GDM) is a condition in which women without previously diagnosed diabetes exhibit high blood glucose levels during pregnancy (especially during their third trimester). There is some question whether the condition is natural during pregnancy. Gestational diabetes is caused when the insulin receptors do not function properly. This is likely due to pregnancy related factors such as the presence of human placental lactogen that interferes with susceptible insulin receptors. This in turn causes inappropriately elevated blood sugar levels. Source: Wikipedia
Gestational diabetes.symptoms: Uterine contractions, Hip stiffness or tightness, Pain during pregnancy, Pelvic pressure, Excessive appetite, Vaginal redness, Problems during pregnancy, Itching of the anus, Mass on vulva
Gestational diabetes.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for gestational diabetes include race/ethnicity = other, age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = hispanic, sex == female and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, sex == male, age 60-74 years, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, age 45-59 years, and age < 1 years almost never get gestational diabetes.

Hidradenitis suppurativa.description: Hidradenitis suppurativa Also known as Axillary Hidradenitis, Apocrine Acne, and Verneuil's Disease Hidradenitis suppurativa (HS) is a skin disease that most commonly affects areas bearing apocrine sweat glands or sebaceous glands, such as the underarms, under the breasts, inner thighs, groin and buttocks. Source: Wikipedia
Hidradenitis suppurativa.symptoms: Skin growth, Arm lump or mass, Groin mass, Lower body pain, Skin lesion, Skin swelling, Acne or pimples, Skin rash, Arm swelling, Arm pain, Skin on arm or hand looks infected, Lump or mass of breast
Hidradenitis suppurativa.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for hidradenitis suppurativa include age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = black and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get hidradenitis suppurativa.

Valley fever.description: Valley fever Also known as Coccidioidomycosis and Posada Wernicke Disease Coccidioidomycosis (/kRksjdiTjdomajkosjs/, kok-sid-oy-doh-my-KOH-sis), commonly known as "Valley fever", as well as "California fever", "Desert rheumatism", and "San Joaquin Valley fever") is a fungal disease caused by Coccidioides immitis or C. posadasii. It is endemic in certain parts of Arizona, California, Nevada, New Mexico, Texas, Utah and northern Mexico. Source: Wikipedia
Valley fever.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Joint pain, Fever, Ache all over, Hand or finger pain, Hip stiffness or tightness, Vulvar sore, Shoulder swelling, Back pain, Fatigue, Hurts to breath, Chills
Valley fever.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for valley fever include age 30-44 years, sex == male and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, race/ethnicity = hispanic and age 15-29 years almost never get valley fever.

Conjunctivitis due to bacteria.description: Conjunctivitis due to bacteria Also known as Bacterial Conjunctivitis and Purulent Conjunctivitis Conjunctivitis (also called pink eye or madras eye) is inflammation of the conjunctiva (the outermost layer of the eye and the inner surface of the eyelids). It is most commonly due to an infection (usually viral, but sometimes bacterial) or an allergic reaction. Source: Wikipedia
Conjunctivitis due to bacteria.symptoms: Symptoms of eye, Fever, Itchiness of eye, Nasal congestion, Cough, White discharge from eye, Abnormal appearing skin, Eye redness, Sore throat, Coryza, Ear pain, Pain in eye
tests: Other OR therapeutic nervous system procedures
Conjunctivitis due to bacteria.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for conjunctivitis due to bacteria include age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, race/ethnicity = black and age < 1 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years almost never get conjunctivitis due to bacteria.

Lewy body dementia.description: Lewy body dementia Also known as Lewy Body Disease Dementia with Lewy bodies (DLB), also known under a variety of other names including Lewy body dementia, diffuse Lewy body disease, cortical Lewy body disease, and senile dementia of Lewy type, is a type of dementia closely associated with both Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases. It is characterized anatomically by the presence of Lewy bodies, clumps of alpha-synuclein and ubiquitin protein in neurons, detectable in post mortem brain histology. Lewy body dementia affects 1.3 million individuals in the United States alone. Source: Wikipedia
Lewy body dementia.symptoms: Abnormal involuntary movements, Paresthesia, Loss of sensation, Rectal bleeding, Disturbance of memory, Hostile behavior, Dizziness, Delusions or hallucinations, Seizures, Problems with movement, Depressive or psychotic symptoms, Weakness
Lewy body dementia.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for lewy body dementia include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 30-44 years, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, age 15-29 years, and age < 1 years almost never get lewy body dementia.

Marfan syndrome.description: Marfan syndrome Marfan syndrome (also called Marfan's syndrome) is a genetic disorder of the connective tissue. People with Marfan tend to be unusually tall, with long limbs and long, thin fingers. Source: Wikipedia
Marfan syndrome.symptoms: Ache all over, Emotional symptoms, Shoulder pain, Skin swelling, Itching of the anus, Increased heart rate, Blood in stool, Focal weakness, Heartburn, Depression, Anxiety and nervousness, Stomach bloating
Marfan syndrome.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for marfan syndrome include age 5-14 years age 15-29 years. On the other hand, race/ethnicity = other, age 75+ years, and age 60-74 years almost never get marfan syndrome.

Multiple myeloma.description: Multiple myeloma Also known as Plasma Cell Myeloma, Plasma Cell Neoplasms, Kahler Disease, and Myelomatosis Multiple myeloma(from Greek myelo-, bone marrow), also known as plasma cell myeloma or Kahler's disease (after Otto Kahler), is a cancer of plasma cells, a type of white blood cell normally responsible for producing antibodies. In multiple myeloma, collections of abnormal plasma cells accumulate in the bone marrow, where they interfere with the production of normal blood cells. Most cases of myeloma also feature the production of a paraprotein an abnormal antibody which can cause kidney problems. Bone lesions and hypercalcemia (high calcium levels) are also often encountered. Source: Wikipedia
Multiple myeloma.symptoms: Impotence, Swollen abdomen, Symptoms of the face, Disturbance of memory, Muscle pain, Stiffness all over, Fatigue, Problems with movement, Weakness, Lip swelling, Hip lump or mass, Chills
Multiple myeloma.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for multiple myeloma include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, age 15-29 years, and age < 1 years almost never get multiple myeloma.

Stomach cancer.description: Stomach cancer Also known as Stomach Carcinoma, Carcinoma Of Stomach, and Gastric Carcinoma Stomach cancer, or gastric cancer, refers to cancer arising from any part of the stomach. Stomach cancer causes about 800,000 deaths worldwide per year. Prognosis is poor (5-year survival <5 to 15%) because most patients present with advanced disease. Source: Wikipedia
Stomach cancer.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Peripheral edema, Nausea, Burning abdominal pain, Difficulty in swallowing, Vomiting, Fluid retention, Fatigue, Constipation, Heartburn, Weakness, Diarrhea
Stomach cancer.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for stomach cancer include race/ethnicity = other, age 75+ years, sex == male and age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get stomach cancer.

Developmental disability.description: Developmental disability Also known as Child Development Disorder Developmental disability is a term used in the United States and Canada to describe lifelong disabilities attributable to mental or physical impairments, manifested prior to age 18. It is not synonymous with "developmental delay" which is often a consequence of a temporary illness or trauma during childhood. Source: Wikipedia
Developmental disability.symptoms: Difficulty speaking, Restlessness, Lack of growth, Hostile behavior, Temper problems, Fears and phobias, Delusions or hallucinations, Seizures, Excessive anger, Antisocial behavior, Obsessions and compulsions, Depressive or psychotic symptoms
tests: Ophthalmologic and otologic diagnosis and treatment
Psychological and psychiatric evaluation and therapy
Developmental disability.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for developmental disability include sex == male, age 5-14 years and age 1-4 years.

Acute stress reaction.description: Acute stress reaction Acute stress disorder (formerly called acute stress reaction, psychological shock, mental shock, or simply shock) is a psychological condition arising in response to a terrifying or traumatic event. It should not be confused with the unrelated circulatory condition of shock, or the concept of shock value. Source: Wikipedia
Acute stress reaction.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Abnormal involuntary movements, Headache, Burning abdominal pain, Dizziness, Chest tightness, Insomnia, Depression, Fatigue, Anxiety and nervousness, Depressive or psychotic symptoms, Sharp chest pain
tests: Psychological and psychiatric evaluation and therapy
Acute stress reaction.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for acute stress reaction include . On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get acute stress reaction.

Delirium.description: Delirium Also known as Acute Brain Syndrome Delirium, or acute confusional state, is a syndrome that presents as severe confusion and disorientation, developing with relatively rapid onset and fluctuating in intensity. It is a syndrome which occurs more frequently in people in their later years. Delirium represents an organically caused decline from a previously-attained baseline level of cognitive function. It is typified by fluctuating course, attentional deficits and generalized severe disorganization of behavior. It typically involves other cognitive deficits, changes in arousal (hyperactive, hypoactive, or mixed), perceptual deficits, altered sleep-wake cycle, and psychotic features such as hallucinations and delusions. Delirium itself is not a disease, but rather a clinical syndrome (a set of symptoms), which result from an underlying disease, from medications administered during treatment of that disease in a critical phase, from a new problem with mentation or from varying combinations of two or more of these factors. Source: Wikipedia
Delirium.symptoms: Abnormal involuntary movements, Difficulty speaking, Depression, Hysterical behavior, Hostile behavior, Disturbance of memory, Disturbance of smell or taste, Slurring words, Delusions or hallucinations, Focal weakness, Problems with movement, Depressive or psychotic symptoms
Delirium.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for delirium include age 75+ years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get delirium.

Callus.description: Callus Also known as Skin callus A callus (or callosity) is a toughened area of skin which has become relatively thick and hard in response to repeated friction, pressure, or other irritation. Rubbing that is too frequent or forceful will cause blisters rather than allow calluses to form. Since repeated contact is required, calluses are most often found on feet because of frequent walking. Calluses are generally not harmful, but may sometimes lead to other problems, such as skin ulceration or infection. Source: Wikipedia
Callus.symptoms: Skin growth, Foot or toe swelling, Skin lesion, Foot or toe pain, Acne or pimples, Skin swelling, Abnormal appearing skin, Skin rash, Itching of skin, Warts, Irregular appearing nails, Skin dryness, peeling, scaliness, or roughness
tests: Other diagnostic procedures on skin and subcutaneous tissue
Debridement of wound; infection or burn
Callus.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for callus include age 5-14 years.

Guillain Barre syndrome.description: Guillain Barre syndrome Also known as Aidp, Ascending Paralysis, Acute Infective Polyneuritis, Acute Idiopathic Polyneuritis, Landry's Paralysis, and Acute Inflammatory Demyelinating Polyradiculoneuropathy (AIDP) Guillain-Barre syndrome is a rare disorder that causes your immune system to attack your peripheral nervous system (PNS). The PNS nerves connect your brain and spinal cord with the rest of your body. Damage to these nerves makes it hard for them to transmit signals. As a result, your muscles have trouble responding to your brain. No one knows what causes the syndrome. Sometimes it is triggered by an infection, surgery or a vaccination. The first symptom is usually weakness or a tingling feeling in your legs. The feeling can spread to your upper body. In severe cases, you become almost paralyzed. This is life-threatening. You might need a respirator to breathe. Symptoms usually worsen over a period of weeks, then stabilize. Most people recover. Recovery can take a few weeks to a few years. Treatment options during the symptom period include medicines or a procedure called plasma exchange. NIH: National Institute of Neurological Disorders and Stroke Source: MedlinePlus,Patients with guillain barre syndrome often receive urinalysis, magnetic resonance imaging, other therapeutic procedures, physical therapy exercises, human papillomavirus dna detection, echocardiography, chlamydia test and insertion of catheter into urinary bladder .
Guillain Barre syndrome.symptoms: Ache all over, Hand or finger pain, Fever, Difficulty speaking, Facial pain, Paresthesia, Loss of sensation, Leg pain, Problems with movement, Leg weakness, Dizziness, Weakness
tests: Insertion of catheter into urinary bladder
Guillain Barre syndrome.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for guillain barre syndrome include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years almost never get guillain barre syndrome.

Lumbago.description: Lumbago Also known as Chronic Low Back Pain Nonspecific low back pain or lumbago /lmbejao/ is a common musculoskeletal disorder affecting 80% of people at some point in their lives. In the United States it is the most common cause of job-related disability, a leading contributor to missed work, and the second most common neurological ailment only headache is more common. It can be either acute, subacute or chronic in duration. With conservative measures, the symptoms of low back pain typically show significant improvement within a few weeks from onset. Source: Wikipedia
Lumbago.symptoms: Low back cramps or spasms, Back cramps or spasms, Lower body pain, Back pain, Side pain, Neck pain, Low back pain, Muscle pain, Low back stiffness or tightness, Leg pain, Hip pain
tests: Physical therapy exercises; manipulation; and other procedures
Insertion of catheter or spinal stimulator and injection into spinal canal
Lumbago.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for lumbago include age 30-44 years age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get lumbago.

Deviated nasal septum.description: Deviated nasal septum Nasal septum deviation is a common physical disorder of the nose, involving a displacement of the nasal septum. Source: Wikipedia
Deviated nasal septum.symptoms: Painful sinuses, Abnormal breathing sounds, Headache, Frontal headache, Facial pain, Nasal congestion, Plugged feeling in ear, Apnea, Nosebleed, Difficulty breathing, Sore throat, Allergic reaction

Diagnostic procedures on nose; mouth and pharynx
Deviated nasal septum.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for deviated nasal septum include age 30-44 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get deviated nasal septum.

Hemangioma.description: Hemangioma Also known as Angioma A hemangioma is a benign, and usually a self-involuting tumor, (swelling or growth) of the endothelial cells that line blood vessels and is characterised by increased number of normal or abnormal vessels filled with blood. It usually appears during the first weeks of life and generally resolves by age 10. In more severe cases hemangiomas may leave residual tissue damage. In infancy, it is the most common tumor. The word "hemangioma" comes from the Greek haema- (), "blood"; angeio (), "vessel"; -oma (-), "tumor". Source: Wikipedia
Hemangioma.symptoms: Skin moles, Skin growth, Lymphedema, Skin lesion, Skin swelling, Abnormal appearing skin, Irregular appearing scalp, Warts, Irregular appearing nails, Lip swelling, Skin irritation, Skin dryness, peeling, scaliness, or roughness
tests: Other diagnostic procedures on skin and subcutaneous tissue
Hemangioma.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for hemangioma include age < 1 years.

Patau syndrome.description: Patau syndrome Also known as Trisomy 13 Syndrome Patau syndrome /pta/ is a syndrome caused by a chromosomal abnormality, in which some or all of the cells of the body contain extra genetic material from chromosome 13. This can occur either because each cell contains a full extra copy of chromosome 13 (a disorder known as trisomy 13 or trisomy D), or because each cell contains an extra partial copy of the chromosome (i.e., Robertsonian translocation) or because of mosaic Patau syndrome. Full trisomy 13 is caused by nondisjunction of chromosomes during meiosis (the mosaic form is caused by nondisjunction during mitosis). The extra genetic material from chromosome 13 disrupts the normal course of development, causing multiple and complex organ defects. Like all nondisjunction conditions (such as Down syndrome and Edwards syndrome), the risk of this syndrome in the offspring increases with maternal age at pregnancy, with about 31 years being the average. Patau syndrome affects somewhere between 1 in 10,000 and 1 in 21,700 live births. Source: Wikipedia
Patau syndrome.symptoms: Vulvar sore, Bedwetting, Pelvic pressure, Joint stiffness or tightness, Shoulder swelling, Shoulder cramps or spasms, Knee lump or mass, Eye strain, Excessive growth, Loss of sex drive, Neck cramps or spasms, Nailbiting
Patau syndrome.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for patau syndrome include age 60-74 years, age 15-29 years and race/ethnicity = white.

Peripheral arterial disease.description: Peripheral arterial disease Peripheral vascular disease (PVD), commonly referred to as peripheral artery disease (PAD) or peripheral artery occlusive disease (PAOD) or peripheral obliterative arteriopathy, refers to the obstruction of large arteries not within the coronary, aortic arch vasculature, or brain. PVD can result from atherosclerosis, inflammatory processes leading to stenosis, an embolism, or thrombus formation. It causes either acute or chronic ischemia (lack of blood supply). Often PVD is a term used to refer to atherosclerotic blockages found in the lower extremity. Source: Wikipedia
Peripheral arterial disease.symptoms: Lymphedema, Leg cramps or spasms, Skin lesion, Foot or toe pain, Hemoptysis, Symptoms of the kidneys, Leg pain, Feeling cold, Poor circulation
tests: Debridement of wound; infection or burn
Peripheral arterial disease.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for peripheral arterial disease include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, age 15-29 years, and age < 1 years almost never get peripheral arterial disease.

Chronic back pain.description: Chronic back pain Back pain is pain felt in the back that usually originates from the muscles, nerves, bones, joints or other structures in the spine. Source: Wikipedia
Chronic back pain.symptoms: Back stiffness or tightness, Back cramps or spasms, Lower body pain, Back pain, Loss of sensation, Side pain, Neck pain, Low back pain, Leg pain, Hip pain, Groin pain, Leg weakness
tests: Insertion of catheter or spinal stimulator and injection into spinal canal
Chronic back pain.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for chronic back pain include age 30-44 years age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get chronic back pain.

Heart failure.description: Heart failure Also known as Weak Heart, Heart Weakness, Myocardial Failure, and Cardiac Insufficiency Heart failure (HF), often called congestive heart failure (CHF) or congestive cardiac failure (CCF), occurs when the heart is unable to provide sufficient pump action to maintain blood flow to meet the needs of the body. Heart failure can cause a number of symptoms including shortness of breath, leg swelling, and exercise intolerance. The condition is diagnosed by patient physical examination and confirmed with echocardiography. Blood tests help to determine the cause. Treatment depends on severity and cause of heart failure. In a chronic patient already in a stable situation, treatment commonly consists of lifestyle measures such as smoking cessation, light exercise, dietary changes, and medications. Sometimes, depending from etiology, it is treated with implanted devices (pacemakers or ventricular assist devices) and occasionally a heart transplant is required. Source: Wikipedia
Heart failure.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Hurts to breath, Cough, Chest tightness, Palpitations, Weight gain, Fluid retention, Peripheral edema, Difficulty breathing, Leg swelling, Weakness, Sharp chest pain
Heart failure.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for heart failure include age 75+ years age 60-74 years.

Conjunctivitis.description: Conjunctivitis Also known as Conjunctiva Inflammation Conjunctivitis (also called pink eye or madras eye) is inflammation of the conjunctiva (the outermost layer of the eye and the inner surface of the eyelids). It is most commonly due to an infection (usually viral, but sometimes bacterial) or an allergic reaction. Source: Wikipedia
Conjunctivitis.symptoms: Symptoms of eye, Fever, Itchiness of eye, Nasal congestion, Swollen eye, Cough, Lacrimation, White discharge from eye, Eye redness, Sore throat, Coryza, Pain in eye
tests: Other extraocular muscle and orbit therapeutic procedures
Other non-OR therapeutic procedures on nose; mouth and pharynx
Other OR therapeutic nervous system procedures
Conjunctivitis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for conjunctivitis include age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years.

Herniated disk.description: Herniated disk Also known as Slipped Disk and Prolapsed Disk A Spinal disc herniation (prolapsus disci intervertebralis) is a medical condition affecting the spine due to trauma, lifting injuries, or idiopathic (unknown) causes, in which a tear in the outer, fibrous ring (annulus fibrosus) of an intervertebral disc (discus intervertebralis) allows the soft, central portion (nucleus pulposus) to bulge out beyond the damaged outer rings. Tears are almost always postero-lateral in nature owing to the presence of the posterior longitudinal ligament in the spinal canal. This tear in the disc ring may result in the release of inflammatory chemical mediators which may directly cause severe pain, even in the absence of nerve root compression. Source: Wikipedia
Herniated disk.symptoms: Shoulder pain, Arm weakness, Lower body pain, Back pain, Loss of sensation, Paresthesia, Neck pain, Low back pain, Leg pain, Hip pain, Arm pain, Leg weakness
tests: Insertion of catheter or spinal stimulator and injection into spinal canal
Herniated disk.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for herniated disk include age 30-44 years age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get herniated disk.

Rhabdomyolysis.description: Rhabdomyolysis Rhabdomyolysis /rbdumajRlhsjs/ is a condition in which damaged skeletal muscle tissue (Greek: rhabdo- striped myo- muscle) breaks down (Greek: lysis) rapidly. Breakdown products of damaged muscle cells are released into the bloodstream; some of these, such as the protein myoglobin, are harmful to the kidneys and may lead to kidney failure. The severity of the symptoms, which may include muscle pains, vomiting and confusion, depends on the extent of muscle damage and whether kidney failure develops. The muscle damage may be caused by physical factors (e.g. crush injury, strenuous exercise), medications, drug abuse, and infections. Some people have a hereditary muscle condition that increases the risk of rhabdomyolysis. The diagnosis is usually made with blood tests and urinalysis. The mainstay of treatment is generous quantities of intravenous fluids, but may include dialysis or hemofiltration in more severe cases. Source: Wikipedia
Rhabdomyolysis.symptoms: Peripheral edema, Ache all over, Headache, Hoarse voice, Loss of sensation, Vomiting, Leg pain, Fatigue, Arm pain, Depressive or psychotic symptoms, Weakness, Sharp chest pain
Rhabdomyolysis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for rhabdomyolysis include age 75+ years. On the other hand, race/ethnicity = other, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get rhabdomyolysis.

Breast infection (mastitis).description: Breast infection (mastitis) Also known as Mastitis and Breast Inflammation Mastitis is the inflammation of breast tissue. S. aureus is the most common etiological organism responsible, but S. epidermidis and streptococci are occasionally isolated as well. Source: Wikipedia
Breast infection (mastitis).symptoms: Pain or soreness of breast, Long menstrual periods, Fever, Skin growth, Recent pregnancy, Postpartum problems of the breast, Abnormal appearing skin, Bleeding or discharge from nipple, Bones are painful, Mouth dryness, Lump or mass of breast, Chills
Breast infection (mastitis).riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for breast infection (mastitis) include age 30-44 years, sex == female and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years almost never get breast infection (mastitis).

Abdominal aortic aneurysm.description: Abdominal aortic aneurysm Abdominal aortic aneurysm (also known as AAA, pronounced "triple-a") is a localized dilatation (ballooning) of the abdominal aorta exceeding the normal diameter by more than 50 percent, and is the most common form of aortic aneurysm. Approximately 90 percent of abdominal aortic aneurysms occur infrarenally (below the kidneys), but they can also occur pararenally (at the level of the kidneys) or suprarenally (above the kidneys). Such aneurysms can extend to include one or both of the iliac arteries in the pelvis. Source: Wikipedia
Abdominal aortic aneurysm.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Shortness of breath, Swollen abdomen, Burning abdominal pain, Retention of urine, Pallor, Back pain, Side pain, Arm swelling, Palpitations, Groin pain, Sharp chest pain
Abdominal aortic aneurysm.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for abdominal aortic aneurysm include age 75+ years, sex == male and age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, age 15-29 years, and age < 1 years almost never get abdominal aortic aneurysm.

Pulmonary embolism.description: Pulmonary embolism Also known as Lung Embolism Pulmonary embolism (PE) is a blockage of the main artery of the lung or one of its branches by a substance that has travelled from elsewhere in the body through the bloodstream (embolism). PE most commonly results from deep vein thrombosis (a blood clot in the deep veins of the legs or pelvis) that breaks off and migrates to the lung, a process termed venous thromboembolism (VTE). A small proportion of cases are due to the embolization of air, fat, talc in drugs of intravenous drug abusers or amniotic fluid. The obstruction of the blood flow through the lungs and the resultant pressure on the right ventricle of the heart lead to the symptoms and signs of PE. The risk of PE is increased in various situations, such as cancer or prolonged bed rest. Source: Wikipedia
Pulmonary embolism.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Sweating, Back pain, Cough, Side pain, Hemoptysis, Chest tightness, Leg pain, Difficulty breathing, Leg swelling, Weakness, Sharp chest pain
Pulmonary embolism.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for pulmonary embolism include age 75+ years, age 60-74 years and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get pulmonary embolism.

Conduct disorder.description: Conduct disorder Conduct disorder is a psychological disorder diagnosed in childhood or adolescence that presents itself through a repetitive and persistent pattern of behavior in which the basic rights of others or major age-appropriate norms are violated. These behaviors are often referred to as "antisocial behaviors." Indeed, the disorder is often seen as the precursor to antisocial personality disorder. Source: Wikipedia
Conduct disorder.symptoms: Fainting, Restlessness, Abusing alcohol, Hysterical behavior, Hostile behavior, Lack of growth, Temper problems, Delusions or hallucinations, Seizures, Excessive anger, Depression, Depressive or psychotic symptoms
tests: Ophthalmologic and otologic diagnosis and treatment
Psychological and psychiatric evaluation and therapy
Conduct disorder.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for conduct disorder include sex == male, age 5-14 years and age 1-4 years.

Air embolism.description: Air embolism Also known as Gas Embolism An air embolism, or more generally gas embolism, is a pathological condition caused by a gas bubble, or bubbles, in a vascular system although an embolism in a medical context refers to any large moving mass or defect in the blood stream. Air embolisms may also occur in the xylem of vascular plants, especially when suffering from water stress. Source: Wikipedia
Air embolism.symptoms: Pain or soreness of breast, Pain during pregnancy, Joint stiffness or tightness, Facial pain, Shoulder cramps or spasms, Knee lump or mass, Wrist pain, Excessive anger, Ankle pain, Fatigue, Excessive urination at night, Pain in eye
Air embolism.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for air embolism include race/ethnicity = other, age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = hispanic, age 75+ years, age 60-74 years, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, race/ethnicity = black, age 15-29 years, age 45-59 years and age < 1 years.

Mastectomy.description: Mastectomy Also known as Surgical Removal Of The Breast Mastectomy ( Greek word: breast + removal ) is the medical term for the surgical removal of one or both breasts, partially or completely. Mastectomy is usually done to treat breast cancer; in some cases, women and some men believed to be at high risk of breast cancer have the operation prophylactically, that is, to prevent cancer rather than treat it. It is also the medical procedure carried out to remove breast cancer tissue in males. Alternatively, certain patients can choose to have a wide local excision, also known as a lumpectomy, an operation in which a small volume of breast tissue containing the tumor and some surrounding healthy tissue is removed to conserve the breast. Both mastectomy and lumpectomy are what are referred to as "local therapies" for breast cancer, targeting the area of the tumor, as opposed to systemic therapies such as chemotherapy, hormonal therapy, or immunotherapy. Source: Wikipedia
Mastectomy.symptoms: Pain or soreness of breast, Problems with shape or size of breast, Burning chest pain, Regurgitation, Skin swelling, Leg cramps or spasms, Smoking problems, Swollen lymph nodes, Hand or finger stiffness or tightness, Heartburn, Lump or mass of breast, Arm stiffness or tightness
Mastectomy.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for mastectomy include age 75+ years, age 60-74 years, sex == female and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, sex == male, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get mastectomy.

Epididymitis.description: Epididymitis Epididymitis ( [pjdjdYmajtjs, p'--d-d'Y-m+'t-s, EP-Y-DID-Y-MEYE-tis) is a medical condition characterized by discomfort or pain in of the epididymis, a curved structure at the back of the testicle in which sperm matures and is stored. Epididymitis is usually characterized as either acute or chronic: if acute, the onset of testicular pain is often accompanied by inflammation, redness, and warmth in the scrotum; if chronic, pain may be the only symptom. In either form, testicular pain in one or both testes can vary from mild to severe, and one or both epididymides may noticeably swell and/ or harden. The pain is often cyclical and may last from less than an hour to several days. Source: Wikipedia
Epididymitis.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Pain in testicles, Swollen abdomen, Blood in urine, Lower abdominal pain, Retention of urine, Painful urination, Lower body pain, Side pain, Mass in scrotum, Groin pain, Swelling of scrotum
tests: Prostate specific antigen measurement (Prostate specific antigen test)
Insertion of catheter into urinary bladder
Epididymitis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for epididymitis include age 30-44 years sex == male. On the other hand, sex == female almost never get epididymitis.

Premature rupture of amniotic membrane.description: Premature rupture of amniotic membrane Also known as PROM A prom (in the United States) is a formal social event usually a dance generally held near the end of the last two years of high school. Source: Wikipedia
Premature rupture of amniotic membrane.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Uterine contractions, Fever, Low back weakness, Spotting or bleeding during pregnancy, Back weakness, Weight gain, Seizures, Abnormal size or shape of ear, Muscle swelling, Coryza, Elbow weakness
Premature rupture of amniotic membrane.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for premature rupture of amniotic membrane include age 30-44 years, sex == female, race/ethnicity = black and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, sex == male, age 60-74 years, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age 45-59 years almost never get premature rupture of amniotic membrane.

Molluscum contagiosum.description: Molluscum contagiosum Also known as Water Wart Molluscum contagiosum (MC) is a viral infection of the skin or occasionally of the mucous membranes, sometimes called water warts. It is caused by a DNA poxvirus called the molluscum contagiosum virus (MCV). MCV has no nonhuman-animal reservoir (infecting only humans). There are four types of MCV, MCV-1 to -4; MCV-1 is the most prevalent and MCV-2 is seen usually in adults. The virus that causes molluscum is spread from person to person by touching the affected skin. The virus may also be spread by touching a surface with the virus on it, such as a towel, clothing, or toys. Once someone has the virus, the bumps can spread to other parts of their body by touching or scratching a bump and then touching another part of the body. Molluscum can be spread from one person to another by sexual contact. This common viral disease has a higher incidence in children, sexually active adults, and those who are immunodeficient, and the infection is most common in children aged one to ten years old. MC can affect any area of the skin but is most common on the trunk of the body, arms, groin, and legs. It is spread through direct contact or shared items such as clothing or towels. There is evidence that molluscum infections have globally been on the rise since 1966, but these infections are not routinely monitored because they are seldom serious and routinely disappear without treatment. The virus commonly spreads through skin-to-skin contact. This includes sexual contact or touching or scratching the bumps and then touching the skin. Handling objects that have the virus on them (fomites), such as a towel, can also result in infection. The virus can spread from one part of the body to another or to other people. The virus can be spread among children at day care or at school. Molluscum contagiosum is contagious until the bumps are gone. Some growths may remain for up to 4 years if not treated. Source: Wikipedia
Molluscum contagiosum.symptoms: Bumps on penis, Skin growth, Arm lump or mass, Skin swelling, Skin lesion, Acne or pimples, Knee lump or mass, Skin rash, Abnormal appearing skin, Itching of skin, Warts, Skin dryness, peeling, scaliness, or roughness
Molluscum contagiosum.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for molluscum contagiosum include race/ethnicity = other, age 5-14 years and age 1-4 years. On the other hand, age 60-74 years almost never get molluscum contagiosum.

Necrotizing fasciitis.description: Necrotizing fasciitis Also known as Necrotizing Cellulitis, Necrotizing Myositis, and Streptococcal Gangrene Necrotizing fasciitis (/n[krYtajzjK fiajtjs/ or /fs-/) or NF, commonly known as flesh-eating disease or flesh-eating bacteria syndrome, is a rare infection of the deeper layers of skin and subcutaneous tissues, easily spreading across the fascial plane within the subcutaneous tissue. Source: Wikipedia
Necrotizing fasciitis.symptoms: Hand or finger pain, Vaginal pain, Skin lesion, Excessive growth, Abnormal appearing skin, Arm swelling, Leg pain, Hip pain, Elbow cramps or spasms, Peripheral edema, Leg swelling, Elbow weakness
Necrotizing fasciitis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for necrotizing fasciitis include age 30-44 years age < 1 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, age 5-14 years, and race/ethnicity = black almost never get necrotizing fasciitis.

Benign vaginal discharge (leukorrhea).description: Benign vaginal discharge (leukorrhea) Also known as Cervical Discharge Benign vaginal discharge (leukorrhea) is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Benign vaginal discharge (leukorrhea).symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Vaginal discharge, Vaginal pain, Pain during pregnancy, Frequent urination, Burning abdominal pain, Painful urination, Vaginal redness, Pelvic pain, Suprapubic pain, Problems during pregnancy, Vaginal itching
Benign vaginal discharge (leukorrhea).riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for benign vaginal discharge (leukorrhea) include age 30-44 years, sex == female, race/ethnicity = black and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, sex == male and age < 1 years almost never get benign vaginal discharge (leukorrhea).

Bladder obstruction.description: Bladder obstruction Bladder obstruction is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Bladder obstruction.symptoms: Impotence, Frequent urination, Symptoms of prostate, Blood in urine, Bedwetting, Retention of urine, Involuntary urination, Suprapubic pain, Symptoms of bladder, Excessive urination at night, Peripheral edema, Hesitancy
tests: Prostate specific antigen measurement (Prostate specific antigen test)
Insertion of catheter into urinary bladder
Bladder obstruction.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for bladder obstruction include age 75+ years, sex == male and age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, age 15-29 years, and age < 1 years almost never get bladder obstruction.

Melanoma.description: Melanoma Also known as Malignant Melanoma, Cutaneous Melanoma, Melanocarcinoma, Melanosarcoma, and Nevocarcinoma Melanoma i/m[lYnomY/ (from Greek melas, "dark") is a malignant tumor of melanocytes. Melanocytes produce the dark pigment, melanin, which is responsible for the color of skin. These cells predominantly occur in skin, but are also found in other parts of the body, including the bowel and the eye (see uveal melanoma). Melanoma can originate in any part of the body that contains melanocytes. Source: Wikipedia
Melanoma.symptoms: Skin moles, Skin growth, Skin lesion, Skin swelling, Abnormal appearing skin, Irregular appearing scalp, Swollen lymph nodes, Itchy eyelid, Skin on arm or hand looks infected, Back mass or lump, Skin irritation, Skin dryness, peeling, scaliness, or roughness
tests: Other diagnostic procedures on skin and subcutaneous tissue
Melanoma.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for melanoma include age 75+ years, age 60-74 years, age 45-59 years and race/ethnicity = white. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get melanoma.

Cervical disorder.description: Cervical disorder Also known as Cervical Disease and Cervix Disease The cervix is the lower part of the uterus, the place where a baby grows during pregnancy. The cervix has a small opening that expands during childbirth. It also allows menstrual blood to leave a woman s body. Your healthcare provider may perform a Pap test during your health checkup to look for changes to the cells of the cervix, including cervical cancer. Other problems with the cervix include: Cervicitis: inflammation of the cervix Cervical incompetence: widening of the cervical opening during pregnancy long before the baby is due Cervical polyps and cysts: abnormal growths on the cervix Source: MedlinePlus,Patients with cervical disorder often receive pelvis exam, examination of breast, biopsy, excision, ultrasonography, other diagnostic procedures; female organs, mammography and pap smear .
Cervical disorder.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Vaginal discharge, Vaginal pain, Painful menstruation, Painful urination, Vaginal bleeding after menopause, Pelvic pain, Hot flashes, Focal weakness, Vaginal itching, Intermenstrual bleeding, Pain during intercourse
Cervical disorder.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for cervical disorder include race/ethnicity = other, sex == female and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, sex == male, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get cervical disorder.

Laryngitis.description: Laryngitis Laryngitis is an inflammation of the larynx. It causes hoarse voice or temporary complete loss of the voice because of irritation to the vocal folds (vocal cords). Dysphonia is the medical term for a vocal disorder, of which laryngitis is one cause. Source: Wikipedia
Laryngitis.symptoms: Fever, Difficulty speaking, Nasal congestion, Difficulty in swallowing, Cough, Allergic reaction, Sinus congestion, Sore throat, Throat feels tight, Coryza, Ear pain, Hoarse voice
tests: Injections and aspirations of muscles; tendons; bursa; joints and soft tissue
Other diagnostic radiology and related techniques
Other OR upper GI therapeutic procedures
Laryngitis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for laryngitis include .

Dyshidrosis.description: Dyshidrosis Also known as Sweat Gland Disorder and Sweat Gland Disease Dyshidrosis (also known as "acute vesiculobullous hand eczema," "cheiropompholyx," "dyshidrotic eczema," "pompholyx," and "podopompholyx") is a skin condition that is characterized by small blisters on the hands or feet. It is an acute, chronic, or recurrent dermatosis of the fingers, palms, and soles, characterized by a sudden onset of many deep-seated pruritic, clear vesicles; later, scaling, fissures and lichenification occur. Recurrence is common and for many can be chronic. Incidence/prevalence is said to be 1/5,000 in the United States. However, many cases of eczema are diagnosed as garden-variety atopic eczema without further investigation, so it is possible that this figure is misleading. Source: Wikipedia
Dyshidrosis.symptoms: Dry or flaky scalp, Frequent urination, Foot or toe lump or mass, Skin lesion, Back pain, Acne or pimples, Skin on leg or foot looks infected, Abnormal appearing skin, Skin rash, Itching of skin, Ankle pain, Skin dryness, peeling, scaliness, or roughness
Dyshidrosis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for dyshidrosis include age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get dyshidrosis.

Poisoning due to opioids.description: Poisoning due to opioids Poisoning due to opioids is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Poisoning due to opioids.symptoms: Sleepiness, Drug abuse, Difficulty speaking, Arm weakness, Abusing alcohol, Vomiting, Slurring words, Arm pain, Problems with movement, Dizziness, Feeling ill, Depressive or psychotic symptoms
Poisoning due to opioids.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for poisoning due to opioids include sex == male age 15-29 years. On the other hand, race/ethnicity = other, age 75+ years, age 5-14 years, and age < 1 years almost never get poisoning due to opioids.

Diaper rash.description: Diaper rash Also known as Diaper Dermatitis, Nappy Rash, and Napkin Dermatitis Irritant diaper dermatitis, also known as "diaper dermatitis" and "napkin dermatitis":80 and commonly known as diaper rash (U.S.) or nappy rash (UK, AUS), is a generic term applied to skin rashes in the diaper area that are caused by various skin disorders and/or irritants. Source: Wikipedia
Diaper rash.symptoms: Diaper rash, Fever, Redness in ear, Irritable infant, Nasal congestion, Cough, Vomiting, Skin rash, Temper problems, Pulling at ears, Blood in stool, Diarrhea
Diaper rash.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for diaper rash include race/ethnicity = hispanic, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years. On the other hand, age 30-44 years, age 60-74 years, age 15-29 years, and age 45-59 years almost never get diaper rash.

Lichen planus.description: Lichen planus Also known as Lichen Ruber Planus Lichen planus is a chronic mucocutaneous disease that affects the skin, tongue, and oral mucosa. The disease presents itself in the form of papules, lesions, or rashes. Lichen planus does not involve lichens, the fungus/algae symbionts that often grow on tree trunks; the name refers to the dry and undulating, "lichen-like" appearance of affected skin. It is sometimes associated with oxidative stress, certain medications and diseases, however the underlying pathology is currently unknown. Source: Wikipedia
Lichen planus.symptoms: Skin moles, Skin growth, Difficulty speaking, Itchy scalp, Skin lesion, Mouth ulcer, Acne or pimples, Skin rash, Abnormal appearing skin, Irregular appearing scalp, Itching of skin, Skin dryness, peeling, scaliness, or roughness
tests: Other OR therapeutic procedures on nose; mouth and pharynx
Lichen planus.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for lichen planus include age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get lichen planus.

Gastroduodenal ulcer.description: Gastroduodenal ulcer Also known as PUD and Peptic Ulcer Disease A peptic ulcer, also known as peptic ulcer disease (PUD), is the most common ulcer of an area of the gastrointestinal tract that is usually acidic and thus extremely painful. It is defined as mucosal erosions equal to or greater than 0.5 cm. As many as 70 90% of such ulcers are associated with Helicobacter pylori, a helical-shaped bacterium that lives in the acidic environment of the stomach; however, only 40% of those cases go to a doctor. Ulcers can also be caused or worsened by drugs such as aspirin, ibuprofen, and other NSAIDs. Source: Wikipedia
Gastroduodenal ulcer.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Changes in stool appearance, Burning abdominal pain, Nausea, Headache, Vomiting, Blood in stool, Vomiting blood, Upper abdominal pain, Heartburn, Melena, Sharp chest pain
Gastroduodenal ulcer.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for gastroduodenal ulcer include age 75+ years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get gastroduodenal ulcer.

Inguinal hernia.description: Inguinal hernia An inguinal hernia /jKawhnYl h\rniY/ is a protrusion of abdominal-cavity contents through the inguinal canal. They are very common (lifetime risk 27% for men, 3% for women). Though their repair is one of the most frequently performed surgical operations, elective surgery is no longer recommended in minimally symptomatic cases, due to the low risk of incarceration (<0.2% per year) and the significant risk (10 12%) of post herniorraphy pain syndrome. Source: Wikipedia
Inguinal hernia.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Ache all over, Pain in testicles, Swollen abdomen, Groin mass, Penis redness, Symptoms of the scrotum and testes, Mass in scrotum, Swelling of scrotum, Groin pain, Lower abdominal pain
tests: Prostate specific antigen measurement (Prostate specific antigen test)
Other OR therapeutic nervous system procedures
Inguinal hernia.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for inguinal hernia include sex == male.

Eczema.description: Eczema Also known as Eczematous Dermatitis Eczema or often referred to as atopic dermatitis (from Greek kzema, "to boil over") is a form of dermatitis, or inflammation of the epidermis (the outer layer of the skin). Source: Wikipedia
Eczema.symptoms: Skin lesion, Cough, Acne or pimples, Skin swelling, Abnormal appearing skin, Skin rash, Irregular appearing scalp, Itching of skin, Warts, Allergic reaction, Skin irritation, Skin dryness, peeling, scaliness, or roughness
tests: Other diagnostic procedures on skin and subcutaneous tissue
Eczema.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for eczema include age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, race/ethnicity = black and age < 1 years.

Asperger syndrome.description: Asperger syndrome Asperger syndrome (AS), also known as Asperger disorder (AD), is an autism spectrum disorder (ASD) that is characterized by significant difficulties in social interaction and nonverbal communication, alongside restricted and repetitive patterns of behavior and interests. It differs from other autism spectrum disorders by its relative preservation of linguistic and cognitive development. Although not required for diagnosis, physical clumsiness and atypical (peculiar, odd) use of language are frequently reported. Source: Wikipedia
Asperger syndrome.symptoms: Fainting, Lack of growth, Hostile behavior, Temper problems, Delusions or hallucinations, Excessive anger, Antisocial behavior, Nightmares, Depression, Anxiety and nervousness, Obsessions and compulsions, Depressive or psychotic symptoms
tests: Psychological and psychiatric evaluation and therapy
Asperger syndrome.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for asperger syndrome include sex == male age 5-14 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years and age < 1 years almost never get asperger syndrome.

Mucositis.description: Mucositis Also known as Mucosal Inflammation, Mucosity, and Mucitis Mucositis is the painful inflammation and ulceration of the mucous membranes lining the digestive tract, usually as an adverse effect of chemotherapy and radiotherapy treatment for cancer. Mucositis can occur anywhere along the gastrointestinal (GI) tract, but oral mucositis refers to the particular inflammation and ulceration that occurs in the mouth. Oral mucositis is a common and often debilitating complication of cancer treatment. Source: Wikipedia
Mucositis.symptoms: Fever, Irritable infant, Difficulty in swallowing, Mouth ulcer, Vomiting, Tongue pain, Mouth pain, Decreased appetite, Swollen tongue, Sore throat, Gum pain, Tongue lesions
Mucositis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for mucositis include race/ethnicity = other, race/ethnicity = hispanic, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years.

Paronychia.description: Paronychia In medicine, paronychia (/prYnjkiY/; Greek: : para-, around, onukh-, nail) is a nail disease that is an often-tender bacterial or fungal infection of the hand or foot where the nail and skin meet at the side or the base of a finger or toenail. The infection can start suddenly (acute paronychia) or gradually (chronic paronychia). Paronychia is commonly misapplied as a synonym for whitlow or felon. Source: Wikipedia
Paronychia.symptoms: Hand or finger pain, Hand or finger swelling, Foot or toe swelling, Skin dryness, peeling, scaliness, or roughness, Foot or toe pain, Skin on leg or foot looks infected, Abnormal appearing skin, Sinus congestion, Skin on arm or hand looks infected, Hand or finger lump or mass, Irregular appearing nails, Nailbiting
tests: Other non-OR therapeutic procedures on skin and breast
Other diagnostic procedures on musculoskeletal system
Paronychia.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for paronychia include age 5-14 years age 1-4 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get paronychia.

Open wound of the jaw.description: Open wound of the jaw Open wound of the jaw is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Open wound of the jaw.symptoms: Wrist swelling, Facial pain, Symptoms of the face, Mouth pain, Lip swelling
tests: Suture of skin and subcutaneous tissue
Open wound of the jaw.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for open wound of the jaw include age 5-14 years age 1-4 years.

White blood cell disease.description: White blood cell disease Also known as WBC Disease and Leukocyte Disorders White blood cells, or leukocytes (also spelled "leucocytes") are cells of the immune system involved in defending the body against both infectious disease and foreign materials. Five different and diverse types of leukocytes exist, but they are all produced and derived from a multipotent cell in the bone marrow known as a hematopoietic stem cell. They live for about three to four days in the average human body. Leukocytes are found throughout the body, including the blood and lymphatic system. Source: Wikipedia
White blood cell disease.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Fever, Nausea, Chills, Cough, Vomiting, Mouth pain, Fluid retention, Fatigue, Heartburn, Weakness, Diarrhea
White blood cell disease.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for white blood cell disease include age 75+ years.

Kaposi sarcoma.description: Kaposi sarcoma Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is a tumor caused by Human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8), also known as Kaposi sarcoma-associated herpesvirus (KSHV). It was originally described by Moritz Kaposi (KA-pY-shi), a Hungarian dermatologist practicing at the University of Vienna in 1872. It became more widely known as one of the AIDS-defining illnesses in the 1980s. The viral cause for this cancer was discovered in 1994. Although KS is now well-established to be caused by a viral infection, there is widespread lack of awareness of this even among persons at risk for KSHV/HHV-8 infection. Source: Wikipedia
Kaposi sarcoma.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Low back weakness, Skin lesion, Cough, Foot or toe pain, Excessive growth, Leg pain, Elbow cramps or spasms, Underweight, Depression, Lip swelling, Elbow weakness
Kaposi sarcoma.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for kaposi sarcoma include race/ethnicity = other, age 30-44 years, sex == male and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 60-74 years, age 5-14 years, and sex == female almost never get kaposi sarcoma.

Spondylolisthesis.description: Spondylolisthesis Spondylolisthesis is the anterior or posterior displacement of a vertebra or the vertebral column in relation to the vertebrae below. The variant "listhesis," resulting from misdivision of this compound word, is sometimes applied in conjunction with scoliosis. These "slips" (aka "step-offs") occur most commonly in the lumbar spine. Spondylolysis (a defect or fracture of the pars interarticularis of the vertebral arch) is the most common cause of spondylolisthesis. Source: Wikipedia
Spondylolisthesis.symptoms: Pain or soreness of breast, Leg cramps or spasms, Lower body pain, Back pain, Loss of sensation, Paresthesia, Neck pain, Low back pain, Leg pain, Hip pain, Problems with movement, Leg weakness
tests: Insertion of catheter or spinal stimulator and injection into spinal canal
Spondylolisthesis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for spondylolisthesis include age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get spondylolisthesis.

Pseudotumor cerebri.description: Pseudotumor cerebri Also known as Benign Intracranial Hypertension and Nonne's Syndrome Idiopathic intracranial hypertension (IIH), sometimes called by the older names benign intracranial hypertension (BIH) or pseudotumor cerebri (PTC), is a neurological disorder that is characterized by increased intracranial pressure (pressure around the brain) in the absence of a tumor or other diseases. The main symptoms are headache, nausea, and vomiting, as well as pulsatile tinnitus (buzzing in the ears synchronous with the pulse), double vision and other visual symptoms. If untreated, it may lead to swelling of the optic disc in the eye, which can progress to vision loss. Source: Wikipedia
Pseudotumor cerebri.symptoms: Abnormal involuntary movements, Headache, Regurgitation, Skin swelling, Spots or clouds in vision, Hot flashes, Slurring words, Fluid retention, Diminished hearing, Dizziness, Diminished vision, Pain in eye
tests: Other OR Rx procedures on respiratory system and mediastinum
Other therapeutic procedures on eyelids; conjunctiva; cornea
Pseudotumor cerebri.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for pseudotumor cerebri include age 30-44 years, sex == female and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, age 60-74 years, and age 1-4 years almost never get pseudotumor cerebri.

Conjunctivitis due to virus.description: Conjunctivitis due to virus Also known as Viral Conjunctivitis Conjunctivitis (also called pink eye or madras eye) is inflammation of the conjunctiva (the outermost layer of the eye and the inner surface of the eyelids). It is most commonly due to an infection (usually viral, but sometimes bacterial) or an allergic reaction. Source: Wikipedia
Conjunctivitis due to virus.symptoms: Fever, Itchiness of eye, Swollen eye, Nasal congestion, Cough, Lacrimation, White discharge from eye, Eye burns or stings, Eye redness, Coryza, Diminished vision, Pain in eye
tests: Referral to home health care service
Conjunctivitis due to virus.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for conjunctivitis due to virus include age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years.

Open wound of the nose.description: Open wound of the nose Open wound of the nose is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Open wound of the nose.symptoms: Sleepiness, Headache, Facial pain, Neck weakness, Diminished hearing, Nosebleed, Hot flashes, Sore in nose, Knee weakness
Open wound of the nose.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for open wound of the nose include age 75+ years age 1-4 years.

Head injury.description: Head injury Also known as Head Trauma, Craniocerebral Trauma, and Craniocerebral Injury Any injury that results in trauma to the scalp, skull, or brain can be classified as a head injury. The terms traumatic brain injury and head injury are often used interchangeably in medical literature. This broad classification includes neuronal injuries, hemorrhages, vascular injuries, cranial nerve injuries, and subdural hygromas, among many others. These classifications can be further categorized as open (penetrating) or closed head injuries. This depends on if the skull was broken or not. Because head injuries cover such a broad scope of injuries, there are many causes including accidents, falls, physical assault, or traffic accidents that can cause head injuries. Many of these are minor, but some can be severe enough to require hospitalization. Source: Wikipedia
Head injury.symptoms: Fainting, Headache, Facial pain, Double vision, Back pain, Ringing in ear, Redness in or around nose, Neck pain, Dizziness, Lip swelling
Head injury.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for head injury include age 5-14 years age 1-4 years.

Ascending cholangitis.description: Ascending cholangitis Ascending cholangitis or acute cholangitis (or sometimes cholangitis without a modifier - from Greek chol-, bile + ang-, vessel + itis-, inflammation) is an infection of the bile duct (cholangitis), usually caused by bacteria ascending from its junction with the duodenum (first part of the small intestine). It tends to occur if the bile duct is already partially obstructed by gallstones. Source: Wikipedia
Ascending cholangitis.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Shortness of breath, Fever, Nausea, Retention of urine, Painful urination, Vomiting, Stomach bloating, Upper abdominal pain, Vaginal itching, Jaundice, Diarrhea
Ascending cholangitis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for ascending cholangitis include race/ethnicity = other, age 75+ years and age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years and race/ethnicity = black almost never get ascending cholangitis.

Idiopathic irregular menstrual cycle.description: Idiopathic irregular menstrual cycle Idiopathic irregular menstrual cycle is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Idiopathic irregular menstrual cycle.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Long menstrual periods, Frequent menstruation, Painful menstruation, Cramps and spasms, Heavy menstrual flow, Pelvic pain, Infertility, Intermenstrual bleeding, Unpredictable menstruation, Blood clots during menstrual periods, Lower abdominal pain
Idiopathic irregular menstrual cycle.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for idiopathic irregular menstrual cycle include age 30-44 years, sex == female and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, sex == male, age 60-74 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get idiopathic irregular menstrual cycle.

Interstitial lung disease.description: Interstitial lung disease Also known as ILD Interstitial lung disease (ILD), also known as diffuse parenchymal lung disease (DPLD), refers to a group of lung diseases affecting the interstitium (the tissue and space around the air sacs of the lungs). It concerns alveolar epithelium, pulmonary capillary endothelium, basement membrane, perivascular and perilymphatic tissues. Source: Wikipedia
Interstitial lung disease.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Fever, Sleepiness, Abnormal breathing sounds, Headache, Nasal congestion, Cough, Difficulty breathing, Sore throat, Wheezing, Coryza, Ear pain
tests: Other non-OR therapeutic procedures on nose; mouth and pharynx
Other therapeutic procedures on eyelids; conjunctiva; cornea
Interstitial lung disease.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for interstitial lung disease include race/ethnicity = other, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years.

Mononeuritis.description: Mononeuritis Peripheral neuropathy is damage to nerves of the peripheral nervous system, which may be caused either by diseases of or trauma to the nerve or the side effects of systemic illness. Source: Wikipedia
Mononeuritis.symptoms: Hand or finger pain, Shoulder pain, Hand or finger weakness, Paresthesia, Loss of sensation, Foot or toe pain, Low back pain, Elbow pain, Wrist pain, Leg pain, Ankle pain, Arm pain
Mononeuritis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for mononeuritis include age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get mononeuritis.

Somatization disorder.description: Somatization disorder Also known as Briquet Syndrome Somatization disorder (also Briquet's syndrome or hysteria) is a somatoform disorder characterized by recurring, multiple, clinically significant complaints about pain, gastrointestinal, sexual and pseudoneurological symptoms. Those complaints must begin before the individual turns 30 years of age, and could last for several years, resulting in either treatment seeking behavior or significant treatment. Individuals with somatization disorder typically visit many doctors in pursuit of effective treatment. Somatization disorder also causes challenge and burden on the life of the caregivers or significant others of the patient. Source: Wikipedia
Somatization disorder.symptoms: Ache all over, Sharp abdominal pain, Fainting, Difficulty breathing, Weakness, Insomnia, Depression, Fatigue, Anxiety and nervousness, Dizziness, Feeling ill, Depressive or psychotic symptoms
Somatization disorder.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for somatization disorder include race/ethnicity = other, age 60-74 years and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get somatization disorder.

Hypovolemia.description: Hypovolemia Also known as Fluid Volume Deficit and Fluid volume depletion In physiology and medicine, hypovolemia (also hypovolaemia, oligemia or shock) is a state of decreased blood volume; more specifically, decrease in volume of blood plasma. It is thus the intravascular component of volume contraction (or loss of blood volume due to things such as hemorrhaging or dehydration), but, as it also is the most essential one, hypovolemia and volume contraction are sometimes used synonymously. Source: Wikipedia
Hypovolemia.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Fever, Fainting, Nausea, Headache, Vomiting, Fluid retention, Decreased appetite, Dizziness, Feeling ill, Weakness, Diarrhea
Hypovolemia.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for hypovolemia include age 75+ years.

Schizophrenia.description: Schizophrenia Schizophrenia (/skjtsufr[niY/ or /skjtsufriniY/) is a mental disorder characterized by a breakdown of thought processes and by a deficit of typical emotional responses. Common symptoms include auditory hallucinations, paranoid or bizarre delusions, or disorganized speech and thinking, and it is accompanied by significant social or occupational dysfunction. The onset of symptoms typically occurs in young adulthood, with a global lifetime prevalence of about 0.3 0.7%. Diagnosis is based on observed behavior and the patient's reported experiences. Source: Wikipedia
Schizophrenia.symptoms: Drug abuse, Hysterical behavior, Hostile behavior, Temper problems, Fears and phobias, Low self-esteem, Delusions or hallucinations, Excessive anger, Insomnia, Depression, Anxiety and nervousness, Depressive or psychotic symptoms
Schizophrenia.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for schizophrenia include age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = black and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get schizophrenia.

Knee ligament or meniscus tear.description: Knee ligament or meniscus tear Also known as Knee Derangement Knee ligament or meniscus tear is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Knee ligament or meniscus tear.symptoms: Knee swelling, Joint swelling, Leg stiffness or tightness, Knee lump or mass, Foot or toe cramps or spasms, Stiffness all over, Knee stiffness or tightness, Knee pain, Knee cramps or spasms, Knee weakness, Leg weakness
tests: Other non-OR therapeutic procedures on musculoskeletal system
Knee ligament or meniscus tear.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for knee ligament or meniscus tear include age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get knee ligament or meniscus tear.
