On the other hand, age 75+ years, sex == male, age 60-74 years, age 1-4 years, age 45-59 years, and age < 1 years almost never get spontaneous abortion.

Genital herpes.description: Genital herpes Also known as Genital HSV and Herpes Genitalis Herpes genitalis (or genital herpes) refers to a genital infection by Herpes simplex virus. Source: Wikipedia
Genital herpes.symptoms: Vaginal pain, Vaginal discharge, Recent pregnancy, Painful urination, Skin lesion, Pelvic pain, Suprapubic pain, Skin rash, Itching of skin, Vaginal itching, Groin pain, Skin pain
Genital herpes.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for genital herpes include age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = black and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get genital herpes.

Adjustment reaction.description: Adjustment reaction An adjustment disorder occurs when an individual is unable to adjust to or cope with a particular stressor, like a major life event. Since people with this disorder normally have symptoms that depressed people do, such as general loss of interest, feelings of hopelessness and crying, this disorder is also sometimes known as situational depression. Unlike major depression however, the disorder is caused by an outside stressor and generally resolves once the individual is able to adapt to the situation. One hypothesis for adjustment disorder is that it may represent a sub-threshold clinical syndrome. Source: Wikipedia
Adjustment reaction.symptoms: Restlessness, Hostile behavior, Temper problems, Low self-esteem, Fears and phobias, Delusions or hallucinations, Excessive anger, Nightmares, Insomnia, Depression, Anxiety and nervousness, Depressive or psychotic symptoms
tests: Psychological and psychiatric evaluation and therapy
Other OR upper GI therapeutic procedures
Adjustment reaction.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for adjustment reaction include age 5-14 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get adjustment reaction.

Gallstone.description: Gallstone Also known as Cholelithiasis, Gallstone Disease, and Calculus Of Gallbladder A gallstone is a crystalline concretion formed within the gallbladder by accretion of bile components. These calculi are formed in the gallbladder but may distally pass into other parts of the biliary tract such as the cystic duct, common bile duct, pancreatic duct, or the ampulla of Vater. Rarely, in cases of severe inflammation, gallstones may erode through the gallbladder into adherent bowel potentially causing an obstruction termed gallstone ileus. Source: Wikipedia
Gallstone.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Nausea, Burning abdominal pain, Sweating, Lower body pain, Back pain, Regurgitation, Side pain, Vomiting, Upper abdominal pain, Heartburn, Sharp chest pain
Gallstone.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for gallstone include . On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get gallstone.

Multiple sclerosis.description: Multiple sclerosis Also known as MS, Disseminated Sclerosis, and Insular Sclerosis Multiple sclerosis (MS), also known as disseminated sclerosis or encephalomyelitis disseminata, is a inflammatory disease in which myelin sheaths around axons of the brain and spinal cord are damaged, leading to loss of myelin and scarring. The cause is not clear, but the underlying mechanism is thought to be either destruction by the immune system or failure of the myelin-producing cells. These changes affect the ability of nerve cells to communicate resulting in a wide range of signs and symptoms. It is more common in women and the onset typically occurs in young adults. Source: Wikipedia
Multiple sclerosis.symptoms: Abnormal involuntary movements, Headache, Paresthesia, Loss of sensation, Disturbance of memory, Leg stiffness or tightness, Focal weakness, Fatigue, Problems with movement, Dizziness, Weakness, Leg weakness
tests: Debridement of wound; infection or burn
Referral to home health care service
Multiple sclerosis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for multiple sclerosis include age 30-44 years age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get multiple sclerosis.

Zenker diverticulum.description: Zenker diverticulum Also known as Pharyngeal Diverticulum, Pharyngoesophageal Diverticulum, and Hypopharyngeal Diverticulum In anatomy, Zenker's diverticulum, also pharyngoesophageal diverticulum, also pharyngeal pouch, also hypopharyngeal diverticulum, is a diverticulum of the mucosa of the pharynx, just above the cricopharyngeal muscle (i.e. above the upper sphincter of the esophagus). It is a false diverticulum (not involving all layers of the esophageal wall). Source: Wikipedia
Zenker diverticulum.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Feeling hot and cold, Regurgitation, Low back weakness, Difficulty in swallowing, Low back pain, Elbow weakness, Wrist weakness, Constipation, Nailbiting, Sore throat, Sharp chest pain
tests: Other diagnostic radiology and related techniques
Zenker diverticulum.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for zenker diverticulum include race/ethnicity = other, race/ethnicity = hispanic, age 75+ years, age 60-74 years and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 30-44 years, age 5-14 years, and age 15-29 years almost never get zenker diverticulum.

Fracture of the pelvis.description: Fracture of the pelvis Also known as Pelvic Fracture and Fractured Pelvis Pelvic fracture is a disruption of the bony structure of the pelvis, including the hip bone, sacrum and coccyx. The most common cause in elderly is a fall, but the most significant fractures involve high-energy forces such as a motor vehicle accident, cycling accidents, or a fall from significant height. Diagnosis is made on the basis of history, clinical features and special investigations usually including X-ray and CT. Because the pelvis cradles so many internal organs, pelvic fractures may produce significant internal bleeding which is invisible to the eye. Emergency treatment consists of advanced trauma life support management. After stabilisation, the pelvis may be surgically reconstructed. Source: Wikipedia
Fracture of the pelvis.symptoms: Ache all over, Difficulty speaking, Back pain, Side pain, Delusions or hallucinations, Leg pain, Hip pain, Groin pain, Problems with movement, Bones are painful, Focal weakness, Knee pain
Fracture of the pelvis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for fracture of the pelvis include age 75+ years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get fracture of the pelvis.

Pneumoconiosis.description: Pneumoconiosis Pneumoconiosis is an occupational lung disease and a restrictive lung disease caused by the inhalation of dust, often in mines. Source: Wikipedia
Pneumoconiosis.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Fever, Nasal congestion, Cough, Vomiting, Dizziness, Chest tightness, Insomnia, Coughing up sputum, Difficulty breathing, Sore throat, Wheezing
Pneumoconiosis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for pneumoconiosis include age 30-44 years age 1-4 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years almost never get pneumoconiosis.

Hyperlipidemia.description: Hyperlipidemia Also known as Lipidemia and Excessive Fat In The Blood Hyperlipidemia, hyperlipoproteinemia, or hyperlipidaemia (British English) involves abnormally elevated levels of any or all lipids and/or lipoproteins in the blood. It is the most common form of dyslipidemia (which also includes any decreased lipid levels). Source: Wikipedia
Hyperlipidemia.symptoms: Lymphedema, Leg cramps or spasms, Smoking problems, Weight gain, Sharp chest pain
tests: Prostate specific antigen measurement (Prostate specific antigen test)
Hyperlipidemia.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for hyperlipidemia include age 75+ years, age 60-74 years and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get hyperlipidemia.

Ulcerative colitis.description: Ulcerative colitis Ulcerative colitis (Colitis ulcerosa, UC) is a form of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD). Ulcerative colitis is a form of colitis, a disease of the colon (large intestine), that includes characteristic ulcers, or open sores. The main symptom of active disease is usually constant diarrhea mixed with blood, of gradual onset. IBD is often confused with irritable bowel syndrome (IBS), a troublesome but much less serious condition. Source: Wikipedia
Ulcerative colitis.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Nausea, Burning abdominal pain, Rectal bleeding, Vomiting, Swollen lymph nodes, Blood in stool, Decreased appetite, Discharge in stools, Melena, Lower abdominal pain, Diarrhea
Ulcerative colitis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for ulcerative colitis include .

Male genitalia infection.description: Male genitalia infection Male genitalia infection is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Male genitalia infection.symptoms: Bumps on penis, Pain in testicles, Swollen abdomen, Skin growth, Penis pain, Irritable infant, Penis redness, Abnormal appearing skin, Mass in scrotum, Warts, Groin pain, Swelling of scrotum
Male genitalia infection.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for male genitalia infection include age 30-44 years, sex == male and age < 1 years. On the other hand, sex == female almost never get male genitalia infection.

HPV.description: HPV Also known as Human Papillomavirus Human papillomavirus (HPV) is a virus from the papillomavirus family that is capable of infecting humans. Like all papillomaviruses, HPVs establish productive infections only in keratinocytes of the skin or mucous membranes. While the majority of the known types of HPV cause no symptoms in most people, some types can cause warts (verrucae), while others can in a minority of cases lead to cancers of the cervix, vulva, vagina, penis, oropharynx and anus. Recently, HPV has been linked with an increased risk of cardiovascular disease. In addition, HPV 16 and 18 infections are strongly associated with an increased odds ratio of developing oropharyngeal (throat) cancer. Source: Wikipedia
HPV.symptoms: Joint pain, Vaginal discharge, Frequent urination, Eyelid lesion or rash, Warts, Mass or swelling around the anus, Vaginal itching, Involuntary urination, Hand or finger lump or mass, Unpredictable menstruation, Coughing up sputum, Lump or mass of breast
HPV.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for hpv include age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = hispanic, sex == female and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get hpv.

Angina.description: Angina Also known as Angina Pectoris, Cardiac Angina, Ischemic Chest Pain, and Anginal Syndrome Angina pectoris commonly known as angina is chest pain due to ischemia of the heart muscle, generally due to obstruction or spasm of the coronary arteries. The main cause of Angina pectoris is coronary artery disease, due to atherosclerosis of the arteries feeding the heart. The term derives from the Latin angina ("infection of the throat") from the Greek ankhon ("strangling"), and the Latin pectus ("chest"), and can therefore be translated as "a strangling feeling in the chest". Source: Wikipedia
Angina.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Irregular heartbeat, Sweating, Lower body pain, Hot flashes, Chest tightness, Palpitations, Increased heart rate, Arm pain, Dizziness, Burning chest pain, Sharp chest pain
Angina.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for angina include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, age 15-29 years, and age < 1 years almost never get angina.

Injury to the spinal cord.description: Injury to the spinal cord Also known as Spinal Cord Injury and Spinal Cord Trauma A spinal cord injury (SCI) refers to any injury to the spinal cord that is caused by trauma instead of disease. Depending on where the spinal cord and nerve roots are damaged, the symptoms can vary widely, from pain to paralysis to incontinence. Spinal cord injuries are described at various levels of "incomplete", which can vary from having no effect on the patient to a "complete" injury which means a total loss of function. Source: Wikipedia
Injury to the spinal cord.symptoms: Drainage in throat, Shoulder pain, Headache, Retention of urine, Arm weakness, Back pain, Side pain, Neck pain, Foot or toe weakness, Arm pain, Throat irritation, Neck cramps or spasms
Injury to the spinal cord.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for injury to the spinal cord include race/ethnicity = other, age 30-44 years and sex == male. On the other hand, race/ethnicity = hispanic and age < 1 years almost never get injury to the spinal cord.

Nasal polyp.description: Nasal polyp Also known as Nose Polyp Nasal polyps are polypoidal masses arising mainly from the mucous membranes of the nose and paranasal sinuses. They are overgrowths of the mucosa that frequently accompany allergic rhinitis. They are freely movable and nontender. Source: Wikipedia
Nasal polyp.symptoms: Painful sinuses, Redness in ear, Headache, Frontal headache, Facial pain, Nasal congestion, Cough, Disturbance of smell or taste, Nosebleed, Difficulty breathing, Allergic reaction, Hoarse voice
tests: Other diagnostic procedures on skin and subcutaneous tissue
Other non-OR therapeutic procedures on nose; mouth and pharynx
Other OR therapeutic procedures on nose; mouth and pharynx
Diagnostic procedures on nose; mouth and pharynx
Nasal polyp.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for nasal polyp include age 45-59 years.

Lichen simplex.description: Lichen simplex Also known as Lichen Simplex Chronicus and Neurodermatitis Circumscripta Lichen simplex chronicus (also known as "Neurodermatitis") is a skin disorder characterized by chronic itching and scratching.:58 The constant scratching causes thick, leathery, brownish skin. Source: Wikipedia
Lichen simplex.symptoms: Skin growth, Difficulty speaking, Itchy scalp, Acne or pimples, Skin lesion, Skin rash, Itching of skin, Vaginal itching, Loss of sex drive, Pain during intercourse, Skin irritation, Skin dryness, peeling, scaliness, or roughness
tests: Other diagnostic procedures on skin and subcutaneous tissue
Lichen simplex.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for lichen simplex include race/ethnicity = other age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get lichen simplex.

Trichiasis.description: Trichiasis Trichiasis is a medical term for abnormally positioned eyelashes that grow back toward the eye, touching the cornea or conjunctiva. This can be caused by infection, inflammation, autoimmune conditions, congenital defects, eyelid agenesis and trauma such as burns or eyelid injury. Source: Wikipedia
Trichiasis.symptoms: Symptoms of eye, Emotional symptoms, Eyelid lesion or rash, Itchiness of eye, Swollen eye, Foreign body sensation in eye, Back weakness, Pus in sputum, Elbow cramps or spasms, Eye redness, Diminished vision, Pain in eye
tests: Other therapeutic procedures on eyelids; conjunctiva; cornea
Trichiasis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for trichiasis include race/ethnicity = other, age 75+ years and age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age 15-29 years almost never get trichiasis.

Acariasis.description: Acariasis Also known as Mite Infestation Acariasis is an infestation with mites. Source: Wikipedia
Acariasis.symptoms: Emotional symptoms, Cross-eyed, Feeling hot and cold, Skin lesion, Vomiting, Excessive growth, Skin rash, Itching of skin, Wrist weakness, Bowlegged or knock-kneed, Swelling of scrotum, Elbow weakness
Acariasis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for acariasis include age 5-14 years age 1-4 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years almost never get acariasis.

Colorectal cancer.description: Colorectal cancer Also known as Colon cancer Colorectal cancer, commonly known as colon cancer or bowel cancer, is a cancer from uncontrolled cell growth in the colon or rectum (parts of the large intestine), or in the appendix. Genetic analysis shows that essentially colon and rectal tumours are genetically the same cancer. Symptoms of colorectal cancer typically include rectal bleeding and anemia which are sometimes associated with weight loss and changes in bowel habits. Source: Wikipedia
Colorectal cancer.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Drainage in throat, Rectal bleeding, Blood in stool, Mass or swelling around the anus, Pain of the anus
Colorectal cancer.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for colorectal cancer include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get colorectal cancer.

Skin pigmentation disorder.description: Skin pigmentation disorder Pigmentation means coloring. Skin pigmentation disorders affect the color of your skin. Skin cells give your skin color by making a substance called melanin. When these cells become damaged or unhealthy, it affects melanin production. Some pigmentation disorders affect just patches of skin. Others affect your entire body. If your body makes too much melanin, your skin gets darker. Pregnancy, Addison's disease and sun exposure all can make your skin darker. If your body makes too little melanin, your skin gets lighter. Vitiligo is a condition that causes patches of light skin. Albinism is a genetic condition affecting all of a person's skin. Infections, blisters and burns can cause lighter skin. Source: MedlinePlus
Skin pigmentation disorder.symptoms: Skin moles, Skin growth, Acne or pimples, Skin lesion, Skin swelling, Too little hair, Skin rash, Abnormal appearing skin, Irregular appearing scalp, Itching of skin, Warts, Skin dryness, peeling, scaliness, or roughness
tests: Other diagnostic procedures on skin and subcutaneous tissue
Other non-OR therapeutic procedures on skin and breast
Skin pigmentation disorder.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for skin pigmentation disorder include race/ethnicity = other.

Factitious disorder.description: Factitious disorder A factitious disorder is a condition in which a person acts as if they have an illness by deliberately producing, feigning, or exaggerating symptoms. Factitious disorder by proxy is a condition in which a person deliberately produces, feigns, or exaggerates symptoms in a person in their care. Mnchausen syndrome, a severe form of factitious disorder, was the first kind identified, and was for a period the umbrella term for all such disorders. People with this condition may produce symptoms by contaminating urine samples, taking hallucinogens, injecting themselves with bacteria to produce infections, and other similar behaviour. They might be motivated to perpetrate factitious disorders either as a patient or by proxy as a caregiver to gain any variety of benefits including attention, nurturance, sympathy, and leniency that are seen as not obtainable any other way. In contrast, somatoform disorders are characterised by multiple somatic complaints, albeit both are diagnoses of exclusion. Source: Wikipedia
Factitious disorder.symptoms: Paresthesia, Loss of sensation, Disturbance of memory, Excessive growth, Itchy eyelid, Wrist weakness, Elbow cramps or spasms, Nailbiting, Depression, Depressive or psychotic symptoms, Lip swelling, Elbow weakness
tests: Psychological and psychiatric evaluation and therapy
Factitious disorder.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for factitious disorder include age 60-74 years. On the other hand, race/ethnicity = black almost never get factitious disorder.

Lymphogranuloma venereum.description: Lymphogranuloma venereum Also known as LGV Lymphogranuloma venereum (also known as "Climatic bubo," "Durand Nicolas Favre disease," "Poradenitis inguinale," and "Strumous bubo") is a sexually transmitted disease caused by the invasive serovars L1, L2, L2a or L3 of Chlamydia trachomatis. Source: Wikipedia
Lymphogranuloma venereum.symptoms: Vulvar sore, Fever, Pelvic pressure, Shoulder swelling, Knee lump or mass, Excessive growth, Loss of sex drive, Nosebleed, Sore throat, Neck cramps or spasms, Ear pain, Chills
Lymphogranuloma venereum.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for lymphogranuloma venereum include age 15-29 years, age 45-59 years and race/ethnicity = white.

Galactorrhea of unknown cause.description: Galactorrhea of unknown cause Galactorrhea of unknown cause is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Galactorrhea of unknown cause.symptoms: Pain or soreness of breast, Emotional symptoms, Burning abdominal pain, Low back weakness, Back pain, Cough, Pelvic pain, Weight gain, Bleeding or discharge from nipple, Anxiety and nervousness, Lump or mass of breast, Sharp chest pain
Galactorrhea of unknown cause.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for galactorrhea of unknown cause include age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = hispanic, sex == female and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, race/ethnicity = other, age 60-74 years, and age 1-4 years almost never get galactorrhea of unknown cause.

G6PD enzyme deficiency.description: G6PD enzyme deficiency Also known as G6pd Deficiency A disease-producing enzyme deficiency subject to many variants, some of which cause a deficiency of GLUCOSE-6-PHOSPHATE DEHYDROGENASE activity in erythrocytes, leading to hemolytic anemia. Source: MeSH
G6PD enzyme deficiency.symptoms: Emotional symptoms, Feeling hot and cold, Low back weakness, Nasal congestion, Cough, Excessive growth, Wrist weakness, Elbow cramps or spasms, Nailbiting, Muscle swelling, Underweight, Elbow weakness
tests: Ophthalmologic and otologic diagnosis and treatment
Other therapeutic procedures on eyelids; conjunctiva; cornea
G6PD enzyme deficiency.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for g6pd enzyme deficiency include sex == male, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, race/ethnicity = black and age < 1 years. On the other hand, age 30-44 years, age 60-74 years, and age 45-59 years almost never get g6pd enzyme deficiency.

Nerve impingement near the shoulder.description: Nerve impingement near the shoulder Also known as Shoulder Impingement Syndrome and Subacromial Impingement Compression of the rotator cuff tendons and subacromial bursa between the humeral head and structures that make up the coracoacromial arch and the humeral tuberosities. This condition is associated with subacromial bursitis and rotator cuff (largely supraspinatus) and bicipital tendon inflammation, with or without degenerative changes in the tendon. Pain that is most severe when the arm is abducted in an arc between 40 and 120 degrees, sometimes associated with tears in the rotator cuff, is the chief symptom. (From Jablonski's Dictionary of Syndromes and Eponymic Diseases, 2d ed) Source: MeSH,Patients with nerve impingement near the shoulder often receive radiographic imaging procedure, physical therapy exercises, plain x-ray, magnetic resonance imaging, other non-or therapeutic procedures on musculoskeletal system, other therapeutic procedures, occupational therapy assessment and other therapeutic procedures on muscles and tendons .
Nerve impingement near the shoulder.symptoms: Shoulder pain, Bones are painful, Vulvar irritation, Neck pain, Muscle pain, Elbow pain, Hand or finger stiffness or tightness, Arm pain, Problems with movement, Shoulder weakness, Knee pain, Shoulder stiffness or tightness
tests: Other non-OR therapeutic procedures on musculoskeletal system
Other therapeutic procedures on muscles and tendons
Nerve impingement near the shoulder.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for nerve impingement near the shoulder include age 60-74 years age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get nerve impingement near the shoulder.

Toxoplasmosis.description: Toxoplasmosis Toxoplasmosis is a parasitic disease caused by the protozoan Toxoplasma gondii. The parasite infects most genera of warm-blooded animals, including humans, but the primary host is the felid (cat) family. Animals are infected by eating infected meat, by ingestion of feces of a cat that has itself recently been infected, or by transmission from mother to fetus. Cats are the primary source of infection to human hosts, although contact with raw meat, especially pork, is a more significant source of human infections in some countries. Fecal contamination of hands is a significant risk factor. Source: Wikipedia
Toxoplasmosis.symptoms: Emotional symptoms, Cross-eyed, Feeling hot and cold, Itchy scalp, Blindness, Excessive growth, Irregular appearing scalp, Wrist weakness, Eye redness, Bowlegged or knock-kneed, Diminished vision, Elbow weakness
tests: Ophthalmologic and otologic diagnosis and treatment
Other therapeutic procedures on eyelids; conjunctiva; cornea
Toxoplasmosis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for toxoplasmosis include race/ethnicity = other age 30-44 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years almost never get toxoplasmosis.

Fibroadenoma.description: Fibroadenoma Fibroadenomas of the breast, are lumps composed of fibrous and glandular tissue. Because breast cancer can also appear as a lump, doctors may recommend a tissue sample (biopsy) to rule out cancer in older patients. Unlike typical lumps from breast cancer, fibroadenomas are easy to move, with clearly defined edges. Source: Wikipedia
Fibroadenoma.symptoms: Pain or soreness of breast, Arm lump or mass, Problems with shape or size of breast, Vaginal dryness, Pain during intercourse, Bleeding or discharge from nipple, Back swelling, Bones are painful, Throat irritation, Hot flashes, Lump or mass of breast
tests: Breast biopsy and other diagnostic procedures on breast
Fibroadenoma.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for fibroadenoma include age 30-44 years, sex == female and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years almost never get fibroadenoma.

Open wound of the hand.description: Open wound of the hand Open wound of the hand is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Open wound of the hand.symptoms: Hand or finger pain, Hand or finger swelling, Hand or finger stiffness or tightness, Skin on arm or hand looks infected
tests: Suture of skin and subcutaneous tissue
Open wound of the hand.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for open wound of the hand include sex == male age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get open wound of the hand.

Missed abortion.description: Missed abortion Miscarriage is the spontaneous end of a pregnancy at a stage where the embryo or fetus is incapable of surviving independently. Miscarriage is the most common complication of early pregnancy. Source: Wikipedia
Missed abortion.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Pain during pregnancy, Recent pregnancy, Cramps and spasms, Spotting or bleeding during pregnancy, Heavy menstrual flow, Infertility, Problems during pregnancy, Blood in stool, Intermenstrual bleeding, Blood clots during menstrual periods, Lower abdominal pain
Missed abortion.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for missed abortion include race/ethnicity = other, age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = hispanic, sex == female and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years, sex == male, age 60-74 years, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, age 45-59 years, and age < 1 years almost never get missed abortion.

Diabetic ketoacidosis.description: Diabetic ketoacidosis Also known as Diabetic Acidosis and Diabetic Ketosis Diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA) is a potentially life-threatening complication in patients with diabetes mellitus. It happens predominantly in those with type 1 diabetes, but it can occur in those with type 2 diabetes under certain circumstances. DKA results from a shortage of insulin; in response the body switches to burning fatty acids and producing acidic ketone bodies that cause most of the symptoms and complications. Source: Wikipedia
Diabetic ketoacidosis.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Frequent urination, Nausea, Diarrhea, Vomiting, Fluid retention, Decreased appetite, Thirst, Polyuria, Weakness, Depressive or psychotic symptoms, Sharp chest pain
Diabetic ketoacidosis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for diabetic ketoacidosis include age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get diabetic ketoacidosis.

Granuloma inguinale.description: Granuloma inguinale Also known as Donovanosis Granuloma inguinale is a bacterial disease caused by Klebsiella granulomatis characterized by ulcerative genital lesions. It is endemic in many less developed regions. It is also known as donovanosis, granuloma genitoinguinale, granuloma inguinale tropicum, granuloma venereum, granuloma venereum genitoinguinale, lupoid form of groin ulceration, serpiginous ulceration of the groin, ulcerating granuloma of the pudendum and ulcerating sclerosing granuloma. Source: Wikipedia
Granuloma inguinale.symptoms: Vulvar sore, Vaginal pain, Nausea, Shoulder swelling, Knee lump or mass, Excessive growth, Wrist weakness, Nailbiting, Groin pain, Loss of sex drive, Neck cramps or spasms, Sharp chest pain
tests: Traction; splints; and other wound care
Granuloma inguinale.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for granuloma inguinale include race/ethnicity = other, race/ethnicity = hispanic and age 15-29 years.

Hemorrhagic fever.description: Hemorrhagic fever The viral hemorrhagic (or haemorrhagic) fevers (VHFs) are a diverse group of animal and human illnesses that may be caused by five distinct families of RNA viruses: the families Arenaviridae, Filoviridae, Bunyaviridae, Flaviviridae, and Rhabdoviridae. All types of VHF are characterized by fever and bleeding disorders and all can progress to high fever, shock and death in many cases. Some of the VHF agents cause relatively mild illnesses, such as the Scandinavian nephropathia epidemica, while others, such as the African Ebola virus, can cause severe, life-threatening disease. Source: Wikipedia
Hemorrhagic fever.symptoms: Pain or soreness of breast, Pain during pregnancy, Joint stiffness or tightness, Facial pain, Shoulder cramps or spasms, Knee lump or mass, Wrist pain, Excessive anger, Ankle pain, Fatigue, Excessive urination at night, Pain in eye
Hemorrhagic fever.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for hemorrhagic fever include race/ethnicity = other, age 30-44 years, race/ethnicity = hispanic, age 75+ years, age 60-74 years, age 5-14 years, age 1-4 years, race/ethnicity = black, age 15-29 years, age 45-59 years and age < 1 years.

Obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD).description: Obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD) Also known as OCD and Obsessive Compulsive Neurosis Obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD) is an anxiety disorder characterized by intrusive thoughts that produce uneasiness, apprehension, fear, or worry; by repetitive behaviors aimed at reducing the associated anxiety; or by a combination of such obsessions and compulsions. Symptoms of the disorder include excessive washing or cleaning; repeated checking; extreme hoarding; preoccupation with sexual, violent or religious thoughts; relationship-related obsessions; aversion to particular numbers; and nervous rituals, such as opening and closing a door a certain number of times before entering or leaving a room. These symptoms can be alienating and time-consuming, and often cause severe emotional and financial distress. The acts of those who have OCD may appear paranoid and potentially psychotic. However, OCD sufferers generally recognize their obsessions and compulsions as irrational, and may become further distressed by this realization. Source: Wikipedia
Obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD).symptoms: Hysterical behavior, Hostile behavior, Lack of growth, Temper problems, Low self-esteem, Fears and phobias, Excessive anger, Depression, Anxiety and nervousness, Obsessions and compulsions, Depressive or psychotic symptoms, Feeling ill
tests: Psychological and psychiatric evaluation and therapy
Obsessive compulsive disorder (OCD).riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for obsessive compulsive disorder (ocd) include age 5-14 years.

Injury of the ankle.description: Injury of the ankle Also known as Ankle injury A sprained ankle, also known as an ankle sprain, twisted ankle, rolled ankle, floppy ankle, ankle injury or ankle ligament injury, is a common medical condition where one or more of the ligaments of the ankle is torn or partially torn. Source: Wikipedia
Injury of the ankle.symptoms: Joint pain, Foot or toe swelling, Ankle stiffness or tightness, Wrist swelling, Leg cramps or spasms, Foot or toe lump or mass, Foot or toe pain, Leg pain, Ankle pain, Foot or toe weakness, Ankle swelling
tests: Physical therapy exercises; manipulation; and other procedures
Injury of the ankle.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for injury of the ankle include .

Hyponatremia.description: Hyponatremia Also known as Sodium Deficiency, Sodium Depletion, and Decreased Serum Sodium Hyponatremia (American English) or hyponatraemia (British English) is an electrolyte disturbance in which the sodium ion concentration in the serum is lower than normal. Sodium is the dominant extracellular cation (positive ion) and cannot freely cross from the interstitial space through the cell membrane, into the cell. Its homeostasis (stability of concentration) inside the cell is vital to the normal function of any cell. Normal serum sodium levels are between 135 and 145 mEq/L. Hyponatremia is defined as a serum level of less than 135 mEq/L and is considered severe when the serum level is below 125 mEq/L. Source: Wikipedia
Hyponatremia.symptoms: Shortness of breath, Sharp abdominal pain, Fever, Fainting, Nausea, Headache, Back pain, Vomiting, Seizures, Dizziness, Weakness, Sharp chest pain
Hyponatremia.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for hyponatremia include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years almost never get hyponatremia.

Stricture of the esophagus.description: Stricture of the esophagus Also known as Esophageal Stricture and Esophageal Stenosis A benign esophageal stricture is a narrowing or tightening of the esophagus that causes swallowing difficulties. Source: Wikipedia
Stricture of the esophagus.symptoms: Difficulty eating, Nausea, Regurgitation, Difficulty in swallowing, Vomiting, Recent weight loss, Stomach bloating, Lump in throat, Heartburn, Problems with movement, Coughing up sputum, Sharp chest pain
Stricture of the esophagus.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for stricture of the esophagus include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get stricture of the esophagus.

Fracture of the ankle.description: Fracture of the ankle Also known as Broken Ankle and Ankle Fracture Fracture of the ankle is encountered rarely on Symcat. We will add more content to this page if enough people like you show interest.
Fracture of the ankle.symptoms: Foot or toe swelling, Foot or toe pain, Leg pain, Ankle pain, Ankle weakness, Ankle swelling, Knee weakness
tests: Traction; splints; and other wound care
Fracture of the ankle.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for fracture of the ankle include age 5-14 years.

Soft tissue sarcoma.description: Soft tissue sarcoma Also known as Sarcoma, Malignant Soft Tissue Tumors, and Mesenchymal Malignant Tumor A soft-tissue sarcoma is a form of sarcoma that develops in connective tissue, though the term is sometimes applied to elements of the soft tissue that are not currently considered connective tissue. Source: Wikipedia
Soft tissue sarcoma.symptoms: Skin moles, Skin growth, Groin mass, Change in skin mole size or color, Skin lesion, Abnormal appearing skin, Itching of skin, Warts, Leg lump or mass, Bones are painful, Irregular appearing nails, Skin dryness, peeling, scaliness, or roughness
tests: Other diagnostic procedures on skin and subcutaneous tissue
Soft tissue sarcoma.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for soft tissue sarcoma include age 75+ years age 60-74 years.

Bone disorder.description: Bone disorder Also known as Bone Disease Bone disease refers to the medical conditions which affect the bone. Source: Wikipedia
Bone disorder.symptoms: Shoulder pain, Difficulty speaking, Leg cramps or spasms, Back pain, Muscle stiffness or tightness, Hot flashes, Leg pain, Stiffness all over, Leg lump or mass, Leg weakness, Bones are painful, Knee pain
Bone disorder.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for bone disorder include age 75+ years age 60-74 years.

Epilepsy.description: Epilepsy Also known as Seizure Disorder Epilepsy is a common and diverse set of chronic neurological disorders characterized by seizures. Some definitions of epilepsy require that seizures be recurrent and unprovoked, but others require only a single seizure combined with brain alterations which increase the chance of future seizures. In many cases a cause cannot be identified; however, factors that are associated include brain trauma, strokes, brain cancer, and drug and alcohol misuse among others. Source: Wikipedia
Epilepsy.symptoms: Abnormal involuntary movements, Difficulty speaking, Headache, Muscle weakness, Disturbance of memory, Lack of growth, Eye moves abnormally, Seizures, Stiffness all over
Epilepsy.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for epilepsy include age 5-14 years.

Personality disorder.description: Personality disorder Personality disorder, according to the current version of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual (DSM-5), refers to a class of maladaptive personality traits, that is, enduring patterns of behavior, cognitions and inner experience that are exhibited across many contexts and deviate markedly from those accepted by the individual's culture. These patterns are inflexible and are associated with significant distress or disability. The definitions may vary some according to other sources. Source: Wikipedia
Personality disorder.symptoms: Drug abuse, Hostile behavior, Temper problems, Low self-esteem, Fears and phobias, Delusions or hallucinations, Excessive anger, Insomnia, Depression, Anxiety and nervousness, Obsessions and compulsions, Depressive or psychotic symptoms
tests: Psychological and psychiatric evaluation and therapy
Personality disorder.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for personality disorder include age 30-44 years age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get personality disorder.

Shingles (herpes zoster).description: Shingles (herpes zoster) Also known as Zoster, Herpes Zoster, and Herpes Zona Herpes zoster (or simply zoster), commonly known as shingles and also known as zona, is a viral disease characterized by a painful skin rash with blisters in a limited area on one side of the body (left or right), often in a stripe. The initial infection with varicella zoster virus (VZV) causes the acute, short-lived illness chickenpox which generally occurs in children and young adults. Once an episode of chickenpox has resolved, the virus is not eliminated from the body but can go on to cause shingles an illness with very different symptoms often many years after the initial infection. Herpes zoster is not the same disease as herpes simplex, despite the name similarity; both the varicella zoster virus and herpes simplex virus belong to the same viral subfamily Alphaherpesvirinae. Source: Wikipedia
Shingles (herpes zoster).symptoms: Ache all over, Sharp abdominal pain, Headache, Facial pain, Back pain, Skin lesion, Side pain, Skin rash, Abnormal appearing skin, Pain in eye, Itching of skin, Sharp chest pain
tests: Other non-OR or closed therapeutic nervous system procedures
Shingles (herpes zoster).riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for shingles (herpes zoster) include age 75+ years age 60-74 years.

Tourette syndrome.description: Tourette syndrome Tourette syndrome (also called Tourette's syndrome, Tourette's disorder, Gilles de la Tourette syndrome, GTS or, more commonly, simply Tourette's or TS) is an inherited neuropsychiatric disorder with onset in childhood, characterized by multiple physical (motor) tics and at least one vocal (phonic) tic. These tics characteristically wax and wane, can be suppressed temporarily, and are preceded by a premonitory urge. Tourette's is defined as part of a spectrum of tic disorders, which includes provisional, transient and persistent (chronic) tics. Source: Wikipedia
Tourette syndrome.symptoms: Sleepiness, Abnormal involuntary movements, Drug abuse, Headache, Temper problems, Delusions or hallucinations, Excessive anger, Abnormal movement of eyelid, Warts, Obsessions and compulsions, Depressive or psychotic symptoms, Allergic reaction
tests: Psychological and psychiatric evaluation and therapy
Tourette syndrome.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for tourette syndrome include sex == male, age 5-14 years and age 15-29 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years and age < 1 years almost never get tourette syndrome.

Avascular necrosis.description: Avascular necrosis Also known as Ischemic Necrosis and Avascular Necrosis Of Bone Avascular necrosis (also osteonecrosis, bone infarction, aseptic necrosis, ischemic bone necrosis, and AVN) is a disease where there is cellular death (necrosis) of bone components due to interruption of the blood supply. Without blood, the bone tissue dies and the bone collapses. If avascular necrosis involves the bones of a joint, it often leads to destruction of the joint articular surfaces. (see Osteochondritis dissecans). Source: Wikipedia
Avascular necrosis.symptoms: Shoulder pain, Drug abuse, Shoulder weakness, Hip pain, Bowlegged or knock-kneed, Knee pain, Shoulder stiffness or tightness
tests: Prostate specific antigen measurement (Prostate specific antigen test)
Avascular necrosis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for avascular necrosis include sex == male age 45-59 years. On the other hand, race/ethnicity = other, age 1-4 years, and age < 1 years almost never get avascular necrosis.

Strep throat.description: Strep throat Also known as Streptococcal Pharyngitis and Streptococcal Sore Throat Streptococcal pharyngitis, streptococcal tonsillitis, or streptococcal sore throat (known colloquially as strep throat) is a type of pharyngitis caused by a group A streptococcal infection. It affects the pharynx including the tonsils and possibly the larynx. Common symptoms include fever, sore throat, and enlarged lymph nodes. It is the cause of 37% of sore throats among children and 5-15% in adults. Source: Wikipedia
Strep throat.symptoms: Ache all over, Fever, Headache, Nasal congestion, Difficulty in swallowing, Cough, Vomiting, Skin rash, Decreased appetite, Sore throat, Ear pain, Chills
Strep throat.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for strep throat include age 5-14 years age 1-4 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years almost never get strep throat.

Spinocerebellar ataxia.description: Spinocerebellar ataxia Also known as Spinocerebellar Atrophy Spinocerebellar ataxia (SCA) is a progressive, degenerative, genetic disease with multiple types, each of which could be considered a disease in its own right. An estimated 150,000 people in the United States are diagnosed with Ataxia, SCA's are the largest group of this hereditary, progressive, degenerative and often fatal neurodegenerative disorders. There is no known effective treatment or cure. Ataxia can affect anyone of any age. It is caused by either a recessive or dominant gene. Many times people are not aware that they carry the ataxia gene until they have children who begin to show signs of having the disorder. Source: Wikipedia
Spinocerebellar ataxia.symptoms: Fainting, Abnormal involuntary movements, Blood in urine, Difficulty speaking, Headache, Foot or toe pain, Cough, Disturbance of memory, Skin rash, Problems with movement, Anxiety and nervousness, Dizziness
tests: Physical therapy exercises; manipulation; and other procedures
Spinocerebellar ataxia.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for spinocerebellar ataxia include age 75+ years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years almost never get spinocerebellar ataxia.

Osteomyelitis.description: Osteomyelitis Also known as Bone Infection Osteomyelitis (sometimes abbreviated to OM, and derived from Greek words osteon, meaning bone, myelo- meaning marrow, and -itis meaning inflammation) is infection and inflammation of the bone or bone marrow. It can be usefully subclassified on the basis of the causative organism (pyogenic bacteria or mycobacteria), the route, duration and anatomic location of the infection. Source: Wikipedia
Osteomyelitis.symptoms: Hand or finger pain, Knee swelling, Hand or finger swelling, Difficulty speaking, Foot or toe swelling, Lymphedema, Skin lesion, Skin on leg or foot looks infected, Arm swelling, Skin on arm or hand looks infected, Bones are painful, Irregular appearing nails
tests: Traction; splints; and other wound care
Debridement of wound; infection or burn
Osteomyelitis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for osteomyelitis include age 75+ years, age 60-74 years and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get osteomyelitis.

Sjogren syndrome.description: Sjogren syndrome Sjogren's syndrome is a disease that causes dryness in your mouth and eyes. It can also lead to dryness in other places that need moisture, such as your nose, throat and skin. Most people who get Sjogren's syndrome are older than 40. Nine of 10 are women. Sjogren's syndrome is sometimes linked to rheumatic problems such as rheumatoid arthritis. Sjogren's syndrome is an autoimmune disease. If you have an autoimmune disease, your immune system, which is supposed to fight disease, mistakenly attacks parts of your own body. In Sjogren's syndrome, your immune system attacks the glands that make tears and saliva. It may also affect your joints, lungs, kidneys, blood vessels, digestive organs and nerves. The main symptoms are: Dry eyes Dry mouth Treatment focuses on relieving symptoms. NIH: National Institute of Arthritis and Musculoskeletal and Skin Diseases Source: MedlinePlus,Patients with sjogren syndrome often receive complete physical skin exam performed (ml), mammography, examination of foot, hip replacement; total and partial, other therapeutic procedures on eyelids; conjunctiva; cornea and bone density scan .
Sjogren syndrome.symptoms: Ache all over, Symptoms of eye, Joint pain, Itchiness of eye, Regurgitation, Difficulty in swallowing, Spots or clouds in vision, Groin pain, Peripheral edema, Mouth dryness, Diminished vision, Pain in eye
tests: Other therapeutic procedures on eyelids; conjunctiva; cornea
Sjogren syndrome.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for sjogren syndrome include age 75+ years, age 60-74 years and sex == female. On the other hand, age 1-4 years, age 15-29 years, and age < 1 years almost never get sjogren syndrome.

Adhesive capsulitis of the shoulder.description: Adhesive capsulitis of the shoulder Also known as Frozen Shoulder Frozen shoulder, medically referred to as adhesive capsulitis, is a disorder in which the shoulder capsule, the connective tissue surrounding the glenohumeral joint of the shoulder, becomes inflamed and stiff, greatly restricting motion and causing chronic pain. Source: Wikipedia
Adhesive capsulitis of the shoulder.symptoms: Ache all over, Shoulder pain, Ankle stiffness or tightness, Shoulder swelling, Neck pain, Muscle pain, Elbow pain, Stiffness all over, Arm pain, Skin on arm or hand looks infected, Shoulder stiffness or tightness
tests: Other diagnostic radiology and related techniques
Other non-OR therapeutic procedures on musculoskeletal system
Other therapeutic procedures on muscles and tendons
Adhesive capsulitis of the shoulder.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for adhesive capsulitis of the shoulder include race/ethnicity = other, age 60-74 years and age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get adhesive capsulitis of the shoulder.

Viral hepatitis.description: Viral hepatitis Viral hepatitis is liver inflammation due to a viral infection. It may present in acute (recent infection, relatively rapid onset) or chronic forms. The most common causes of viral hepatitis are the five unrelated hepatotropic viruses Hepatitis A, Hepatitis B, Hepatitis C, Hepatitis D, and Hepatitis E. In addition to the nominal hepatitis viruses, other viruses that can also cause liver inflammation include Herpes simplex, Cytomegalovirus, Epstein-Barr virus, or Yellow fever. Source: Wikipedia
Viral hepatitis.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Incontinence of stool, Drug abuse, Abusing alcohol, Low self-esteem, Symptoms of the kidneys, Hand or finger stiffness or tightness, Stomach bloating, Melena
Viral hepatitis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for viral hepatitis include race/ethnicity = other age 45-59 years. On the other hand, age < 1 years almost never get viral hepatitis.

Tonsillar hypertrophy.description: Tonsillar hypertrophy Palatine tonsils, occasionally called the faucial tonsils, are the tonsils that can be seen on the left and right sides at the back of the throat. Source: Wikipedia
Tonsillar hypertrophy.symptoms: Drainage in throat, Abnormal breathing sounds, Redness in ear, Fever, Swollen or red tonsils, Nasal congestion, Difficulty in swallowing, Cough, Apnea, Hurts to breath, Sore throat, Allergic reaction
tests: Ophthalmologic and otologic diagnosis and treatment
Other OR therapeutic procedures on nose; mouth and pharynx
Tonsillar hypertrophy.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for tonsillar hypertrophy include race/ethnicity = hispanic, age 5-14 years and age 1-4 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years almost never get tonsillar hypertrophy.

Gastritis.description: Gastritis Also known as Stomach Inflammation and Gastric Inflammation Gastritis is an inflammation of the lining of the stomach, and has many possible causes. The main acute causes are excessive alcohol consumption or prolonged use of nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (also known as NSAIDs) such as aspirin or ibuprofen. Sometimes gastritis develops after major surgery, traumatic injury, burns, or severe infections. Gastritis may also occur in those who have had weight loss surgery resulting in the banding or reconstruction of the digestive tract. Chronic causes are infection with bacteria, primarily Helicobacter pylori, chronic bile reflux, and stress; certain autoimmune disorders can cause gastritis as well. The most common symptom is abdominal upset or pain. Other symptoms are indigestion, abdominal bloating, nausea, and vomiting and pernicious anemia. Some may have a feeling of fullness or burning in the upper abdomen. A gastroscopy, blood test, complete blood count test, or a stool test may be used to diagnose gastritis. Treatment includes taking antacids or other medicines, such as proton pump inhibitors or antibiotics, and avoiding hot or spicy foods. For those with pernicious anemia, B12 injections are given, but more often oral B12 supplements are recommended. Source: Wikipedia
Gastritis.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Fever, Burning abdominal pain, Nausea, Headache, Diarrhea, Regurgitation, Vomiting, Vomiting blood, Upper abdominal pain, Heartburn, Sharp chest pain
Gastritis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for gastritis include race/ethnicity = hispanic.

Skin cancer.description: Skin cancer Also known as Malignant Neoplasm Of Skin Skin cancers (skin neoplasms) are named after the type of skin cell from which they arise. Basal cell cancer originates from the lowest layer of the epidermis, and is the most common but least dangerous skin cancer. Squamous cell cancer originates from the middle layer, and is less common but more likely to spread and, if untreated, become fatal. Melanoma, which originates in the pigment-producing cells (melanocytes), is the least common, but most aggressive, most likely to spread and, if untreated, become fatal. Still, melanoma has one of the higher survival rates among major cancer, with over 75% of patients surviving 10 years in the UK during 2005-2007. Source: Wikipedia
Skin cancer.symptoms: Skin moles, Skin growth, Skin lesion, Skin swelling, Acne or pimples, Abnormal appearing skin, Irregular appearing scalp, Itching of skin, Warts, Lip swelling, Skin irritation, Skin dryness, peeling, scaliness, or roughness
tests: Other diagnostic procedures on skin and subcutaneous tissue
Other non-OR therapeutic procedures on skin and breast
Skin cancer.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for skin cancer include age 75+ years, age 60-74 years and race/ethnicity = white. On the other hand, age 1-4 years and age < 1 years almost never get skin cancer.

Rheumatic fever.description: Rheumatic fever Also known as Polyarthritis Rheumatica Rheumatic fever is an inflammatory disease that occurs following a Streptococcus pyogenes infection, such as streptococcal pharyngitis or scarlet fever. Believed to be caused by antibody cross-reactivity that can involve the heart, joints, skin, and brain, the illness typically develops two to three weeks after a streptococcal infection. Acute rheumatic fever commonly appears in children between the ages of 6 and 15, with only 20% of first-time attacks occurring in adults. The illness is so named because of its similarity in presentation to rheumatism. Source: Wikipedia
Rheumatic fever.symptoms: Vulvar sore, Bedwetting, Pelvic pressure, Itchiness of eye, Shoulder swelling, Joint stiffness or tightness, Knee lump or mass, Excessive growth, Eye strain, Loss of sex drive, Neck cramps or spasms, Nailbiting
Rheumatic fever.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for rheumatic fever include race/ethnicity = other, age 60-74 years, age 15-29 years and age 45-59 years.

Aphthous ulcer.description: Aphthous ulcer Also known as Canker Sore, Aphthous Stomatitis, and Aphtha Aphthous stomatitis (also termed canker sores, recurrent aphthous stomatitis, RAS, recurring oral aphthae and recurrent aphthous ulceration) is a common cause of benign and non-contagious mouth ulcers (canker sores). This condition is characterized by the repeated formation of ulcers on the mucous membrane of the oral cavity (the lining of the mouth), in otherwise healthy individuals. These ulcers occur periodically and heal completely between attacks. Symptoms range from a minor nuisance to interfering with eating and drinking. The cause is not completely understood, but may involve a T cell mediated immune response which is triggered by a variety of factors. Different people may have different triggers, including nutritional deficiencies, local trauma, stress, hormonal influences, allergies, and a genetic predisposition. The condition is very common, affecting about 20% of the general population. There is no cure, and treatments are aimed at reducing pain and speeding the healing process. Often, the onset of the condition is during childhood or adolescence and usually lasts for several years before gradually disappearing, with or without any form of treatment. Source: Wikipedia
Aphthous ulcer.symptoms: Ache all over, Fever, Headache, Mouth ulcer, Lip sore, Cough, Skin rash, Swollen tongue, Mouth pain, Toothache, Sore throat, Tongue lesions
Aphthous ulcer.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for aphthous ulcer include age 5-14 years age 1-4 years.

Tonsillitis.description: Tonsillitis Also known as Tonsil Inflammation Tonsillitis is inflammation of the tonsils most commonly caused by viral or bacterial infection. Symptoms may include sore throat and fever. When caused by a bacterium belonging to the group A streptococcus, it is typically referred to as strep throat. The overwhelming majority of people recover completely with or without medication. In 40%, symptoms will resolve in three days, and within one week in 85% of people, regardless of whether streptococcal infection is present or not. Source: Wikipedia
Tonsillitis.symptoms: Drainage in throat, Abnormal breathing sounds, Redness in ear, Swollen or red tonsils, Nasal congestion, Apnea, Diminished hearing, Lump in throat, Sore throat, Throat redness, Throat feels tight, Allergic reaction
tests: Ophthalmologic and otologic diagnosis and treatment
Other OR therapeutic procedures on nose; mouth and pharynx
Diagnostic procedures on nose; mouth and pharynx
Tonsillitis.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for tonsillitis include age 5-14 years age 1-4 years. On the other hand, age 75+ years almost never get tonsillitis.

Intestinal cancer.description: Intestinal cancer Also known as Bowel Cancer, Cancer Of Intestines, and Malignant Neoplasm Of Intestine Colorectal cancer, commonly known as colon cancer or bowel cancer, is a cancer from uncontrolled cell growth in the colon or rectum (parts of the large intestine), or in the appendix. Genetic analysis shows that essentially colon and rectal tumours are genetically the same cancer. Symptoms of colorectal cancer typically include rectal bleeding and anemia which are sometimes associated with weight loss and changes in bowel habits. Source: Wikipedia
Intestinal cancer.symptoms: Sharp abdominal pain, Pain in testicles, Changes in stool appearance, Neck mass, Foot or toe swelling, Regurgitation, Throat feels tight, Mouth pain, Decreased appetite, Jaundice, Lump or mass of breast, Diarrhea
Intestinal cancer.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for intestinal cancer include age 75+ years age 60-74 years. On the other hand, age 5-14 years and age 1-4 years almost never get intestinal cancer.

Rocky Mountain spotted fever.description: Rocky Mountain spotted fever Also known as Rocky Mountain Tick Fever Rocky Mountain spotted fever is the most lethal and most frequently reported rickettsial illness in the United States. It has been diagnosed throughout the Americas. Some synonyms for Rocky Mountain spotted fever in other countries include tick typhus, Tobia fever (Colombia), So Paulo fever or febre maculosa (Brazil), and fiebre manchada (Mexico). It is distinct from the viral tick-borne infection, Colorado tick fever. The disease is caused by Rickettsia rickettsii, a species of bacterium that is spread to humans by Dermacentor ticks. Initial signs and symptoms of the disease include sudden onset of fever, headache, and muscle pain, followed by development of rash. The disease can be difficult to diagnose in the early stages, and without prompt and appropriate treatment it can be fatal. Source: Wikipedia
Rocky Mountain spotted fever.symptoms: Pain or soreness of breast, Pain during pregnancy, Joint stiffness or tightness, Headache, Facial pain, Shoulder cramps or spasms, Knee lump or mass, Wrist pain, Excessive anger, Ankle pain, Fatigue, Pain in eye
Rocky Mountain spotted fever.riskGroups: Groups of people at highest risk for rocky mountain spotted fever include sex == female, age 15-29 years and race/ethnicity = white.
